<page> <title>aapg_bulletin</title><text>{{infobox journal\n| title = aapg bulletin\n| cover = [[file:aapg bulletin low res cover.gif]]\n| editor = \n| discipline = [[geosciences]]\n| former_names = the american association of petroleum geologists bulletin (1967-1974, {{issn|0002-7464}}); bulletin of the american association of petroleum geologists (1918-1967, {{issn|0883-9247}}); bulletin of the southwestern association of petroleum geologists (1917-1918)\n| abbreviation = \n| publisher = [[american association of petroleum geologists]]\n| country = united states\n| frequency = monthly\n| history = 1917-present\n| openaccess = \n| license = \n| impact = 1.964\n| impact-year = 2010\n| website = http://www.aapg.org/bulletin/\n| link1 = \n| link1-name = \n| link2 = \n| link2-name = \n| jstor = \n| oclc = \n| lccn = \n| coden = aabud2\n| issn = 0149-1423\n| eissn = 1558-9153\n}}\nthe \'\'\'\'\'aapg bulletin\'\'\'\'\' is a monthly peer-reviewed [[scientific journal]] covering [[geosciences]] and associated technologies relating to the energy industry. it is an official journal of the [[american association of petroleum geologists]].\n\n==abstracting and indexing==\nthis journal is abstracted and/or indexed in: [[georef]], [[geobase (database)|geobase]], [[scopus]], [[pubmed]], [[current contents]], and [[web of science]].<ref>{{cite web|title=aapg bulletin|url=https://ulrichsweb.serialssolutions.com/title/1319213330857/41446|work=ulrichsweb|publisher=proquest llc.|accessdate=21 october 2011}}</ref>\n\n==references==\n<references />\n\n==external links==\n{{official website|http://www.aapg.org/bulletin/}}\n\n[[category:publications established in 1917]]\n[[category:geology journals]]\n[[category:english-language journals]]\n[[category:monthly journals]]\n\n\n{{geology-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>aar_type_a_switcher_truck</title><text>[[image:bn 440 19920900 il eola.jpg|thumb|sw-1000 with switcher trucks]]\n[[image:rigid switcher.jpg|thumb|150|right|side profile of the aar type switcher truck.]]\nthe \'\'\'aar type a switcher truck\'\'\' is a [[diesel locomotive]] [[bogie|truck]] introduced by [[electro-motive diesel|emd]] and installed as standard equipment on most emd [[switcher]] locomotives and on those of other manufacturers. it was designed by [[martin p blomberg]] and its us patent was filed on jul 6, 1937 and approved nov 15, 1938 under {{us patent|2,137,074}}. it was designed for switcher service where the more complex high-speed passenger locomotive trucks were not needed. the truck uses drop equalizers but does not have swing hangers as used on the [[blomberg b]] and others. a combination of [[coil spring]]s, and [[leaf springs]], positioned fore-and-aft inside the drop equalizers, give a good balance of [[damping]]. the [[wheelbase]] is {{convert|8|ft|mm|0|abbr=on}}.\n\n== see also ==\n* [[bogie|truck]]\n* [[blomberg b]]\n\n{{locomotive running gear}}\n\n[[category:bogie]]\n\n\n{{diesel-loco-stub}}\n\n{{defaultsort:aar type a switcher truck}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>abb_grain</title><text>{{infobox_company\n|company_name   = abb grain limited\n|company_logo   = [[image:abb grain limited logo.png|100px]]\n|company_type = \n|foundation = 1939<ref name=\"ngr\">{{cite web|url=http://www.ngr.com.au/shareholders.aspx|title=shareholders|publisher=\'\'national growers register\'\'|accessdate=10 may 2008}}</ref>\n|location       =  [[adelaide]], [[wool]], [[fertiliser]], [[chemicals]], storage and handling services\n|revenue        = \n|net_income     = \n|homepage       = \n}}\n\n\'\'\'abb grain\'\'\' was [[australia]]\'s largest [[agribusiness]]. founded in 1939, the company was listed on the [[australian securities exchange]] until its takeover by [[viterra]] in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abb.com.au/aboutabb/whoweare.aspx|title=who we are|publisher=\'\'abb grain\'\'|accessdate=28 april 2008}}</ref> until recently, the company focused solely on [[grain]] accumulation and marketing. it expanded its focus to other activities, such as [[grain elevator|grain receival and storage]], [[malt]]ing and [[fertiliser]]s. abb buys grain from all growing regions in australia and trades in all grain commodities.\n\n== history ==\nabb traces its origins to the former australian barley board, and due to the company\'s expanded operations into different areas, it demutualised to become abb grain on 1 july 1999.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fas.usda.gov/grain/circular/1999/99-08/dtricks.htm|title=foreign countries\' policies and programs|date=13 november 2003|publisher=\'\'[[foreign agricultural service]]\'\'|accessdate=28 april 2008}}</ref> in 2004, abb merged with the [[south australia]]n storage and handling company ausbulk and the holding company united grower holdings. this brought the control of the two major grain handlers, along
<page> <title>abc_cinemas</title><text>{{refimprove|date=march 2010}}\n{{infobox company|\n|type = cinema chain\n|name = abc cinemas\n|foundation = 1927\n|defunct = 2000\n|logo = [[file:abc cinema logo.jpg]]\n|successor = [[odeon cinemas]], [[cineworld]]\n}}\n\'\'\'abc cinemas\'\'\' (\'\'associated british cinemas\'\') was a [[movie theatre|cinema]] chain in the [[united kingdom]]. a wholly owned subsidiary of [[associated british picture corporation]] (abpc), it operated between the 1930s and the late 1960s. the [[brand name]] was reused in the 1990s until 2000.\n\n==history==\n[[file:abc cinema butlins bognor regis.jpg|thumb|right|the still open abc cinema at [[butlins bognor regis]], [[west sussex]].]]\n\n===early years===\nabc cinemas was established in 1927 by solicitor john maxwell<ref>{{cite book | last1 = gardiner | first1 = juliet | title = the thirties: an intimate history | chapter = prologue | publisher = harper press | year = 2010 | location = london | pages = 663 | isbn = 978-0-00-724076-0}}</ref> by merging three smaller scottish cinema circuits. it became a wholly owned cinema subsidiary of [[british international pictures]] when it was merged with the production arm of [[british national studios]], which had been formed by maxwell in 1926.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.competition-commission.org.uk/rep_pub/reports/1960_1969/fulltext/034c02.pdf | title = films - a report on the supply of films for exhibition in cinemas | accessdate = 2011-01-01 | year = 1966 | publisher = hmso}}</ref>\n\nduring the thirties it grew rapidly by acquisitions and an ambitious building programme under the direction of chief architect w.r.glen, who had been appointed in about 1929<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.scottisharchitects.org.uk/architect_full.php?id=100595 | title = dsa architect biography report | accessdate = 2011-01-01 | work = dictionary of scottish architects}}</ref> and maintained a distinct house style. existing cinemas which could not be re-modelled
<page> <title>abc_dj</title><text>{{infobox television\n| show_name = abc dj\n| image = \n| caption = \'\'abc dj\'\' title card\n| format = [[sitcom]]\n| camera = [[single camera setup|single camera]]\n| runtime = 30 minutes (with commercials)\n| executive_producer = [[daisy irani]]<br>[[hossan leong]]\n| starring = [[eugene lee (actor)|eugene lee]]<br>[[richard loh]]<br>[[ezann lee]]<br>[[deng mao hui]]<br>[[margaret lim]]<br>[[marcus chin]]<br>[[subin subiah]]\n| narrated = \n| country = [[singapore]]\n| network = [[mediacorp tv channel 5]]\n| first_aired = 23 may 2006 \n| last_aired = 15 august 2006\n| num_episodes = 13 \n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'abc dj\'\'\'\'\' is a [[singapore]]an sitcom on [[mediacorp tv channel 5]]. this show often makes references to sensitive issues such as [[culture shock]] and [[racial discrimination]].\n\n==plot summary and cast==\n===dj (dong-jin) and master zhang===\nthis series is about an [[american-born chinese]] \"[[spoiled brat|brat]]\" from [[beverly hills]] named chia dong-jin, also known as dong-jin or dj ([[eugene lee (actor)|eugene lee]]), who is a rich, spoilt and almost-worthless [[americanized]] chinese that was sent or banished to [[singapore]] by his father, master zhang, to live with a conservative chinese family, the gohs, so that dj will learn about [[chinese culture]].\n\ndj was tricked by his father into going to [[singapore]]. he thought he was in [[singapore]] on a vacation when he received a phone call from his father, explaining to dj that he had come to [[singapore]] not for a vacation but to live with the goh family to learn the traditional chinese culture from them. however, dj did not adapt well to the chinese traditions, such as [[filial piety]].  during the stay with the goh family, dj was often being threatened or bullied by goh, and his family. dj was often regarded as a [[chinese people|chinese]] [[ang moh]], a [[singlish]] term for a [[chinese people|chinese]] person who lives in [[western world|the west]].\n\
<page> <title>abc_radio_grandstand</title><text>{{use dmy dates|date=april 2012}}\n{{use australian english|date=april 2012}}\n{{primarysources|date=may 2010}}\n<!--  commented out because image was deleted: [[file:abc-logo.jpg|125px|right]] -->\n\'\'\'abc radio grandstand\'\'\' is a live radio sports focused commentary and talk-back program which runs on the [[australian broadcasting corporation]] local radio network across [[australia]] and on one digital-only station.  the program runs on saturdays and sundays, typically from noon or an hour before, until 6 pm. sports that are covered by abc radio under the grandstand banner include test and one day international [[cricket]], [[rugby league]] (mostly in [[queensland]] and [[new south wales]]), the [[summer olympics]], [[australian football league]] games, [[australian open]] [[tennis]] and occasional [[soccer]] matches, including games involving the [[socceroos]] and the [[a-league]] grand final. however, when there are major football, cricket or tennis matches in progress, or the olympics and commonwealth games, the coverage is often continued for the entirety of the relevant time frame if grandstand is broadcasting the competition, as opposed to simply reporting the results. this can result in broadcasts in the early hours of the morning if australia is playing in a cricket test on another side of the world.\n\nbeing a national program with significant local content, grandstand includes live crosses to local abc radio stations for sporting updates as well as centralised broadcasts of major events.\n\npresenters include:\n*[[charlie king (sports broadcaster)|charlie king]] (nt)\n*[[gerard whateley]] (vic)\n*[[dan lonergan]] (vic)\n*[[quentin hull]] (qld)\n*[[simone thurtell]] (nsw)\n*[[karen tighe]] (wa)\n*[[peter walsh (sports broadcaster)|peter walsh]] (sa)\n* clint wheeldon (wa)\n* david morrow (nsw)\n* jim maxwell (nsw)\n* drew morphett (vic)\n* alistair nicholson (qld)\n* corbin middlemas (wa)\n* matt clinc

<page> <title>abc_symphony_australia_young_performers_awards</title><text>the \'\'\'abc symphony australia young performers awards\'\'\' is the current name of a classical music competition for young people that has been run annually since 1944.  it is generally considered the most prestigious australian classical music competition not restricted to a single instrument.  \n\nit is conducted by the [[australian broadcasting corporation]] in conjunction with [[symphony australia]] (a trading name of [[symphony services international|symphony services australia limited]], a non-profit arts organisation that operates both domestically and internationally).\n\n==names==\nthe competition has had a number of names throughout its history. <ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/tv/ypa/about/ abc: ypa]</ref>\n* it was founded in 1944 by the then [[australian broadcasting commission]] as a set of six state-based competitions.\n* in 1950 it was given the name \'\'\'abc concerto and vocal competition\'\'\'.  \n* in 1968 it became known as the \'\'\'abc instrumental and vocal competition\'\'\'.  \n* in 1987 it was renamed the \'\'\'abc young performers awards\'\'\'. \n* in 1997 the concerts division of the abc devolved to become [[symphony australia]], and the competition was then known as the \'\'\'symphony australia young performers awards\'\'\'. \n* in 2005 after a corporate restructure within symphony australia, the competition was rebranded as the \'\'\'abc symphony australia young performers awards\'\'\'.\n\n==format==\nthe structure of the competition has also undergone numerous changes.  initially, there were six state-based competitions, with no overall winner.  in 1949, the six state winners competed for the commonwealth final for the first time.  in 1950, singers and instrumentalists were separated.  in 1968 a preliminary recital stage was introduced and the instrumental categories were divided into keyboard and other.  in 1978, four categories were introduced: vocal, orchestral 
<page> <title>abc_tropical_north</title><text>{{infobox radio station \n|image     =<!-- deleted image removed:  [[image:abclocalradio.png]] -->|\n|name      = abc tropical north|\n|callsign = 4qaa|\n|coordinates = {{coord|21|08|24.94|s|149|11|21.79|e|type:landmark_scale:2000_region:au}}\n|airdate   = 1951 |\n|frequency = 101.1 [[megahertz|mhz]] [[frequency modulation|fm]] mackay|\n|area      = [[mackay, queensland|mackay]]|\n|owner = [[australian broadcasting corporation]] |\n|format = [[talk radio|talk]] |\n|website = [http://www.abc.net.au/tropic/ http://www.abc.net.au/tropic/] |\n}}\n\n\'\'\'abc tropical north\'\'\' is an [[abc local radio]] station based in [[mackay, queensland|mackay]] and broadcasting to the surrounding [[regions of queensland#mackay|region]] in [[queensland]].  this includes the towns of [[proserpine, queensland|proserpine]], [[sarina, queensland|sarina]], [[bowen, queensland|bowen]] and the [[whitsunday islands]].\n\nthe station began broadcasting as \'\'\'4qa\'\'\' in 1951 on 756 am, originally as a relay of the national program.  studios were then built and local programs began in 1955.  the station now broadcasts through the following main [[fm broadcasting|fm]] transmitters along with a number of low-power fm repeaters:\n\n*\'\'\'4qaa\'\'\' 101.1 fm\n*\'\'\'4qaa/t\'\'\' 104.9 fm\n*\'\'\'4qaa/t\'\'\' 91.7 fm\n\n==local programs==\n===weekdays===\n\n*breakfast with meecham philpott – 5:30am to 8:00 am\n*mornings with kim kleidon – 8:30 am to 11:00 am\n\n===saturday===\n\n*saturday breakfast – 6:00 am to 10:00 am\n\nabc tropical north produces and broadcasts rural news & information which is hosted by miriam hall as well as the mornings program which is usually hosted by aaron stevens or kim kleidon and is broadcast throughout queensland using the abc local radio queensland branding.\n\nwhen local programs are not broadcast the station is a relay of [[abc capricornia]], [[abc southern queensland]] and [[612 abc brisbane]].\n\n==refer
<page> <title>abc_of_emergency_radiology</title><text>{{infobox book |\n| name          = abc of emergency radiology\n| title_orig    =\n| translator    =\n| image = otto chan - abc of emergency radiology.jpeg\n| image_caption =\n| author        = [[dr otto chan]] (editor)\n| illustrator   =\n| cover_artist  =\n| country       = [[england]]\n| language      = [[english language|english]]\n| series        =\n| genre         = nonfiction\n| publisher     =\n| release_date  = 2007\n| english_release_date =\n| media_type    = paperback\n| pages         =\n| isbn          =  978-0-7279-1528-3\n| dewey= 305.42 21\n| congress=\n| oclc=\n| preceded_by   =\n| followed_by   =\n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'abc of emergency radiology\'\'\'\'\' is a book edited by british [[radiologist]] [[otto chan]]. it is meant to be useful in emergencies by providing examples to refer to. the book addresses the difficulties in evaluating a radiograph during emergency situations. it also highlights comparisons between normal and abnormal radiographs. one of the main themes of the book is how to avoid the mistakes that can occur.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.barnesandnoble.com/abc-of-emergency-radiology/otto-chan/e/9780727915283 |title=abc of emergency radiology, abc series, otto chan, book - barnes & noble |publisher=search.barnesandnoble.com |date=2009-04-23 |accessdate=2010-03-21}}</ref> it is aimed at trainee radiologists and medical students.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lavoisier.fr/notice/fr608523.html |title=livre abc of emergency radiology (2nd ed.), médecine d\'urgence, radiologie et imagerie medicale, edition lavoisier |publisher=lavoisier.fr |date= |accessdate=2010-03-21}}</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==external links==\n* chan, o., walsh, m., and wilson, a. (14-05-2005) [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/pmc557900/ extract from \'\'abc of emergency radiology\'\']. [[national center for biotechnology information]], [[united states national library of medicine]].\n* chan,

<page> <title>ab_doradus_moving_group</title><text>\'\'\'ab doradus moving group\'\'\' is a group of about 30 associated stars that are moving through space together with the star [[ab doradus]]. a [[moving group]] is distinguished by its members having about the same age, composition (or [[metallicity]]) and motion through space. hence they most likely formed in the same location.\n\nthis group is located about 20 [[parsec]]s from the [[earth]] and is the closest known co-moving group. the average [[stellar kinematics|space velocity]]\nof this group has components of u&nbsp;=&nbsp;−8, v&nbsp;=&nbsp;−27 and w&nbsp;=&nbsp;−14&nbsp;km/s. about 10 of these stars form a nuclear group within a volume roughly 10 [[parsec]]s\nacross.<ref name=apj613>\n{{cite journal\n | last1=zuckerman |first1=b.\n | last2=song |first2=i.\n | year=2004 \n | title=the ab doradus moving group\n | journal=[[the astrophysical journal]]\n | volume=613 |issue=1 |pages=l65–l68\n | bibcode=2004apj...613l..65z\n | doi=10.1086/425036\n}}</ref>\n\nthe proximity of this moving group makes it useful for studies of shared stellar properties, as well as detection of companions through direct imaging. these can be used for refinement of young stellar models, for example.<ref>\n{{cite journal\n | last1=hormuth | first1=f.\n | last2=brandner |first2=w.\n | last3=hippler |first3=s.\n | last4=janson |first4=m.\n | last5=henning |first5=t.\n | year=2007 \n | title=direct imaging of the young spectroscopic binary hd 160934 \n | journal=[[astronomy and astrophysics]]\n | volume=463 | issue=2 | pages=707–711\n | arxiv=astro-ph/0612158\n | bibcode=2007a&a...463..707h\n | doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20066765\n}}</ref>\n\n==age==\nthe age of the ab dor moving group has been somewhat controversial, with quoted ages in the range of ~50 to ~150 myr, however recent work seems\nto have converged on an age similar to that of the pleiades (130+-20 myr)\n.<ref name=barrado>{{cite journal\n | last1=barrado y navascues

<page> <title>ac_crusaders</title><text>{{infobox football club\n| clubname    = ac crusaders\n| image       = [[image:accrusaders.png|175px]]\n| fullname    = ac crusaders\n| nickname    = crusaders\n| founded     = 2010\n| ground      = [[egg harbor township high school]]<br>[[egg harbor township, new jersey]]\n| capacity    = 3,000\n| chrtitle    = owner\n| chairman    = {{flagicon|sco}} [[matt driver]]\n| mgrtitle    = head coach\n| manager     = {{flagicon|wal}} [[barry lynch]]\n| league      = [[national premier soccer league]]\n| season      = [[2011 npsl season|2011]]\n| position    = inaugural season\n| american    = true\n| current     = \n| pattern_la1 = \n| pattern_b1  = _unknown\n| pattern_ra1 = \n| leftarm1    = \n| body1       = \n| rightarm1   = \n| shorts1     = \n| socks1      = \n| pattern_la2 =\n| pattern_b2  = _unknown\n| pattern_ra2 =\n| leftarm2    = \n| body2       = \n| rightarm2   = \n| shorts2     = \n| socks2      = \n| }}\n\n\'\'\'ac crusaders\'\'\' is an american [[association football|soccer]] team based in [[egg harbor township, new jersey]], [[united states]]. founded in 2010, the team will make its debut in the northeast keystone division of the [[national premier soccer league]] (npsl), the fourth tier of the [[american soccer pyramid]], in 2011.\n\nthe team plays its home games in the stadium at [[egg harbor township high school]]. the club\'s colors, and other details have yet to be announced.\n\n==history==\n{{empty section|date=march 2011}}\n\n==players==\n{{fs start}} \n{{fs mid}}\n{{fs end}}\ntimothy van liew\nrich ongaro \nmario declerico \nemmanuel asangmbeng \nsonimi halliday \nchris hayman \ndan fairhurst \nnick bolton \ngreig edwards \ntom o’rourke\nevan jaep \neddie campbell \nadam williamson \nrichard stone \nfederico diaz \nwilliam swetra \nneal melchionni \njulian berrios \nadam sternberger \ngreg biggiani \nrodney aguirre \njames totczyk \nmicheal ryan j\nnico tramonata \nanthony procupio \nabdullah zubair \njerem
<page> <title>ac_diomidis_argous</title><text>{| style=\"margin:5px; border:1px solid #87ceff;\" align=\"right\" cellpadding=3 cellspacing=3 width=280\n|- align=\"center\" bgcolor=\"#87ceff\"\n| colspan = 2| \'\'\'ac diomidis argous\'\'\'\n|- align=\"center\"\n| colspan = 2|[[image:ac_diomidis_argous_logo.jpg|210px|logo]]\n|- align=\"center\" \n| colspan = 2|  \n|- align=\"center\" bgcolor=\"#eeeeee\" \n| \'\'\'founded\'\'\' || 1976\n|- align=\"center\" \n| \'\'\'full name\'\'\' ||ac diomidis argous<br>\n|- align=\"center\" bgcolor=\"#eeeeee\"\n| \'\'\'arena\'\'\' || \'\'\'[[argos]] municipal athletic center\'\'\'\n|- align=\"center\" \n| \'\'\'club colours\'\'\' || green & white\n|- align=\"center\" bgcolor=\"#eeeeee\"\n| \'\'\'website\'\'\' || [http://www.diomidis-handball.gr/ www.diomidis-handball.gr]\n|}\n\n\'\'\'ac diomidis argous\'\'\'  is a [[team handball]] club from [[argos]], [[greece]]. they currently compete in the [[greek men\'s handball championship|greek handball championship]]. popularly nicknamed the \"wolves\", the team won for the first time the [[ehf challenge cup]] in 2012, downing in the final [[wacker thun]]. it was also the first time a greek team won a european title in a handball club competition. the victory was celebrated in argos before a crowd of several thousand people.\n\n==achievements==\n*1 [[ehf challenge cup]]: 2012\n*1 [[greek men\'s handball championship|greek championship]]: 2012\n\n\n==external links==\n* [http://www.diomidis-handball.gr official website]\n\n[[category:greek handball clubs]]\n\n{{handball-team-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>ac_pure</title><text>{{infobox network |\nlogo         = |\nnetwork_name = ac pure|\ncountry      = [[united states]]|\nnetwork_type = [[radio network]]|\navailable    = national|\nowner        = [[waitt radio networks]] <br><small>(through [[triton media group]])</small>|\nkey_people   = chuck denver, christina cooper, dennis anderson, kevin conners, cami carlisle|\nlaunch_date  = 2003|\nfounder      = |\npast_names   = |\nbrand        = |\nwebsite      = [http://www.wrnonline.com/formats/acpure/content.aspx ac pure website] |\n}}\n\'\'\'ac pure\'\'\' was a 24-hour music format produced by [[waitt radio networks]] and then by [[dial global]] under its [[dial global local]] banner. its playlist was composed of [[adult contemporary]] music released from the 1970s to this day from artists such as [[phil collins]], [[celine dion]], [[rod stewart]] [[gloria estefan]], [[michael bolton]], etc. that mainly targeted listeners ages 25-54. \n\nin june 2012, due to reorganizations at dial global, the dial global local 24/7 formats were fully integrated into dial global\'s portfolio of formats, and \"dial global local\" ceased to exist as a brand name. however, most of the former dial global local formats are still offered to affiliate stations in the same manner in which they were previously offered. ac pure continues as a local version of dial global\'s adult contemporary format.\n\n==competitor networks==\n*[[hits & favorites]] by [[cumulus media|abc radio networks]]\n\n== external links == \n*[http://www.wrnonline.com/formats/acpure/content.aspx ac pure - info from waitt radio networks]\n\n{{triton media}}\n\n[[category:radio formats]]\n[[category:american radio networks]]</text> </page>

<page> <title>adt_championship</title><text>the \'\'\'adt championship\'\'\' was a women\'s professional [[golf]] tournament on the [[united states|u.s.]]-based [[lpga|lpga tour]]. the season-ending event on the tour, it became the \'\'\'lpga playoffs at the adt\'\'\' from 2006 through 2008.\n\n==history==\nthe tournament was played in its final playoff form for the first time in november [[2006 lpga tour|2006]]; the champion of the event, [[julieta granada]], won $1 million, the highest first-place prize in the history of women\'s golf.  the event took place at the [[trump international golf club]] in [[west palm beach]], [[florida]].\n\nfrom [[1996 lpga tour|1996]] through [[2005 lpga tour|2005]] the tournament was a standard, 72-hole [[stroke play]] event. it had a purse of $1,000,000 in its final season, with a winner\'s share of $215,000.\n\nthe playoff event in 2006 was the first time golf has ever used a postseason of any kind on any tour. beginning in [[2007 pga tour|2007]], the [[pga tour]] also employed a playoff system.\n\nthrough the [[2008 lpga tour|2008]] season, the title sponsor was [[adt security services|adt]], a worldwide supplier of electronic security and fire alarm systems, communication systems and integrated building management systems, with headquarters in [[boca raton, florida]].\n\n==successors==\non october 16, 2008 it was announced adt would not extend its sponsorship.<ref name=\"adt1\">\n{{cite web\n  | last = \n  | first = \n  | title = adt declines to extend sponsor relationship\n  | publisher = lpga\n  | date = \n  | url = http://www.lpga.com/content_1.aspx?pid=17729&mid=1\n  | accessdate = 2009-11-21 }}\n</ref> another entirely new tournament,<ref name=\"adt2\">\n{{cite web\n  | last = \n  | first = \n  | title = lpga tour championship presented by rolex\n  | publisher = lpga\n  | date = \n  | url = http://www.lpga.com/tournament_microsite.aspx?id=18532\n  | accessdate = 2009-11-21 }}\n</ref> the [[lpga tour championship]], took adt

<page> <title>afc_challenge_cup</title><text>{{infobox football tournament\n| logo                 = [[file:afc challenge cup.svg|150px]]\n| caption              = official logo of the afc challenge cup\n| founded              = 2006\n| region               = [[asia]] ([[asian football confederation|afc]])\n| number of teams      = 8 (finals)\n| current champions    = {{fb|prk}}<br>(2nd title)\n| most successful team = {{fb|prk}}<br>(2 titles)\n| website              = \n| current              = [[2014 afc challenge cup]]\n}}\nthe \'\'\'afc challenge cup\'\'\' is an international [[association football|football]] competition for [[asian football confederation]] (afc) member countries that are categorized as \"emerging countries\" in the \"vision asia\" programme.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.the-afc.com/uploads/documents/competitions/bangladesh_afccc2006_competitionsregulations.pdf |title=regulations - afc challenge cup |work=the-afc.com |publisher=asian football confederation |accessdate=2012-03-26 }}</ref>  \"vision asia\", created by former afc president, [[mohammed bin hammam]], is the afc\'s plan for a continent wide programme to raise the standards of asian football at all levels.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.the-afc.com/en/vision-asia-philosophy |title=visiona asian philosophy |work=the-afc.com |publisher=asian football confederation |date=2007-08-31 |accessdate=2012-03-26 }}</ref>  the afc challenge cup, which reflects the philosophy of vision asia, was created for teams to experience playing in a continental competition with the possibility to win an afc trophy and to potentially discover new talent.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.the-afc.com/en/challenge-cup-previous-competitions/afc-challenge-cup-2006/afc-challenge-cup-2006-competition-information |title=afc challenge cup in 2006 competition information |work=the-afc.com |publisher=asian football confederation |accessdate=2012-03-26 }}</ref>\n\nthe inaugural tournament was hosted by [[bangladesh]] in 
<page> <title>afl_trade_week</title><text>the \'\'\'afl trade week\'\'\' is a period of time which during which [[australian football league]] (afl) clubs are permitted to exchange players and draft picks with each other. trade week takes place shortly after the conclusion of each afl season, but prior to the [[afl draft|national draft]]. this is the only time during the afl season or off-season when clubs are allowed to make trades.\n\nclubs are permitted to exchange players, draft picks in the next national draft, or compensation draft picks during trade week; draft picks in the preseason draft or the rookie draft, or non-compensation draft picks for future seasons cannot be traded. it is permissible for a club to trade a player in exchange for a very low draft pick that it does not ultimately use, serving effectively as a direct player transfer.\n\nthe majority of trades are simple exchanges between two clubs, but more complicated exchanges involving three or more clubs are permissible, and are not uncommon.\n\nfrom the 2012 season onwards, the duration of trade week has been lengthened from one week to three. afl football operations manager [[adrian anderson]] explained that the afl had decided to expand trade week due to the introduction of [[free agency]].<ref>{{cite web|last=macgugan|first=mark|title=trade \'week\' upped to three|url=http://www.afl.com.au/tabid/208/default.aspx?newsid=131862|publisher=australian football league|accessdate=25 april 2012|date=30 march 2012}}</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n[[category:australian football league draft]]\n\n\n{{afl-stub}}</text> </page>

<page> <title>agla_france</title><text>{{infobox non-profit\n|non-profit_name   = lgbt advocacy group\n|non-profit_logo   = [[file:logo agla france small.jpg|width:150px|right:150px|agla france logo]]\n|non-profit_type   = association loi 1901\n|founded_date      = 2001\n|founder           = micha meroujean\n|location          = france\n|origins           =\n|key_people        = -\n|area_served       =\n|product           =\n|focus             = advocacy for lgbt rights in armenia\n|method            = [[social network|networking]], [[civil society campaign|campaigning]], [[advocacy]], [[outreach]], [[community media]], tv, radio and internet\n|revenue           =\n|endowment         =\n|num_volunteers    =\n|num_employees     =\n|num_members       = 40\n|subsib            =\n|owner             =\n|non-profit_slogan = \"love knows no gender!\"\n|homepage          = [http://www.agla.info www.agla.info]\n|dissolved         = 2007\n|footnotes         =\n}}\n[[file:agla france in le marais 21 02 2004.jpg|200px|left|thumb|agla france members\' sit in demonstration against hate crimes, paris, circa february 2004]]\n[[file:agla18.jpg|200px|left|thumb|agla france at the gay and lesbian pride march, paris. banner reads \"armenia must abolish the anti-gay law\", circa june 2002]]\n\'\'\'agla france\'\'\' (association des gays et lesbiennes arméniens de france) ({{lang-en|association of gay and lesbian armenians of france}}, {{lang-hy|Ֆրանսահայ Միասեռականների Ասոցիացիա}}) was a paris-based advocacy group working to fight widespread [[homophobia]] in [[armenia]]<ref>[http://www.unhcr.org/cgi-bin/texis/vtx/refworld/rwmain?page=search&docid=45f147e128&skip=0&query=gays%20in%20armenia/ report by canadian government: the situation of homosexuals and lesbians in armenia]</ref> and among [[armenians in france]]<ref>[http://www.france-armenie.fr/sommaire/sommaire03-2004.pdf \"hay et homo: d\'une reconnaissance à l\'autre\"], \"france arménie\" magazi
<page> <title>ag_securities_v_vaughan</title><text>{{infobox court case\n| name = ag securities v vaughan\n| court = house of lords\n| image = \n| caption = \n| date decided = \n| full name = ag securities v vaughan; antoniades v villiers\n| citations =  [1990] 1 ac 417, [1988] 3 all er 1058\n| judges = \n| prior actions =  \n| subsequent actions = \n| opinions = \n| transcripts =\n| keywords = lease\n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'ag securities v vaughan\'\'\'\'\' [1990] 1 ac 417 was an [[english land law]] case concerning the concept of exclusive possession in defining what is a [[lease]].\n\n==facts==\nag securities, an unlimited company, had a long lease of 25 linden mansions, hornsey lane, london, with four bedrooms and communal areas. it rented to nigel vaughan and three others. each moved in at different times from 1982, signing independent agreements. in may 1985 ag securities terminated the agreements. they claimed they jointly held the lease and therefore had statutory protection. judge held there was no lease. court of appeal held the occupiers had a lease. sir george waller dissented.\n\nin the second case, mr antoniades had a long lease of 6 whiteley rd, upper norwood, london, with a bedroom, kitchen and bathroom, and rented it to mr villiers and miss bridger. they moved in together and signed identical agreements on 9 february 1985. it stated that the rent acts did not apply and that ‘the licensor is not willing to grant... exclusive possession’ and that the use of the flat was ‘in common with the licensor and such other licensees or invitees as he may permit from time to time’. clause 16 said that other people could use the rooms. in 1986 mr antoniades claimed possession. statute would limit the power to remove them. judge held they did have a lease. the court of appeal held they were licensees.\n\n==house of lords==\nthe house of lords held that mr vaughan with his co-tenants were licensees but that mr villiers and ms bridger had leases. lord templeman view

<page> <title>aida_interactive_educational_freeware_diabetes_simulator</title><text>\'\'\'aida\'\'\' is a [[freeware]] [[computer program]] that permits the interactive [[simulation]] of [[blood plasma|plasma]] [[insulin]] and [[blood glucose]] profiles for demonstration, [[teaching]], self-learning, and [[research]] purposes.<ref>{{cite journal |title=experience with the internet release of aida v4 — an interactive educational diabetes simulator |journal=diabetes technol ther |volume=1 |issue= |pages=41–54 |year=1999 |format=pdf |url=http://www.2aida.net/aida/articles/dtt-v1n1-aida-paper.pdf}}</ref>   originally developed in 1991,<ref>{{cite journal |title=a physiological model of glucose-insulin interaction |journal=in: ieee embs proceedings, 13th annual international conference of the ieee engineering in medicine and biology society |volume=13 |issue=5 |pages=2274–2275 |year=1991 |format=pdf |url=http://www.2aida.net/aida/articles/aida-ieee-embs-physiological-model-paper-1991.pdf}}</ref> it has been updated and enhanced since, and made available without charge from 1996 on the [[world wide web]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=lehmann ed |title=diabetes moves onto the internet |journal=lancet |volume=347 |issue=9014 |pages=1542 |year=1996 |month=june}}</ref>  the freeware [[software]] can be downloaded now from: http://www.2aida.org and http://www.2aida.net as well as from numerous freeware software repositories <ref>{{cite journal |author=selected example freeware software repositories hosting the aida diabetes software simulator |title=download32.com  |url=http://www.download32.com/aida-diabetes-software-simulator-program-4-3a-i51119.html}} {{cite journal |title=freedownloadscenter.com |url=http://www.freedownloadscenter.com/programming/visual_basic_components_h-p/aida_freeware_diabetes_software_simulator_program_of_blood_glucose_insulin_action.html}} {{cite journal |title=softpedia.com |url=http://www.softpedia.com/get/others/home-education/aida-diabetes-sof
<page> <title>aids_clinical_trials_group</title><text>{{unreferenced|date=december 2009}}\n[[file:aids_clinical_trials_group_logo.gif|thumb|right|actg logo]]\nthe \'\'\'aids clinical trials group\'\'\' network (actg) is one of the largest [[hiv]] clinical trials organizations in the world, playing a major role in setting standards of care for hiv infection and [[opportunistic diseases]] related to hiv and [[aids]] in the [[united states]] and the [[developing world]]. the actg is composed of, and directed by, leading clinical scientists in hiv/aids therapeutic research. the actg is funded by the [[department of health and human services]], [[national institutes of health]] through the [[national institute of allergy and infectious diseases]].\n\n==mission==\nthrough innovative studies of the treatment of hiv-1 infection and its complications, actg research focuses on: \n\n*new therapies based on knowledge of the cellular events and reactions in the development of disease (pathogenesis) \n*treatment strategies to limit replication of hiv-1 and improve disease-free survival among infected individuals \n*rapid development of agents (drugs or treatment strategies) that prevent or delay the complications of hiv-related disorders \n*hiv-1 pathogenesis through advanced laboratory investigation \n*recruitment and retention of clinical trial participants who reflect the changing demographics of the aids epidemic \n*therapeutic approaches that improve quality of life for persons with hiv-1 infection\n\n==history==\nthe actg has been pivotal{{cn|date=october 2013}} in providing the data necessary for the approval of therapeutic agents, as well as treatment and prevention strategies, for many opportunistic infections and malignancies.\n\n:in 1986, the original aids treatment and evaluation units were established by the national institutes of health. \n:in 1987, the aids clinical trials group (actg) was established by the national institute of allergy and infectious diseases. \n

[[malcolm fraser]], on [[australia day|26 january]] 1981 and was originally named the national indoor sports centre and was the inaugural home of the [[australian institute of sport]].\n\nthe ais <page> <title>aj_taylor</title><text>{{for|the modern historian|a. j. p. taylor}}\n\n\'\'\'dr arnold joseph taylor cbe\'\'\' (1911–2002) was a distinguished medieval [[historian]], who specialised in his study of [[castle]]s. his work on [[edward i of england|edward i]]\'s welsh castles is particularly notable.\n\n==references==\n*[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/arnold-taylor-603616.html obituary], \'\'the independent\'\', 8 november 2002\n\n==external links==\n*{{worldcat id|lccn-n50-8664}}\n\n{{authority control|viaf=40614136}}\n\n{{persondata <!-- metadata: see [[wikipedia:persondata]]. -->\n| name              = taylor, a. j.\n| alternative names =\n| short description = british historian\n| date of birth     = 1911\n| place of birth    =\n| date of death     = 2002\n| place of death    =\n}}\n{{defaultsort:taylor, a. j.}}\n[[category:commanders of the order of the british empire]]\n[[category:british medievalists]]\n[[category:1911 births]]\n[[category:2002 deaths]]\n\n\n{{uk-historian-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>akap</title><text>the \'\'\'a-kinase anchor proteins (akaps)\'\'\' are a group of structurally diverse [[proteins]], which have the common function of binding to the regulatory subunit of [[protein kinase a]] (pka) and confining the [[holoenzyme]] to discrete locations within the cell. at least 20 akaps have been cloned.<ref>{{cite journal |author=schwartz jh |title=the many dimensions of camp signaling |journal=proc. natl. acad. sci. u.s.a. |volume=98 |issue=24 |pages=13482–4 |year=2001 |month=november |pmid=11717418 |doi=10.1073/pnas.251533998 |url= |pmc=61065}}</ref> there are at least 50 members, often named after their molecular mass. \n\n*[[akap1]]\n*[[akap2]]\n*[[akap3]]\n*[[akap4]]\n*[[akap5]]\n*[[akap6]]\n*[[akap7]]\n*[[akap8]]\n*[[akap9]]\n*[[akap10]]\n*[[akap11]]\n*[[akap12]]\n*[[akap13]]\n\n== function ==\n\nakaps act as a signaling hub that assembles signaling proteins on a scaffold that itself targets to various domains, such as the nucleus, in cells. this allows specific targeting of substrates to be regulated by phosphorylation (by pka) and dephosphorylation (by phosphatases).\nthe dimerization and docking (d/d) domain of the regulatory subunit dimer of pka binds with the a-kinase binding (akb) domain (an amphipathic helix) of akap.\nthe akaps also bind other components, including; phosphodiesterases (pdes) which break down camp, phosphatases which dephosphorylate downstream pka targets and also other kinases (pkc and mapk).\nsome akaps are able to bind both regulatory subunits (ri & rii) of pka and are dual-specific akaps (d-akap1 and d-akap2)\n\n== references ==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{defaultsort:akap}}\n[[category:proteins]]\n\n\n{{protein-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>akg</title><text>\'\'\'akg\'\'\' is a three-letter abbreviation with multiple meanings, as described below:\n\n*[[akg acoustics]], an american owned, austrian manufacturer of audio electronics\n*[[alpha-ketoglutaric acid]],  also known as 2-ketoglutaric acid, 2-oxopentanedioic acid, 2-oxoglutamate, 2-oxoglutaric acid & oxoglutaric acid\n*[[asian kung-fu generation]], a japanese rock band\n*[[alternatív közgazdasági gimnázium]], a high school in budapest, hungary\n*[[a.k. gopalan]], an indian communist leader\n*the icao code for [[no. 84 squadron raf]], united kingdom\n\n{{disambig}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>alargan_international_real_estate_company</title><text>{{orphan|date=december 2008}}\n{{unreferenced|date=december 2008}}\n{{infobox company \n| name = alargan international real estate company <br/> شركة الأرجان العالمية العقارية\n| logo = \n| type = private \n| foundation = 1994\n| location = [[kuwait]]  \n| key_people = - khaled k. al-mashaan <br>chairman<br>- hamad al-mudhaf<br>vice-chairman\n| industry = \n| homepage = http://www.alargan.com\n}}\n\n\'\'\'alargan international real estate company\'\'\' is a [[kuwait]]i [[real estate development]] company. alargan underwent an [[initial public offering]] on the [[kuwait stock exchange]] in july 2007. \"alargan projects\" a sister company of alargan projects was established in riyadh, kingdom of saudi arabia in 2005. owing to the size of the kingdom, alargan successfully formed alliances with prime strategic partners from all the major provinces in the kingdom which has hugely benefited all its on-going projects.\n\n\nabout alargan: \n\nthe chairman of the company is mr. [[khaled al mashaan]]. www.alargan.com\n\n==external links==\n* [http://www.alargan.com/ official website]\n\n{{defaultsort:alargan international real estate}}\n[[category:real estate companies]]\n[[category:companies of kuwait]]\n\nengineer [[eyad albunyan]] [[إياد عبدالرحمن البنيان]] is the chief executive officer of \"alargan projects\" which is a sister company of alargan, and considered as the investment arm of alargan in the kingdom of saudi arabia. alargan is known as one of the most successful real estate developers in k.s.a. it is one of the fast growing companies in k.s.a.</text> </page>

<page> <title>alpao</title><text>{{infobox company\n| name\t\t=alpao sas\n| industry \t=[[deformable mirror]]<br/>[[adaptive optics]]\n| founded\t= [[grenoble]], france (2006)\n| founder \t= dr. frédéric rooms\n| location_city=montbonnot, france\n| area_served\t= worldwide\n| products \t = [[deformable mirror]] and [[adaptive optics]] systems\n| homepage \t=  [http://www.alpao.com/ www.alpao.com] \n| num_employees\t= 10-20 \n| revenue          = 1-2 m€ \n}}\n \n\'\'\'alpao\'\'\' manufactures a range of [[adaptive optics]] products for use in research and industry, including [[deformable mirror]]s with large strokes, [[wavefront sensor]]s, and [[adaptive optics]] loops. \nthese products are designed for [[astronomy]], [[vision science]], [[microscopy]], wireless optical communications, and [[laser]] applications.\n\n==history==\nalpao developed from groundwork at the [[université joseph fourier]] ([[grenoble]]) and floralis. in 2006 and 2008 alpao received  awards for innovative technology from the french ministry of research. other alpao partners include the institut de planetologie et d\'astrophysique de grenoble, oseo, anr, région rhône-alpes, grenoble alpes incubation, the reseau entreprendre and ubi france. \n\n* 2009 alpao introduces a new drive electronics increasing the performances of magnetic deformable mirrors. \n* 2008 alpao introduces a new patented technology for deformable mirrors with increased strokes and improved optimal temporal response.  \n* 2007 alpao introduces its own wavefront sensor for closed loop operations  \n* 2006 alpao introduces a low speed deformable mirror.\n\n==applications==\nalpao’s [[deformable mirror]]s can be used in the following disciplines for image enhancement:\n\n===vision science===\ndiagnosing illnesses of the eye may require high resolution images of the retina. images taken using conventional instruments may be too poor in quality due to aberrations introduced by the eye itself. <page> <title>alpha_academy</title><text>{{lead rewrite|date=september 2009}}\n\n{{infobox secondary school\n| name = alpha academy\n| principal = keith doehrmann\n| city = [[magnolia, texas|magnolia]]\n| state = [[texas]]\n| country = [[united states|us]]\n| type = public secondary\n| students = approx. 65\n| grades = typically 10–12\n| district = magnolia independent school district\n| website = http://joomla.magnoliaisd.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=category&sectionid=6&id=21&itemid=574\n| website name = alhpa academy official website\n}}\n\nthe \'\'\'alpha program\'\'\' is a learning program. it allows an alternative route to graduation for students who have not been successful  in the  traditional setting. the program is not intended for students with discipline problems. opportunities are offered for  students to complete the appropriate credits for graduation. teacher assisted and technology-driven programs are available for credit recovery. in addition, classes for acceleration and [[texas assessment of knowledge and skills]] (taks) remediation are available.\n\n==goals==\n*  provide students with innovative and flexible opportunities for achieving success while earning a high school diploma.<ref>[http://joomla.magnoliaisd.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=231&itemid=339 alternative schooling<!-- bot generated title -->]</ref>\n\n*  provide a setting that gives the student an opportunity to develop a positive self-concept through achieving success.<ref>[http://joomla.magnoliaisd.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=231&itemid=339 small campus<!-- bot generated title -->]</ref>\n\n==mission==\nalpha academy is an accelerated learning program, servicing students who have not been successful or have faced challenges in the traditional school setting. the mission of alpha academy is to provide a learning experience that is student centered, nurturing and supportive, academically comprehensive, educationally sensitive to the varied

<page> <title>amice_consortium</title><text>\'\'\'amice consortium\'\'\' was a european organization of major companies concerned with [[computer integrated manufacturing]] (cim). it was initiated in 1985 and dissolved in 1995, and eventually included users, vendors, consulting companies, and academia.<ref name=\"nia07\"> qianfu nia et al. (2006). \"business information modeling for process integration in the mold making industry\". in: \'\'robotics and computer-integrated manufacturing\'\', volume 23, issue 2, april 2007, pp. 195-207.</ref> among the participating companies were [[ibm]], [[hewlett-packard]], [[digital equipment corporation]] (dec), [[siemens]], [[fiat]], and [[daimler-benz]].<ref>ted williams (2000) \"[http://www.pera.net/arc_cimosa.html cimosa european enterprise integration concept]\" on \'\'pera.net\'\'. last updated august 21, 2000 by . accessed july, 30, 2013.</ref> \n\nthe amice consortium was initiated as [[european strategic program on research in information technology]] (esprit) project<ref>joão josé pinto ferreira (2004) \'\'e-manufacturing: business paradigms and supporting technologies\'\'. p. 242</ref> to bring together stakeholders in the development of computer integrated manufacturing for the development of new standards for cim-systems. this lead to the development of the [[computer integrated manufacturing open systems architecture]] (cimosa), which defined \"a comprehensive set of constructs sufficient to describe all aspects of manufacturing systems.\"<ref>manfred klittich (1991) \"from cim to cim-osa a step ahead in system integration.\"\'\'computer integrated manufacturing\'\'. p. 55-65</ref> this [[reference architecture]] can model the functions, information, resources and organisation of any particular enterprise. \n\n== publications ==\nthe amice consortium has published several books and papers. a selection:\n* 1989. \'\'open system architecture for cim, research report of esprit project 688\'\', vol. 1, springer-verla

group\'\'\' is a large mini coach and executive vehicle hire operator based in [[liphook]], [[hampshire]]. it was founded in 1973 by kevin and angela moger.<ref name=history>[http://www.amkxl.com/history.html history] amk group</ref>\n\nit specialises in long-term contract hire for the public sector, run on behalf of local authorities and the [[national health service]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailyecho.co.uk/business/1092674.amk_geared_up_for_future_with_buyout/|title=amk geared up for future with buy-out|first=matt|last=smith |date=28 december 2006|work=\'\'[[southern daily echo]]\'\'}}</ref> \n \nas at october 2013 amk operate 140 vehicles making it one of the largest mini coach operators in the united kingdom. it also provides chauffeur driven mini coach hire and operates dial-a-bus services in and around [[liphook]] as well as five conventional bus services.<ref name=history/><ref>[http://www.amkxl.com/bus.html bus services] amk group</ref> \namk also provides vehicle servicing and [[mot test]]s.
<page> <title>ams_carat</title><text>\n{|{{infobox aircraft begin\n  |name = carat a \n  |logo = <!--only for an individual logo of the aircraft model, (not the main manufacturer logo)-->\n  |image = carat motorglider on ground.jpg\n  |caption =\n|co\n}}{{infobox aircraft type\n  |type = high performance [[motorglider]]\n  |national origin=[[germany]]\n  |manufacturer = [[ams flight|ams-flight]], [[ljubljana]]\n  |designer = <!--only appropriate for single designers, not project leaders-->\n  |first flight = 16 december 1997\n  |produced = <!--years in production, e.g. 1970-1999, if still in active use but no longer built-->\n  |number built = 31 by september 2009\n  |program cost= <!-- total program cost. -->\n  |unit cost = <!-- incremental or flyaway cost for military aircraft or retail price for commercial aircraft. -->\n  |developed from = <!-- the aircraft which formed the basis for the topic type -->\n  |variants with their own articles = <!-- variants of the topic type -->\n}}\n|}\n\nthe \'\'\'carat a\'\'\' is a single-seat, high performance [[motorglider]]. the sailplane was originally designed and built by [[technoflug]] in [[germany]] and is now manufactured by [[ams flight|ams-flight]] in slovenia.<ref name=jawa11/><ref name=\"wdla11\">bayerl, robby; martin berkemeier; et al: \'\'world directory of leisure aviation 2011-12\'\', page 141. wdla uk, lancaster uk, 2011. issn 1368-485x</ref>\n\n==design and development==\n\nthe carat was designed by technoflug around the [[wing]]s and horizontal tail of the [[schempp-hirth discus]] [[sailplane]], marrying these to a new [[fuselage]], [[fin]], [[undercarriage]] and engine..  structurally the aircraft is a mixture of [[glass fibre|fibre]]glass and [[carbon fibre]] [[composite material|composites]]. the wings have [[pvc]] foam cores.  in plan the wings have parallel [[chord (aircraft)|chord]] inner panels and two outer sections of increasing straight taper. [[winglets]] are an option. schempp-hirth type [[air br
<page> <title>amt_coffee</title><text>{{refimprove|date=march 2011}}\n\'\'\'amt coffee\'\'\' is a [[united kingdom|uk]] chain of [[coffeehouse]]s that are mainly located in [[railway station]]s. it was founded in 1992 by alistair mccallum toppin and his two brothers angus and alan. their first shop opened in [[oxford]] city centre. amt was the first coffee company in the uk to use 100% [[fairtrade]] coffee and 100% organic milk.<ref name=\"amtc home\">{{cite web|title=welcome to amt coffee|url=http://www.amtcoffee.co.uk/|publisher=amt coffee|accessdate=3 march 2011}}</ref>\n\namt also operate coffee kiosks which are normally on station concourses. sometimes these are expanded into \'amt coffee lounges\' which are kiosks combined with a small seating area.\n\nnew bars recently opened in stratford international station, guys hospital, gatwick airport and eastbourne.\n\n== locations ==\nas of november 2010 amt coffee has 68 locations across the uk and western europe.\n \n*uk rail 37\n*uk airport 8\n*uk hospital 5\n*uk other 9\n*eire rail 3\n*belgium rail 4\n*germany rail 2\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==external links==\n* [http://www.amtcoffee.co.uk official website]\n\n{{uk food}}\n\n{{defaultsort:amt coffee}}\n[[category:coffee houses of the united kingdom]]\n[[category:restaurants established in 1992]]\n[[category:1992 establishments in the united kingdom]]</text> </page>	
<page> <title>amx_international</title><text>{{unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=december 2009}}\n\'\'\'amx international\'\'\' is a [[joint venture]] between [[alenia aeronautica|alenia]] (46.5%), [[embraer]] (29.7%) and [[aermacchi]] (23.6%) to build the [[amx international amx|amx]] [[ground attack aircraft]]. the company is headquartered in [[rome]].\n\nthe partner companies produce different sections of the aircraft as follows:\n* alenia: centre fuselage section and tail fin\n* embraer: wings, elevators, air intakes, landing gear, fuel tanks\n* aermacchi: front and rear fuselage sections\n\n{{aviation lists}}\n\n{{defaultsort:amx international}}\n[[category:multinational aircraft manufacturers]]\n[[category:brazil–italy relations]]\n[[category:alenia aermacchi]]\n\n{{aero-company-stub}}</text> </page>

stands for \'\'anis mohamed youssef ferchichi\'\', bushido\'s real name. the album released on october 12, 2012 over [[ersguterjunge]]. videos has been shoot to the \"intro\" and the two singles \"kleine bushidos\" (released on october 4, 2012) and \"theorie & praxis\" (november 9, 2012), and were put online on bushido\'s youtube channel.\n\nbefore the album\'s release date, bushido has put <page> <title>and_gate</title><text>{| class=\"wikitable\" align=right\n|- bgcolor=\"#ddeeff\" align=\"center\"\n|colspan=2|\'\'\'input\'\'\' || \'\'\'output\'\'\'\n|- bgcolor=\"#ddeeff\" align=\"center\"\n| a || b || a and b\n|- bgcolor=\"#ddffdd\" align=\"center\"\n|0 || 0 || 0\n|- bgcolor=\"#ddffdd\" align=\"center\"\n|0 || 1 || 0\n|- bgcolor=\"#ddffdd\" align=\"center\"\n|1 || 0 || 0\n|- bgcolor=\"#ddffdd\" align=\"center\"\n|1 || 1 || 1\n|}\nthe \'\'\'and gate\'\'\' is a basic digital [[logic gate]] that implements [[logical conjunction]] - it behaves according to the [[truth table]] to the right. a high output (1) results only if both the inputs to the and gate are high (1). if neither or only one input to the and gate is high, a low output results. in another sense, the function of and effectively finds the \'\'minimum\'\' between two binary digits, just as the or function finds the \'\'maximum\'\'. therefore, the output is always 0 except when all the inputs are 1s.\n\n==symbols==\n\nthere are three symbols for and gates: the american ([[ansi]] or \'military\') symbol and the [[international electrotechnical commission|iec]] (\'european\' or \'rectangular\') symbol, as well as the deprecated [[din]] symbol. for more information see [[logic gate#symbols|logic gate symbols]].\n  \n\n{| align=center style=\"text-align:center\"\n|[[image:and ansi.svg]]\n|[[image:and iec.svg]]\n|[[image:and din.svg]]\n|-\n|\'\'mil/ansi symbol\'\'\n|\'\'iec symbol\'\'\n|\'\'din symbol\'\'\n|}\n\nthe and gate with inputs \'\'a\'\' and \'\'b\'\' and output \'\'c\'\' implements the logical expression <math>c = a \\\\cdot b</math>.\n\n==implementations==\n{|\n| [[image:nmos and gate.png|thumb|nmos and gate]] || [[image:and gate diode.svg|thumb|and gate using diodes]]\n|}\nan and gate is usually designed using n-channel (pictured) or p-channel [[mosfet]]s. the digital inputs \'\'\'a\'\'\' and \'\'\'b\'\'\' cause the output \'\'\'f\'\'\' to have the same result as the and function.\n\n=
<page> <title>an_railway</title><text>{{infobox sg rail|\nrailroad_name=an railway|\nlogo_filename=g&w_an_logo.png|\nlogo_size=81|\nsystem_map=|\nmap_size=|\nmap_caption=|\nimage=psj an rr co bldg01.jpg|\nimage_caption=the apalachicola northern\'s headquarters in port st. joe, florida.|\nmarks=an|\nlength={{convert|96|mi|abbr=on}}|\nlocale=[[florida panhandle]]|\nstart_year=1907|\nhq_city=[[port saint joe, florida]]|\n}}\n\nthe \'\'\'an railway\'\'\' {{reporting mark|an}} is one of several [[short-line railroad|shortline]] railroad companies owned by the [[genesee & wyoming inc.|genesee & wyoming]] parent company. it operates between [[port saint joe, florida]] and a connection with [[csx]]\'s pensacola & atlantic and tallahassee subdivisions at [[chattahoochee, florida]], with a short spur to [[apalachicola, florida]]. the railroad operates approximately {{convert|96|mi}} of track.\n\n==overview==\nthe \'\'\'apalachicola northern railroad\'\'\' was chartered on april 7, 1903. construction began on march 21, 1905, and trains began running north from apalachicola in 1907. the extension to port st. joe was completed on may 10, 1910.\n\nthe company operated in [[receivership]] on three separate occasions: july 1907 to october 1908, may 1914 to february 1916 and may 1932 to december 1936.\n\nthe company came under ownership of [[alfred i. du pont]] in 1933, along with the entire town of port st. joe. the railroad\'s largest customer, the [[st. joe company#st. joe paper company|st. joe paper company]] mill in port st. joe, was owned by the [[alfred i. dupont testamentary trust]] from 1936 to 1996.<ref name=hnet>[http://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.cgi?path=281131086612921 humanities & social sciences online: \'\'green empire: the st. joe company and the remaking of florida\'s panhandle\'\' by kathryn ziewitz and june wiaz-2004 isbn 978-0-8130-2697-8]</ref>  on september 30, 1940, [[edward ball (businessman)|edward ball]], who managed the du pont trust properties, transf
<page> <title>aolpress</title><text>[[file:aolpress icon.png|right|thumb|140px|aolpress icon]]\n[[file:aolpress screenshot.png|right|thumb|140px|aolpress on windows 2000]]\n\'\'\'aolpress\'\'\' was an [[html editor#wysiwyg editors|html editor]] available from [[america online|aol]]. it was originally developed as \'\'\'navipress\'\'\' by the company [[navisoft]] before being bought by aol. it was discontinued in 2000. however, the last version (2.0) can still be found on some websites for downloading. aolpress is rather strict about enforcing legal html which does not comply to the html 3.2 standard and specifications.  when saving edited pages which were created outside of aolpress code that did not comply may have been changed to do so. today, the html code used is very outdated and may not display more recent websites. it does not support [[portable network graphics|png]], and this limits its support on many websites where the new png format has been adopted.\n\nit actively pushed aol\'s [[primehost]] service.\n\n==history==\nin february 1994 navipress released a [[web browser]] with an integrated [[html editor]], which was very similar to the first web browser [[worldwideweb]],<ref>{{cite web|last=berners-lee|first=tim|title=the world wide web: past, present and future|url=http://www.w3.org/people/berners-lee/1996/ppf.htm|publisher=[[world wide web consortium]]|accessdate=25 august 2010|authorlink=tim berners-lee|date=august 1996}}</ref> for [[mac os]] and [[microsoft windows]].<ref>{{cite web|last=stewart|first=bill|title=web browser history|url=http://www.livinginternet.com/w/wi_browse.htm|accessdate=18 august 2010}}</ref>\n\nin 1995, the package was retitled as \"gnnpress\", and made available for downloading on aol\'s [[global network navigator]] website.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://gnn.1campusa.com/html/downloads.htm |title=gnn downloads |work=gnn.1campusa.com |year=2007 |accessdate=june 5, 2013}}</ref>\n\n==system requirements==\naolpress 2.0 requires 8 me

<page> <title>apexc</title><text>{{refimprove|date=march 2010}}\nthe \'\'\'ape(x)c\'\'\', or  \'\'\'all purpose electronic (x) computer\'\'\'  series was designed by [[andrew donald booth]] at [[birkbeck, university of london|birkbeck college]], [[london]] in the early 1950s. his work on the ape(x)c series was sponsored by the [[british rayon research association]].<ref>the british computer industry: crisis and development by tim kelly, page 41</ref><ref name=\"earlybrit\">early british computers, simon hugh lavington 1980</ref> although the naming conventions are slightly unclear, it seems the first model belonged to the brra.<ref name=\"histcomp\">history of computing:learning from the past, arthur tatnall springer, 2010</ref> according to booth, the x stood for x-company.<ref>book 495 in origins of cyberspace: a library on the history of computing, diana h. hook, jeremy m. norman, michael r. williams. norman publishing, 2002</ref> \n\none of the series was also known as the ape(x)c or \'\'\'all purpose electronic x-ray computer\'\'\' and was sited at birkbeck.\n\nfrom 1943 on, booth started working on the determination of [[crystal]] structures using [[x-ray diffraction]] data.  the computations involved were extremely tedious and there was ample incentive for automating the process and he developed an analogue computer to compute the reciprocal spacings of the diffraction pattern.<ref>\n{{cite book|author=andrew brown|title=j.d. bernal, the sage of science|page=276|publisher=oxford u.p.|year=2005}}\n</ref> in 1947, along with his collaborator and future spouse [[kathleen booth|kathleen britten]], he spent a few months with [[von neumann]]\'s team, which was the leading edge in computer research at the time. booth designed an electromechanical computer, the [[automatic relay computer|arc]], in the late 1940s. later on, they built an experimental electronic computer named sec ([[simple electronic computer]]), and finally the ape(x)c (all-purpose electronic compute

<page> <title>apset</title><text>\'\'\'andhra pradesh state eligibility test\'\'\' or \'\'\'apset\'\'\' is an eligibility test for applying for assistant professor position in universities in [[andhra pradesh]]. the test is conducted based on subjects and only those who have post graduation in that particular filed are eligible.<ref>http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/hyderabad/apset-notification-on-july-1-exam-on-sept-22/article4860790.ece?ref=slidernews</ref>\n\nthe 2013 eligibility test is conducted by osmania university when it last conducted in 1999.\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==external links==\n* [http://www.apset.org/ official site]\n\n[[category:education in andhra pradesh]]\n[[category:standardized tests in india]]</text> </page>	
<page> <title>apt_process</title><text>{{distinguish|advanced packaging tool}}\n\nthe \'\'\'apt process\'\'\' is a photographic transfer system that can photographically transfer lines or solid blocks of colors onto acetate sheets (cels). a very similar process is used in silk screen printing. the process relies on uv-sensitive inks that cure when exposed to light and stick to the plastic sheet, while the ink in the non-exposed areas are chemically removed from the sheet. its main advantage is that coloring - normally done via back painting after xerox scanning - can be controlled better and multiple versions made quickly. to put it simply: the drawings are photographed and the negatives then processed onto the cels instead of the typical photography. it also meant that a line on an animated character could be in color instead of just black (although xerography at this point could be done in colors too); this is known as self-colored lines.\n\nthis process was used on [[disney]]\'s animated features such as \'\'[[the black cauldron (film)|the black cauldron]]\'\', \'\'[[the great mouse detective]]\'\', \'\'[[oliver & company]]\'\' and \'\'[[little mermaid (movie)|the little mermaid]]\'\'.\n\n==see also==\n*[[the black cauldron (film)|the black cauldron]]\n*[[timeline of cgi in film and television]]\n*[[traditional animation]]\n\n==external links==\n*[http://experts.about.com/q/animation-3158/apt-process-1.htm \'\'the apt process\'\' on the \'\'allexperts\'\' forum]\n\n[[category:visual effects]]\n[[category:animation techniques]]\n\n\n{{animation-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>ap_music_theory</title><text>{{advanced placement}}\n\'\'\'advanced placement [[music theory|music theory]]\'\'\' (or \'\'\'ap music theory\'\'\', \'\'\'ap jams\'\'\', \'\'\'ap music\'\'\', or even \'\'\'music ap\'\'\') is a course and examination offered in the [[united states]] by the [[college board]] as part of the [[advanced placement program]] to [[high school]] students who wish to earn credit for a college level [[music theory]] course.\n\n==the course==\nsome of the material covered in the course involves low [[sight reading]], in-depth terminology, [[musical phrasing]] and composition, [[music history]], [[chord structure]] and [[cadence (music)|cadence]]s, and other areas of music theory. this course is recommended for students with particularly strong abilities in music and college music majors.<ref>[http://www.collegeboard.com/student/testing/ap/sub_music.html ap: music theory<!-- bot generated title -->]</ref>\n\n==the exam==\nthe exam itself is divided into two broad sections: section i, the multiple-choice section, and section ii, the free-response section. in turn, each section is divided into parts.\n\n===section i - multiple choice===\nsection i of the exam consists of four-choice multiple choice questions; the total amount varies each year. the first half of the section is listening-based; the proctor will begin playing a provided cd, and the exam will begin. each question or group of questions is based on a musical selection or an auditory stimulus. the selection or stimulus will be played, and the student must answer as many of the questions as possible. each musical selection or auditory stimulus is usually played two or three times for each question or group of questions, though the exact number differs from question to question.\n\n===section ii - free response===\nsection ii of the exam consists of three different parts, all of which are student-produced responses. one part of the section is listening-based, one part is part-w

<page> <title>art_innsbruck</title><text>\'\'\'art innsbruck\'\'\' is an international [[fair]] for [[contemporary art]] held annually in [[innsbruck]]. the 4&nbsp;km² fair features about 70 exhibitors from 8 - 10 nations presenting [[fine art]] of the [[the 20th century|20th]] and 21st centuries. it is organized by the development association of fine arts and is the second largest art fair in austria, second only to art vienna.\n\nart innsbruck was started in 1997 and has taken place since the foundation every year in february. it is held at the fair hall of innsbruck. events include \"art-clubbing\", the \"art-lounge\" and art seminars for beginners and collectors.\n\nat the program: fine arts from the 20th and 21st century - \npaintings, original prints, works on paper, editions, sculptures, photography, new media,\nart as an investment and return items from the period after 1960.\n\n== for art lovers and collectors ==\npaintings, works on paper, original graphics, sculptures, editions, photography, new mediums, multiples, objects and installations -  the art innsbruck presents international fine art of the 20th and 21st century.\n\nmaximum seventy exhibitors are allowed. thereby and through the selected exhibitor jury the art innsbruck obtains her small and very fine,\nexclusive ambience. the art innsbruck is conceived according to international valid criteria for art fairs.  \n\nunder the motto \"for art lovers and collectors\" are [[gallery owner]]s, [[artists]], and experts meeting. the fair is a mediator between creators of art, art providers and art friends, as well as [[art gallery|galleries]] and the [[public]]. the fair has now become indispensable as a meeting point for local and international art scene.\n\n== facts ==\n* 70 exhibitors from 10 nations (2009)\n* over 4000 visitors at the open evening (2009)\n* more than 17000 visitors on all fair days (2013)\n* over 100 reports in print, radio and television\n* tasteful ambience\n* interesting accompany

<page> <title>asa_hall_of_fame_stadium</title><text>{{infobox stadium\n| image = [[file:hall of fame park.jpg|250px|alt=view towards home plate along the first base side]]\n| name = asa hall of fame stadium\n| fullname = don e. porter hall of fame stadium\n| coordinates = {{coord|35.524796|-97.463719|type:landmark_region:us-ok|display=inline,title}}\n| location = [[oklahoma city, oklahoma]] [[usa]]\n| capacity = 7,300\n| operator = [[amateur softball association]]\n| opened = 1987\n| renovated = 2003<ref name=\"asa_complex\">{{cite web|url=http://www.asasoftball.com/complex/renovations.asp|title=asa hall of fame complex renovation|accessdate=2009-08-30}}</ref>\n}}\n\n\'\'\'asa hall of fame stadium\'\'\' is a 7,300-seat [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[oklahoma city, oklahoma]] [[united states]].  it is located next to and operated by the [[amateur softball association]].\n\nit opened in 1987 and is widely regarded as the finest [[softball]] facility in the nation and has played host to the best softball competition in the world, including usa teams that represent the nation in international competitions.\n\nthrough 2010, it hosted two major college tournaments: the [[big 12 conference]] championship and the [[women\'s college world series]], as well as the [[world cup of softball]], one of the premiere international softball events. the big 12 conference decided to discontinue their tournament after 2010, however the women\'s college world series is still held there.\n\nin 2007, it was ranked the number eight sporting venue in the state of oklahoma.\n\n<gallery>\nimage:asafield.jpg|asa hall of fame stadium\nimage:asascoreboard.jpg|asa hall of fame stadium\n</gallery>\n\n== see also ==\n\n* the [[oklahoma state firefighters museum]] is across the street\n* [[remington park]] is next to the stadium to the west\n* [[national softball hall of fame and museum]]\n\n== references <page> <title>asa_tel_aviv_university</title><text>{{for|the handball team|asa tel aviv}}\n{{football club infobox |\n  clubname = asa tel aviv |\n  image    = |\n  fullname = asa tel aviv university|\n  nickname =  |\n  founded  = |\n  ground   =  |\n  capacity =  |\n  chairman =  |\n  manager  =  |\n  league   = [[ligat nashim rishona]] |\n  season   =  |\n  position = |\n  pattern_la1=|pattern_b2=_unknown|pattern_ra2=|\n  leftarm1=ffffff|body2=ffffff|rightarm2=ffffff|shorts2=ffffff|socks2=ffffff|\n  pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=_unknown|pattern_ra2=|\n  leftarm2=ffffff|body2=ffffff|rightarm2=ffffff|shorts2=ffffff|socks2=ffffff|\n  website =  |\n}}\n\'\'\'asa tel aviv university\'\'\' is university sports club of the [[tel aviv university]] in [[israel]]. it is famous for its [[women\'s association football|women\'s football]] team that won 4 national league-championships and participated in the [[uefa women\'s champions league]].\n\nthe team played in the [[2010-11 uefa women\'s champions league]] qualifying round and finished third in a group of four. in 2011 they won their fourth championship title and again qualified for the [[2011-12 uefa women\'s champions league]] qualifying round. the same year the won the cup.<ref>{{cite web|title=2011 cup results|url=http://women.soccerway.com/national/israel/state-cup-/2010-2011/final-stages/|publisher=women.soccerway-com|accessdate=18 june 2011}}</ref> \n\n==titles==\n* 6 [[ligat nashim rishona|israeli women\'s championships]]: 1998-99, 1999–2000, 2009–10, 2010–11, 2011–12, 2012–13\n* 2 [[israeli women\'s cup]] winners: 2010–11, 2011–12\n\n==european record==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! competition\n! round\n! country\n! club\n! result\n|-\n|rowspan=3|[[2010–11 uefa women\'s champions league]]\n|rowspan=3|qualifying round || {{flagicon|swe}} || [[umeå ik]] ||0–3\n|-\n| {{flagicon|bih}} || [[sfk 2000]] || 3–1\n|-\n| {{flagicon|cyp}} || [[apollon limassol]] || 0–3\n|-\n|rowspan=4|[[2011–12 uefa women\'
<page> <title>asb_classic</title><text>{{use british english|date=july 2011}}\n{{use dmy dates|date=july 2011}}\n{{infobox wta tennis tournament\n| name                  = asb classic\n| current               = 2013 asb classic\n| logo                  = asbclassic logo.png\n| logo_size             = 200px\n| city                  = [[auckland]]\n| country               = {{nzl}}\n| venue                 = [[asb tennis centre]]\n| tier                  = [[wta international tournaments|international]]\n| surface               = [[plexicushion]]\n| draw                  = 32m/32q/16d\n| prize_money           = us$220,000\n| web_site              = [http://www.asbclassic.co.nz/ asbclassic.co.nz]\n| notes                 = \n}}\nthe \'\'\'asb classic\'\'\' is a women\'s tennis tournament held in [[auckland]], new zealand. held since 1986, this [[women\'s tennis association|wta tour]] event is an [[wta international tournaments|international series tournament]] and is played on outdoor hardcourts. the tournament takes place during the first week of the year, one week before another [[asb tennis centre]] event, men\'s [[heineken open (tennis)|heineken open]].\n\nat the 2008 tournament, the courts were changed to a [[plexicushion|blue plexicushion]] surface, replacing the green [[rebound ace]]. this was consistent with the surface change that was also implemented at the australian open.  \n\non 15 october 2012, it was announced that world no. 4 and reigning [[the championships, wimbledon|wimbledon]] runner-up [[agnieszka radwańska]] from poland will be competing in the tournament\'s 2013 edition as the top seed.<ref>[http://i.stuff.co.nz/sport/tennis/7824373/radwanska-will-be-asb-classics-top-talent \'radwanska will be asb classic\'s top talent\'] \'\'[[stuff.co.nz]]\'\' (retrieved october 16, 2012)</ref>\n\n[[image:flickr - chascow - agnieszka radwańska.jpg|thumb|200px|[[agnieszka radwańska]] is the current champion, having defeated [[yanina wickmayer]] in the 2013 fi
<page> <title>ascaad</title><text>{{notability|company|date=july 2009}}\n\nthe \'\'\'arab society for computer-aided architectural design\'\'\' (\'\'\'ascaad\'\'\') is a society active in the area of [[computer-aided architectural design]] ([[caad]]).<ref>[http://portal.unesco.org/culture/en/ev.php-url_id=28155&url_do=do_topic&url_section=201.html digi-arts knowledge portal], [[unesco]].</ref>\n\n== history and mission of ascaad ==\nthe founding meeting of ascaad took place on the 16th of may, 2001 in [[jordan university of science and technology]].\n\nascaad is a society of those who teach and conduct research in computer-aided architectural design in schools of architecture in the [[arab world]]. ascaad aims to facilitate communication and information exchange regarding the use of computers and information technology in architecture, planning and building science.\n\n== membership ==\nmembership of ascaad is available to architects, designers, educators and researchers. membership is not restricted to any geographical region, however, the activities of ascaad are mainly carried out in the [[arab world]] (west asia, and north africa). we accept members from all over the world. anyone can register online via [http://ascaad.org/index.html ascaad website].\n\n== annual conference ==\nascaad organises an annual conference in one of the universities or institutions in the arab region [http://ascaad.org/site/english/conferences.html]. papers are accepted in the conference after a blind review process. all accepted papers are published in the proceedings of the conference, and included in [http://cumincad.scix.net/ cumincad].public cumincad records are available via an open archives initiative protocol for metadata harvesting (oai-pmh) feed and records are available via multiple  bibliographic archives and citation indexes onine.<ref>{{cite web|title=architexturez cumincad oai-pmh mirror|url=http://cumincad.architexturez.net/col/ascaad|publisher=architexturez|accessdate=2
<page> <title>asean_wildlife_enforcement_network</title><text>{{advert|date=march 2013}}\n{{coi|date=august 2010}}\nthe \'\'\'asean wildlife enforcement network\'\'\' (asean-wen) was officially launched on 1 december 2005 as a regional inter-agency and inter-governmental initiative to counter the illegal cross-border trade in endangered flora and fauna. the network is a direct and proactive response against poaching and wildlife trafficking that has led to alarming levels of biodiversity loss in southeast asia. it helps countries share information on and tackle cross-border wildlife crime and facilitates the exchange of regional best practices in combating those crimes. as the world’s largest wildlife law enforcement network, it comprises law enforcement agencies of the 10 asean countries ([[brunei]], [[cambodia]], [[indonesia]], [[laos]], [[malaysia]], [[myanmar]], the [[philippines]], [[singapore]], [[vietnam]] and [[thailand]]) forming a \'\'\'regional intergovernmental\'\'\' law-enforcement network.\n{{infobox non-profit\n| name              = asean wildlife enforcement network (asean-wen)\n| type              = intergovernmental organization\n| founded_date      = 1 december 2005\n| location          = bangkok, thailand\nmembers are all ten asean nations (brunei darussalam, cambodia, indonesia, lao pdr, malaysia, myanmar, philippines, singapore, thailand, viet nam)\n| area_served       = southeast asia\n| products          = id sheets on protected flora & fauna, quarterly newsletter, quarterly action updates, law enforcement training manuals & packages\n| mission           = illegal [[wildlife trade]] suppression, [[conservation (ethic)|preservation]] of [[biodiversity]]\n| homepage          = {{url|www.asean-wen.org}}\n}}\n\n== overview ==\n\nthe establishment of asean-wen was a response by the governments of southeast asia to the serious threat of illegal wildlife trade.  asean-wen aims to address illegal exploitation and trade in [[cites]]-listed [[endange
