inline,title\n  | locmapin = new york\n  | built = 1859\n  | architect = abner concklin\n  | architecture = \n  | added = august 6, 1987\n  | area = {{convert|1|acre}}\n  | governing_body = private\n  | refnum = 87001358<ref name=\"nris\">{{nrisref|2009a}}</ref>\n}}\n\'\'\'abner concklin house\'\'\', also known as \'\'\'old yellow house\'\'\', is a historic home located at [[palisades, new york|palisades]] in [[rockland county, new york]].  it was built around 1859 and is a small two story frame residence, three bays wide, with later rear wings and alterations.  it features a hipped roof with a [[monitor (architecture)|monitor]]-like cap at the apex.  also on the property are a garage and shed.<ref name=\"nrhpinv_ny\">{{cite web|url=http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?groupview=7871|title=national register of historic places registration: abner concklin house|date= june 1987|accessdate=2010-05-28 |author=neil larson|publisher=[[new york state office of parks, recreation and historic preservation]]}}  \'\'see also:\'\' {{cite web|url=http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?groupview=7904|title=accompanying eight photos}}</ref>\n\nit was listed on the [[national register of historic places]] in 1987.<ref name=\"nris\"/>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{national register of historic places in new york}}\n\n{{defaultsort:concklin, abner, house}}\n[[category:houses on the national register of historic places in new york]]\n[[category:houses completed in 1859]]\n[[category:houses in rockland county, new york]]\n\n\n{{rocklandny-nrhp-stub}}</text> </page
<page> <title>abner_dieujuste</title><text>{{multiple issues|\n{{orphan|date=august 2013}}\n{{citation style|date=june 2013}}\n}}\n\n{{infobox writer\n| name         = \'\'\'abner dieujuste\'\'\'\n| birth_name   = abner de la bastide dieujuste\n| birth_date   = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1981|8|22}}\n| birth_place  = [[\'\'\'jean rabel, haiti\'\'\'|jean rabel]], [[nord-ouest department]], haiti\n| occupation   = poet, community leader, actor, playwright, film director, author, professor\n| ethnicity    = [[haitian people|haitian]]\n| period       =\n| genre        = autobiography\n| language     = english, french, haitian creole, russian\n| period       = 1981–present\n| subject      =\n| movement     = education\n| influences   =  [[maya angelou]], [[william shakespeare]], [[edgar allan poe]], [[douglas johnson (historian)|douglas johnson]], [[james weldon johnson]], [[frances harper]], [[anne spencer]], [[james baldwin]]\n| influenced   =\n| notableworks = \'\'[[an act of will]]\'\'<br>\'\'[[elasticity of love]]\'\'\n| website      = http://www.abnerdieujuste.net\n}}\n\n== early life ==\nabner dieujuste is a haitian-american author and poet, born on the wondrous island of haiti inheriting in his blood a rich culture, full of life and breathtaking ambiance. this picturesque island, with its plush green mountains and colorful array of flowers, was a backdrop in stimulating his mind and sparking inside of him an ingenious desire to become a poet and historian. dieujuste\'s interest in writing sparked at the early age.\nall my life i\'ve felt this uncontrollable urge to write. not necessarily to \"be a writer\" but just to write to put things into words on paper.i decided to make this a career, every morning i sit down, do some stream-of-consciousness writing in an old notebook, and try to piece together a short personal essay.\nshe has published three books: \'\'un malleable amour\'\',<ref>http://www.amazon.com/mall%c3%a9able-amour-french-abner-dieujuste/dp/145158
<page> <title>abner_wilcox</title><text>{{infobox person\n|name        = abner wilcox\n|image       = abner wilcox.jpg\n|image_size  = |caption     = \n|birth_date  = {{birth date|1808|4|19}}\n|birth_place = [[harwinton, connecticut]]\n|death_date  = {{death date and age|1869|8|20|1808|4|19}}\n|death_place = [[colebrook, connecticut]]\n|parents     =\n|occupation  = educator\n|nationality =\n}}\n\n\'\'\'abner wilcox\'\'\' (april 19, 1808 &ndash; august 20, 1869) was a missionary teacher from [[new england]] to the [[kingdom of hawaii]].\n\n==life==\nabner wilcox was born april 19, 1808 in [[harwinton, connecticut]]. his father was aaron wilcox (1770–1850) and mother was lois phelps. he was fourth of nine children.<ref>{{cite web |title= descendants of ralph hutchinson: fifth generation (continued) |url= http://www.cgall.com/web/ralph/pafg13.htm#2371 |accessdate= september 22, 2010 }}</ref>\non november 23, 1836 he married lucy eliza hart who was born november 17, 1814 in [[cairo (town), new york|cairo, new york]]. they were assigned to be in the eighth company of [[list of missionaries to hawaii|missionaries to hawaii]] for the [[american board of commissioners for foreign missions]]. the sailed from [[boston]] on december 14, 1836 on the [[barque|bark]] \'\'mary frasier\'\' and arrived in [[honolulu]] on april 9, 1837.\nalso on this voyage were missionaries [[amos starr cooke]] and [[samuel northrop castle]], founders of [[castle & cooke]].\nthe wilcoxes taught at the [[haili church|hilo mission]] boarding school founded by [[david belden lyman]] and his wife on the [[hawaii (island)|island of hawai{{okina}}i]].<ref>{{cite book |title=portraits of american protestant missionaries to hawaii |author= hawaiian mission children\'s society |url= http://www.archive.org/details/portraitsofameri00hawarich |year=1901 |location=honolulu |publisher=hawaiian gazette company |page=70}}</ref> they had four sons born while at hilo. \n[[image:waioli-missionhall-full.jpg|thumb| r
<page> <title>aboaso</title><text>{{refimprove|date=june 2012}}\n\n{{infobox settlement\n|official_name          = aboaso\n|coordinates_region     = gh\n|subdivision_type       = country\n|subdivision_name       = [[image:flag of ghana.svg|25px]] [[ghana]]\n|subdivision_type1      = [[regions of ghana|region]]\n|subdivision_name1      = [[ashanti region]]\n|population_blank1_title        =ethnicities\n|population_blank1              =\n|population_blank2_title        =religions\n|population_blank2              =\n}}\n\n\'\'\'aboaso\'\'\' is a town in the [[ashanti region]] of [[ghana]]. the town is known for the gyeama penson secondary technical school.<ref name=scho>{{cite web|title=educational institutions|url=http://www.centralregion.gov.gh/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=34&itemid=57|publisher=www.centralregion.gov.gh|accessdate=12 august 2011}}</ref><ref name=morescho>{{cite web|title=references » schools/colleges|url=http://www.modernghana.com/ghanahome/regions/schools.asp?menu_id=6&sub_menu_id=310&gender=&s=a|publisher=www.modernghana.com|accessdate=12 august 2011}}</ref>  the school is a [[second cycle]] institution.<ref name=allschool>{{cite web|title=list of secondary schools in ghana|url=http://www.ghanaschoolsnet.com/page/list-of-senior-secondary|publisher=www.ghanaschoolsnet.com/|accessdate=12 august 2011}}</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{coord missing|ghana}}\n\n[[category:populated places in the ashanti region]]\n\n\n{{ghana-geo-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>abobra</title><text>{{taxobox\n|regnum = [[plant]]ae\n|unranked_divisio = [[angiosperms]]\n|unranked_classis = [[eudicots]]\n|unranked_ordo = [[rosids]]\n|ordo = [[cucurbitales]]\n|familia = [[cucurbitaceae]]\n|genus = \'\'\'\'\'abobra\'\'\'\'\'\n|genus_authority = [[charles victor naudin|naudin.]]\n|species = \'\'\'\'\'a. tenuifolia\'\'\'\'\'\n|binomial = \'\'abobra tenuifolia\'\'\n|binomial_authority = ([[john gillies|gillies]]) [[cogn.]]\n|}}\n\'\'\'\'\'abobra\'\'\'\'\' is a monotypic genus of the [[cucurbitaceae|gourd family]] containing the one species \'\'\'\'\'abobra tenuifolia\'\'\'\'\' ([[syn.]] \'\'abobra viridiflora\'\' <small>[[charles victor naudin|naudin.]]</small>, \'\'bryonia tenuifolia\'\' <small>[[william jackson hooker|hook.]] & [[george arnott walker arnott|arn.]]</small>). it is native to [[south america]], and sometimes cultivated as [[ornamental plant]]s and also for its edible fruits. common names include \'\'\'cranberry gourd\'\'\'.\n\n==references==\n* {{cite book | author=[[l. h. bailey|bailey, l. h.]] | title=manual of gardening (second edition).  | url=http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/9550 | year=2005 | publisher=[[project gutenberg|project gutenberg literary archive foundation]]}}\n\n==external links==\n*[http://www.pfaf.org/database/plants.php?abobra+tenuifolia plants for a future: \'\'abobra tenuifolia\'\']\n\n[[category:cucurbitaceae]]\n[[category:flora of brazil]]\n[[category:monotypic plant genera]]\n\n{{cucurbitales-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>aboriginal_centre_for_the_performing_arts</title><text>[[file:acpa logo black.jpg|thumb|logo]]\nthe \'\'\'aboriginal centre for the performing arts\'\'\' (acpa) is an elite national australian institution for the culturally sensitive<ref>[http://www.myfuture.edu.au/the%20facts/education%20and%20training/education%20and%20training%20providers/details.aspx?providerid=13537 my future] careers.</ref> training of [[aboriginal australians]] and [[torres strait islanders]].\n\nacpa relocated to new premises at [[kangaroo point, queensland|kangaroo point]] in brisbane in october 2012 where greatly improved facilities include seven purpose built studios for music, acting and dance.<ref>{{cite web\n| title=dance space improving their leaps and bounds\n| work=[[the australian]]\n| url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/arts/dance-space-improving-their-leaps-and-bounds/story-e6frg8n6-1226490149703\n| date=8 november 2012\n| accessdate=20 april 2013}}</ref>\n\n[[file:acpa production 2012.jpg|thumbnail|right|a 2012 acpa production]]\nthe organisation teaches indigenous and non-indigenous acting, music and dance. it has won several national awards<ref>{{cite web\n| title =australian dance award winners\n| url =http://www.danceinforma.com/magazine/tag/aboriginal-centre-for-the-performing-arts-acpa/\n| date=30 july 2011\n| accessdate=20 april 2013}}</ref> and is nationally accredited as a [[registered training organisation]]. acpa receives funding from the [[government of queensland|queensland]] and [[government of australia|federal]] governments,<ref>{{cite web\n| title=new era for aboriginal centre for the performing arts\n| url =http://statements.qld.gov.au/statement/2012/10/5/new-era-for-aboriginal-centre-for-the-performing-arts\n| publisher=queensland government\n| date=5 november 2012\n| accessdate=20 april 2013}}</ref> as well as from the private sector.<ref>{{cite web\n| title =training path\n| url =http://acpa.net.au/about/training-path\n| accessdate=20 april 201
<page> <title>aboriginal_medical_services_alliance_northern_territory</title><text>the \'\'\'aboriginal medical services alliance northern territory\'\'\' (amsant) is the peak body for aboriginal community controlled primary health services in the [[northern territory]] of australia.  it has offices in [[alice springs]] and [[darwin, northern territory|darwin]] but works across the entire northern territory.  amsant was formally established in october 1994 at a meeting of aboriginal health services which was held in central australia.\n\nin 1995 amsant successfully led the move take [[australian government|australian government]] funding of aboriginal health from the [[atsic|aboriginal and torres strait islander commission (atsic)]] to direct funding through the [[office of aboriginal and torres strait islander health|office for aboriginal and torres strait islander health (oatsih)]], a division of the [[department of health and ageing|department of health and ageing (doha)]].  amsant played a leading role in ensuring significantly increased funding to aboriginal comprehensive primary health care as a consequence of the [[northern territory national emergency response|northern territory emergency response (the \"intervention\")]].\n\nit is an independent, not for profit organisation and receives funding from the australian government, the [[government of the northern territory|northern territory government]] and from a range of charities and non government organisations, including the [[fred hollows foundation#indigenous australia|fred hollows foundation]]. amsant is a partner in the northern territory aboriginal health forum, which determines aboriginal health policy in the northern territory in conjunction with the australian and northern territory governments. amsant is an affiliate of the national aboriginal community controlled health organisation (naccho).\n\n==overview==\namsant supports aboriginal health services by advocating for the right of local aborigin
<page> <title>abortion_in_albania</title><text>{{pp-semi-vandalism|small=yes|expiry=29 november 2014}}\n\'\'\'abortion in albania\'\'\' was fully legalized on december 7, 1995.<ref name=\"shqip\">[http://www.shkoder.net/fjala/2003/aborti.htm aborti - vrasje e fëmijës së palindur (in albanian)] nr. 8045, data 07. 12. 1995, që është mbështetje e nenit të ligjit nr. 7491, të vitit 1991 \"për dispozitat kryesore kushtetuese\" me propozimin e këshillit të ministrive, miratuar në kuvendin popullor të shqipërisë.</ref> abortion can be performed on demand until the twelfth week of pregnancy.<ref name=\"un\">[http://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/abortion/doc/albani1.doc albania - abortion policy - united nations]</ref> women must undergo counseling for a week prior to the procedure, and hospitals which perform abortions are not allowed to release information to the public regarding which women they have treated.<ref name=\"un\" />\n\nduring the government of [[enver hoxha]], albania had a [[natalist]] policy,<ref name=\"un\" /> leading women to have abortions performed illegally or inducing them on their own. eventually the country had the second-highest maternal mortality rate in all of europe, and it was estimated that 50% of all pregnancies ended in an abortion.<ref name=\"un\" /> women found guilty of aborting their pregnancies would either be shamed socially by the communist party or sent to work in a [[:wikt:reeducation|reeducation]] program.<ref name=\"un\" />\n\nin 1989 abortion was legalized in the case of rape and incest or if the patient was under the age of 16.<ref name=\"un\" /> in 1991 abortion-by-application was introduced, allowing women to terminate their pregnancies for a variety of reasons if a board of medical practitioners agreed it was the best decision.<ref name=\"un\" /> the 1995 law nullifies all previous laws.<ref name=\"shqip\" />\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{abortion in europe}}\n{{abortion}}\n\n{{defaultsort:aborti
<page> <title>abortion_in_colombia</title><text>{{pp-semi-vandalism|small=yes|expiry=29 november 2014}}\n\'\'\'abortion in colombia\'\'\' is illegal except in case of the threat to life or health of the woman, if the pregnancy is the result of rape, or when the fetus is expected to die after birth because of severe fetal abnormalities. it was completely illegal until 2006, when (as a result of the [[marta gonzalez]] case) legislation was passed making it legal in the above circumstances.<ref>\n{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/5284604.stm |title=first legal abortion in colombia |work=bbc news\n|location=bogota |last=mcdermott  |first=jeremy |date=25 august 2006 |accessdate=2012-05-27\n}}</ref>\n\nthe punishment for a woman who has an illegal abortion is up to three years in prison and the punishment for a doctor or other person who performs the procedure illegally (even if medically licensed to do so) is also up to three years.<ref>\n{{cite web |url=http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/50664.php |title=first legal abortion performed in colombia following authorization from country\'s high court |work=medical news today |date=30 august 2006 |accessdate=2012-05-27}}</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==see also==\n*[[abortion]]\n*[[:category:abortion by country|abortion by country]]\n*[[abortion law]]\n\n\n{{south america topic|abortion in}}\n{{abortion}}\n[[category:abortion in colombia| ]]</text> </page>	
<page> <title>abortion_in_costa_rica</title><text>{{pp-semi-vandalism|small=yes|expiry=29 november 2014}}\n\'\'\'abortion in [[costa rica]]\'\'\' is severely restricted.  currently, [[abortion]]s are allowed only in order to preserve the life or physical health of the woman.  abortions are illegal in cases of rape or incest, when the foetus suffers from medical problems or birth defects, for social reasons, and for economic reasons.  abortions are not available on demand, with no reason given. currently, it is unclear whether or not abortions are legal to preserve the mental health of the woman.<ref>http://www.pregnantpause.org/lex/world02.htm</ref>\n\n==statistics==\n\ncurrently, abortions in costa rica are most commonly practiced in secret, either in private clinics or by other means where statistics of maternal deaths are difficult to obtain.  in 2007, data revealed that the number of illegal abortions is on the rise, up to 22.3 for every 1,000 from 10.6 for every 1,000 women.  this comes out to about 27,000 illegal abortions being performed in costa rica annually.<ref>http://www.lifenews.com/2008/09/23/int-930/</ref>\n\n==legal issues==\n\ninduced abortion is classified as a crime in the penal code of 1970, included in the crimes against life. doctors who suspect that a woman has had an abortion are obligated to report them to the organization of judicial investigation (\'\'organizacion de investigacion judicial\'\'). punishment may vary depending on if the woman consented or not to the procedure, and depending of if the fetus had reached six months\' gestation at the time.  in 2003, there were no women or doctors in prison for having or performing an abortion, however there was one lay woman, an untrained midwife, accused of carrying out abortions who served a three-year sentence.  although the [[united nations human rights council]] recommended in 1999 that costa rica should introduce more exceptions to the prohibition of abortions, the actual costa rican legi
<page> <title>abortion_in_the_republic_of_ireland</title><text>{{engvarb|date=october 2013}}\n{{use dmy dates|date=october 2013}}\n{{refimprove|date=december 2012}}\n\'\'\'abortion in ireland\'\'\' is illegal unless it occurs as the result of a medical intervention performed to save the life of the mother.<ref>{{cite book |first1=peter |last1=charleton |first2=paul anthony |last2=mcdermott |first3=marguerite |last3=bolger |title=criminal law |year=1999 |publisher=butterworths |location=dublin |isbn=1854758454 |page=518}}</ref> the availability of abortion services can be even more restricted in the absence of a readily available method of determining the circumstances in which an abortion might be lawfully obtained.<ref>{{cite book |last=herring |first=jonathan |title=medical law and ethics |year=2012 |publisher=oxford university press |location=oxford |isbn=9780199646401 |edition=4th ed. |page=308}}</ref>\n\nabortion is a controversial issue in irish politics and five national referendums have been held on the topic in the last 30 years.\n\nin 2013, ireland passed a new law allowing abortion under certain circumstances. on 30 july 2013, president [[michael d. higgins]] signed off on the [[protection of life during pregnancy act 2013]] without referring it to the supreme court after meeting his advisers, the council of state. the new law provides for a woman\'s right to an abortion if her life is at risk, including from suicide.<ref name=\":0\">http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/abortion-bill-signed-into-irish-law-by-president-higgins-602117.html</ref>\n\n==history==\n{{life in the republic of ireland}}\nat independence from the uk in 1922, the [[offences against the person act 1861]] remained in force, maintaining all abortions to be illegal and subject to punishment. one of ireland\'s best-known abortionists, [[mamie cadden]], was famously sentenced to death by hanging in 1957 – this was later commuted to life imprisonment – when one of her pati

<page> <title>about_box</title><text>{{unreferenced|date=august 2009}}\n[[image:about kde.png|right|thumb|the about box for [[kde]] 3.5.1]]\nan \'\'\'about box\'\'\' or \'\'\'about dialog\'\'\' is a [[dialog box]] that displays the [[credit (creative arts)|credit]]s and revision information of a [[computer software]]. many times the [[splash screen]] (if one exists) includes the same information that the about box.\n\ngenerally, most programs\' about boxes include information about product name and installed [[software versioning|version]], [[software company|company]] name, and [[copyright]] information. however there are programs that include much more information in their about box, like system information, [[software license]] ownership information or the license agreement text, and the names of contributors to the project. the function for updating the software can be included in the about dialog, too.\n\nthe concept of the about box originated with the first [[mac os|macintosh classic operating system]], where \'\'about [program name]\'\' was typically the first item in the [[apple menu]].  in [[mac os x]], about boxes are typically listed as the first item in the menu with the program\'s name (next to the apple menu). in most [[microsoft windows]] [[computer program|program]]s (prior to major user interface changes in windows 7), about boxes can be accessed from the \'\'help\'\' menu, from a menu item of \'\'about ...\'\'. for example, [[microsoft]] [[internet explorer]]\'s about box could be opened by opening the \'\'help\'\' menu, then selecting \'\'about internet explorer\'\' menu item.\n\nabout boxes are usually not standardized and are sometimes creative or entertaining in their design. they might contain some small [[animation]] or they may be a passage to an [[easter egg (media)|easter egg]]. in some occasions, mostly in [[web browser]]s, the about dialog can be shown as a document of its own in the application.\n\nthe [[mac os x]] and the [[morphos]] 
<page> <title>abr</title><text>{{for|the three letter acronym|abr (disambiguation){{!}}abr}}\n{{infobox settlement\n|official_name =abr\n|native_name =ابر\n|settlement_type        = village\n|pushpin_map            =iran\n|mapsize                =150px\n|coordinates_region     = ir\n|subdivision_type       = [[list of countries|country]]\n|subdivision_name = {{flag|iran}}\n|subdivision_type1 =[[provinces of iran|province]]\n|subdivision_name1 =[[semnan province|semnan]]\n|subdivision_type2 =[[counties of iran|county]]\n|subdivision_name2 = [[shahrud county|shahrud]]\n|subdivision_type3 =[[bakhsh]]\n|subdivision_name3 =[[bastam district|bastam]]\n|subdivision_type4 =[[rural districts of iran|rural district]]\n|subdivision_name4 =[[kharqan rural district (semnan province)|kharqan]]\n|leader_title           = \n|leader_name            = \n|established_title      =\n|established_date       = \n|area_total_km2           = \n|area_footnotes           = \n|population_as_of         = 2006\n|population_total =1,383\n|population_density_km2   =auto\n|timezone               = [[iran standard time|irst]]\n|utc_offset             = +3:30\n|timezone_dst           = [[iran daylight time|irdt]]\n|utc_offset_dst         = +4:30\n|coordinates_display      = %\n|latd=36|latm=42|lats=28|latns=n\n|longd=55|longm=05|longs=07|longew=e\n|elevation_m            = \n|area_code              = \n|website                = \n|footnotes              =\n}}\n\'\'\'abr\'\'\' ({{lang-fa|ابر}}; also known as \'\'\'abz\'\'\')<ref>{{geonet3|-3051574|abr}}</ref> is a village in [[kharqan rural district (semnan province)|kharqan rural district]], [[bastam district]], [[shahrud county]], [[semnan province]], [[iran]]. at the 2006 census, its population was 1,383, in 355 families.<ref>{{irancensus2006|20}}</ref>  \n\n== references ==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{shahrud county}}\n\n\n[[category:populated places in shahrud county]]\n\n{{shahrud-geo-stub}}</text> </page>

<page> <title>abraham_azulai</title><text>[[file:hesed leavraham.jpg|thumb|170px|right|title page of \'\'chesed le\'avraham\'\' by abraham azulai, published in [[vilna]], 1877]]\n{{kabbalah}}\n\'\'\'abraham ben mordecai azulai\'\'\' (c. 1570–1643) ([[hebrew]]: אברהם בן מרדכי אזולאי) was a [[kabbalistic]] author and commentator born in [[fes]], [[morocco]]. in 1599 he moved to [[israel]] and settled in [[hebron]].<ref>dov zlotnick, \"the commentary of rabbi abraham azulai to the mishnah\", in: \'\'proceedings of the american academy for jewish research\'\', vol. 40, 1972, pp. 147-168</ref>\nin hebron he wrote a commentary on the [[zohar]] under the title \'\'kiryat arba\'\' (city of arba (in hebrew four); [[book of genesis|gen]]. xxiii.2). the plague of 1619 drove him from his new home, and while in [[gaza]], where he found refuge, he wrote his kabalistic work \'\'chesed le-abraham\'\' (mercy to abraham; [[book of micah|micah]] vii.20). it was published after the author\'s death by meshullam zalman ben abraham berak of gorice, in amsterdam, 1685. the work is a treatise with an introduction, אבן השתיה (\'\'the cornerstone\'\'; see talmud [[yoma]] 53b), and is divided into seven \"fountains\" (see [[book of zechariah|zecharia]] iii.9), each fountain being subdivided into a number of \"streams.\" a specimen of the work chesed le-avraham, taken from the fifth fountain, twenty-fourth stream, p.&nbsp;57d, of the amsterdam edition:\n<blockquote>\non the mystery of [[gilgul]] (reincarnation) and its details: know that god will not subject the soul of the wicked to more than three migrations; for it is written, \"lo, all these things doth god work twice, yea thrice, with a man\" ([[book of job|job]] xxxiii. 29). which means, he makes him appear twice and thrice in a human incarnation; but the fourth time he is incarnated as a clean animal. and when a man offers a sacrifice, god will, by miraculous intervention, make him select an animal that is an 
<page> <title>abraham_bristow</title><text>\'\'\'abraham bristow\'\'\' was a british [[seal hunter|sealer]] and [[whaler]]. it is documented that he started his career in 1797. in august 1806 he discovered the [[auckland islands]].<ref>{{cite book|last=mawar|first=granville|title=ahab\'s trade: the saga of south seas whaling|year=1999|publisher=st. martin\'s press|location=new york|isbn=0-312-22809-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://nq.oxfordjournals.org/content/17/10/369.full.pdf+html|format=pdf|first=a. g. e.|last=jones|title=captain abraham bristow and the auckland islands|journal=[[notes and queries]]|year=1970|volume=17|issue=10|pages=369–371|doi= 10.1093/nq/17.10.369|accessdate=2011-12-14}}</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist|2}}\n\n{{defaultsort:bristow}}\n[[category:19th-century explorers]]</text> </page>	
<page> <title>abraham_darby_iv</title><text>\'\'\'abraham darby iv\'\'\' (30 march 1804 – 28 november 1878) was an english ironmaster.\n\nhe was born in dale house, [[coalbrookdale]], [[shropshire]] the son of edmund darby, a member of the darby ironmaking family and lucy (née burlingham) darby. he was a great-nephew of [[abraham darby iii]].\n\nin 1830, he and his brother alfred took over the management of the [[horsehay]] foundry, one of several foundries owned by the family business, and set about re-establishing the coalbrookdale company\'s reputation by investing in new technology there for the manufacture of wrought iron.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.ironbridge.org.uk/our_attractions/darby_houses/history/|title= darby houses|publisher= ironbridge gorge museum|accessdate= 28 february 2011}}</ref>\n\nin 1844, he became a major shareholder in the [[ebbw vale]] ironworks in [[south wales]]. after a series of family disagreements, he resigned his management of the coalbrookdale company in 1849, and, in 1851, bought stoke court near [[stoke poge]]s in [[buckinghamshire]], and moved to live there. he also acquired property at [[treberfydd]] in [[breconshire]], wales. he acted as a justice of the peace in both counties, and, in 1853, was appointed [[high sheriff of buckinghamshire]].<ref>{{londongazette|issue=21409|startpage=329|date=8 february 1853|accessdate=2008-04-16}}</ref>\n\nalthough born into a quaker family, he joined the church of england and paid for the building of holy trinity church in coalbrookdale (1850–54).\n\nhe died at treberfydd and was buried at his church in coalbrookdale. he had married his cousin matilda frances, the daughter of francis darby, in 1853.\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{persondata <!-- metadata: see [[wikipedia:persondata]]. -->\n| name              = darby, abraham, iv\n| alternative names =\n| short description = ironmaster\n| date of birth     = 30 march 1804\n| place of birth    = coalbrookdale, shropshire\n| date
<page> <title>abraham_john_valpy</title><text>\'\'\'abraham john valpy\'\'\' (1787&ndash;1854) was an [[english people|english]] printer and publisher.\n\nhe was the son of the [[reading, berkshire|reading]] schoolmaster [[richard valpy]]. he is remembered in connection with two great undertakings in the department of [[classical literature]]. these were reissues of (1) [[henry estienne|stephanus]]\' \'\'greek thesaurus\'\', for which [[edmund henry barker|e. h. barker]] was chiefly responsible; and (2) the \'\'delphin classics\'\' in 143 volumes with variorum notes, under the editorial superintendence of [[george dyer (poet)|george dyer]]. he also founded the \'\'[[classical journal]]\'\' in 1810.\n\n==references==\n*{{1911}}\n*{{cite dnb|wstitle=valpy, abraham john}}\n\n==external links==\n*{{worldcat id|lccn-nr92-13472}}\n\n{{authority control|viaf=13082604}}\n{{persondata <!-- metadata: see [[wikipedia:persondata]]. -->\n| name              = valpy, abraham john\n| alternative names =\n| short description = english publisher\n| date of birth     = 1787\n| place of birth    =\n| date of death     = 1854\n| place of death    =\n}}\n{{defaultsort:valpy, abraham john}}\n[[category:1787 births]]\n[[category:1854 deaths]]\n[[category:british book publishers (people)]]\n[[category:english printers]]\n[[category:people from reading, berkshire]]</text> </page>	
<page> <title>abraham_kidunaia</title><text>{{infobox saint\n|name=saint abraham the great\n|birth_date=\n|death_date=c. 366\n|feast_day=july 29; october 24; october 29; december 14 \n|venerated_in=[[roman catholic church]], [[eastern orthodox church]], [[coptic orthodox church of alexandria|coptic church]], [[syrian orthodox church]] \n|image=abraham kidunaia (menologion of basil ii).jpg\n|imagesize=300px\n|caption=miniature from the \'\'[[menologion of basil ii]]\'\'\n|birth_place=\n|death_place=[[assos]], in the [[troad]], [[asia minor]] (modern-day [[turkey]])\n|titles=hermit\n|beatified_date=\n|beatified_place=\n|beatified_by=\n|canonized_date=\n|canonized_place=\n|canonized_by=\n|attributes=\n|patronage=\n|major_shrine= \n|suppressed_date=\n|issues=\n|prayer=\n|prayer_attrib=\n}}\n\'\'\'saint abraham the great of kidunja\'\'\' (or \'\'\'kidunaja\'\'\') (died c. 366) was a [[hermit]] and [[priest]] of the [[christian church]].\n\n==biography==\nst. abraham was born to a wealthy family during the third century. after receiving an excellent education, abraham was encouraged to get married. he followed the wishes of his parents, but after the wedding ceremony, he told his bride his desire to remain a virgin and dedicate his life to god. his bride accepted this resolution and abraham retired to a hermitage near edessa, a city near mesopotamia.\n\nten years after he retreated from the world, his parents died and left a great amount of wealth to abraham. as soon as he was aware of this, he asked a friend to distribute the sum to charitable causes. through actions like this and his deep prayer life, abraham became known throughout the region as a holy man and many came to him for guidance.\n\nhis reputation even came to the ears of the bishop, and when edessa became poisoned with sin and idolatry, abraham was ordained and asked to go to the city preaching reform. abraham was greatly distressed by this, but obeyed the wishes of the bishop.\n\nwhen abraham arrived in ed
<page> <title>abraham_lincoln_ii</title><text>{{infobox person\n| name          = abraham lincoln ii\n| image         = abraham lincoln ii.jpg\n| image_size    = 70px\n| birth_date    = august 14, 1873\n| birth_place   =  [[chicago|chicago, illinois]]\n| death_date    = {{death date and age|1890|3|5|1873|8|14}}\n| death_place   = [[london|london, england]]\n| death_cause   = [[sepsis|blood poisoning]]\n| resting_place = originally the [[lincoln tomb]] (1890–1930),<br/>[[arlington national cemetery]] section 31 (may 27, 1930&nbsp;– present)\n| other_names   = \"jack\"\n| known_for     = being a namesake and grandson of president lincoln\n}}\n\n\'\'\'abraham \"jack\" lincoln ii\'\'\' (august 14, 1873&nbsp;– march 5, 1890), was the middle of three children of [[robert todd lincoln]] and [[mary eunice harlan]], and the only grandson of [[abraham lincoln]]. jack and his sisters were described as ‘bright, natural, unpretentious children, well liked by the people of the town’.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=biography and family line of the lincolns\n|url=http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/d/u/n/terence-l-duniho/gene5-0003.html# }}</ref> it was claimed that jack was much like president lincoln.<ref name=ala>{{cite web |url=http://www.abrahamlincolnassociation.org/newsletters/9-3.pdf |title=a death in the family : abraham lincoln ii \"jack\" (1873–1890) |accessdate=2008-09-21 |last=schwartz |first=thomas f. |year=2007 |month=autumn |format=pdf |work=for the people |publisher=abraham lincoln association }}</ref> \n\n[[image:abraham lincoln ii and his sisters, mary and jesse.jpg|thumb|left|abraham lincoln ii (top), with his sisters [[mary \"mamie\" lincoln]] (left) and [[jessie harlan lincoln]] (right).]]\n==illness and death==\nat the age of 16, jack was in [[versailles (city)|versailles]] to study [[french language|french]] in preparation for an entrance examination for [[harvard university]].<ref name=ala/> his family was 
<page> <title>abraham_moles</title><text>\'\'\'abraham moles\'\'\' (1920–may 22, 1992) was an engineer of [[electrical engineering]] and [[acoustics]], and a doctor of [[physics]] and [[philosophy]]. he was one of the first researchers to establish and analyze links between [[aesthetics]] and [[information theory]].\n\nhe taught [[sociology]] and [[psychology]] at the universities of [[ulm]], [[strasbourg]], [[san diego]], [[national autonomous university of mexico|mexico]], [[compiègne]], and founded the \ninstitute of [[social psychology]] of [[communication]] in [[strasbourg]].\n\n== selected work ==\n\n* \'\'physique et technique du bruit\'\', paris, dunod, 1952\n* \'\'la création scientifique\'\', genève, kister, 1957\n* \'\'musiques expérimentales\'\', zurich, cercle d\'art, 1961\n* \'\'communications et langages\'\', (en collaboration avec b. vallancien), paris, gauthier-villars, 1963\n* \'\'phonétique et phonation\'\', (en collaboration avec b. vallancien) paris, masson, 1966\n* \'\'l\'affiche dans la société urbaine\'\', paris, dunod, 1969\n* \'\'créativité et méthodes d\'innovation\'\', paris, fayard, 1970\n* \'\'art et ordinateur\'\', paris, casterman, 1971\n* \'\'théorie des objets\'\', paris, ed. universitaires, 1972\n* \'\'psychologie de l\'espace\'\', (en collaboration avec Élisabeth rohmer), paris, casterman, 1972\n* \'\'théorie de l\'information et perception esthétique\'\', paris, denoël, 1973 ([[information theory]] and aesthetical perception)\n* \'\'sociodynamique de la culture\'\', paris, mouton, 1973\n* \'\'la communication\'\', paris, marabout, 1973\n* \'\'micropsychologie et vie quotidienne\'\', (en collaboration avec Élisabeth rohmer), paris, denoël, 1976\n* \'\'psychologie du kitsch\'\', paris, denoël, 1977\n* \'\'théorie des actes\'\', (en collaboration avec Élisabeth rohmer), paris, casterman, 1977\n* \'\'l\'image, communication fonctionnelle\'\', paris, casterman, 1981\n* \'\'labyrinthes du vécu\'\', paris, klincks

<page> <title>abraham_palatnik</title><text>{{one source|article|date=october 2007}}  \n\n\'\'\'abraham palatnik\'\'\' (born 1928) is a [[brazilian people|brazilian]] artist and inventor whose innovations include [[kinechromatic art]]. he is [[jewish]] and of [[russians|russian]] descent.\n\n==references==\n*frederico morais, \'\'abraham palatnik : a pioneer of technological art\'\', [http://www.olats.org/pionniers/pp/palatnik/morais_en.php leonardo on-line].\n\n{{authority control|viaf=96557053}}\n\n{{persondata <!-- metadata: see [[wikipedia:persondata]]. -->\n| name              = palatnik, abraham\n| alternative names =\n| short description =\n| date of birth     = 1928\n| place of birth    =\n| date of death     =\n| place of death    =\n}}\n{{defaultsort:palatnik, abraham}}\n[[category:1928 births]]\n[[category:brazilian artists]]\n[[category:modern artists]]\n[[category:living people]]\n[[category:brazilian people of russian descent]]\n[[category:brazilian inventors]]\n[[category:russian inventors]]\n\n\n{{brazil-artist-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>abraham_prescott</title><text>{{infobox person\n| name = abraham prescott\n| image = \n| image_size = \n| caption = \n| birth_name = \n| birth_date = {{birth date|1789|7|5}}\n| birth_place = [[deerfield, new hampshire|deerfield]], [[new hampshire]], [[united states]]\n| death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|1858|5|1|1789|7|5}}\n| death_place = [[concord, new hampshire|concord]], [[new hampshire]], [[united states]]\n| occupation = [[luthier]]\n| years_active = \n| religion = \n| website = \n}}\n\n\'\'\'abraham prescott\'\'\' was a noted [[luthier]], particularly of the [[double bass]], who worked in [[deerfield, new hampshire|deerfield]] and [[concord, new hampshire]] during the 19th century. prescott built his first double bass in 1819, building 207  over the course of his career.<ref>{{citation | last = shrader | first = erin | title = pilgrim\'s pride | journal = strings magazine | url = http://www.stringsmagazine.com/article/default.aspx?articleid=21453}}</ref>\nprescott and his apprentices also made hundreds of [[american bass viol|church basses]] in addition to [[violoncellos]], [[violins]], and keyboard instruments such as [[reed organ|melodians]].  <ref>{{citation| last = wall\n  | first = edward\n  | author-link =  \n  | title = abraham prescott: bass viol maker of deerfield and concord\n  | journal = historical new hampshire\n  | volume = 42\n  | issue = \n  | pages = 101–117\n  | date = \n  | year = 1987\n  | url = http://home.earthlink.net/~prescottviol/data/nhhistsoc101.jpg\n  | doi = \n  | id = }} </ref>  <ref>{{cite book | last=bush | first=douglas | coauthors=kassel, richard | title=the organ: an encyclopedia  | publisher=routledge | year=2006 | isbn= 0-415-94174-1 | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=cgdjaeffupoc&lpg=pp1&pg=pt455#v=onepage&q=&f=false | accessdate=2010-01-10}}</ref> \n\nprescott basses are prized by professional musicians throughout the united states.  one particularly famous prescott bass was owned by [[jazz]] l
<page> <title>abraham_sofaer</title><text>{{for|the us jurist|abraham david sofaer}}\n{{no footnotes|date=february 2013}}\n{{infobox person\n| name = abraham sofaer\n| image = sofaer.jpg\n| imagesize =\n| caption = sofaer in \'\'[[mission: impossible]]\'\'\n| birth_date = {{birth date|1896|10|1|df=y}}\n| birth_place = [[rangoon]], [[burma]]\n| height = \n| death_date = {{dda|1988|1|21|1896|10|1|df=y}}\n| death_place = [[woodland hills, los angeles, california|woodland hills]], [[los angeles, california|los angeles]], [[california]], [[united states]]\n| birthname = \n| othername = \n| homepage =\n| notable role =\n| academyawards =\n}}\n\n\'\'\'abraham sofaer\'\'\' (october 1, 1896 – january 21, 1988) was a stage actor of [[burma|burmese]]-[[jew]]ish descent who became a familiar supporting player on film and television in his later years.  he was born in [[rangoon]]. sofaer\'s strong features and resonant voice complemented the many exotic character parts he played.\n\nhe began his acting career on the london stage in 1921, but soon was alternating between london and [[broadway theatre|broadway]].  by the 1930s, he was appearing in both british and american films. among his more prominent performances were the dual role of the judge and surgeon in [[powell and pressburger]]\'s \'\'[[a matter of life and death (film)|a matter of life and death]]\'\' (1946) and [[paul of tarsus|st. paul]] in \'\'[[quo vadis (1951 film)|quo vadis]]\'\' (1951).\n\nhe also appeared on television from its earliest days in the late 1930s and on radio.  although his film appearances diminished after the 1950s, he continued to have guest roles on dozens of major u.s. television series throughout the 1960s.  he made three appearances on \'\'[[perry mason]]\'\', including the role of defendant elihu laban in the 1963 episode, \"the case of the two-faced turn-a-bout.\"  he also guest starred on \'\'[[star trek]]\'\' (\"[[charlie x]]\") & (\"[[spectre of the gun]]\" - voice only), \'\'[[the t
<page> <title>abraham_sowden</title><text>{{infobox person\n| name        = abraham sowden\n| image       = <!-- just the filename, without the file: or image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] -->\n| alt         = \n| caption     = \n| birth_name  = \n| birth_date  = {{birth date|1853|12|1}}\n| birth_place =  [[great horton]], [[bradford]], [[yorkshire]], [[england]]\n| death_date  = {{death date and age|1921|7|5|1853|12|1}}\n| death_place =  [[heaton, west yorkshire]], england\n| nationality = \n| other_names = \n| known_for   = \n| occupation  = \n}}\n\'\'\'abraham sowden\'\'\' (1 december 1853 &ndash; 5 july 1921) was an [[english people|english]] [[first-class cricket]]er, who played eight matches for [[yorkshire county cricket club]] from 1878 to 1887,<ref name=\"yb\">{{cite book |title=the yorkshire county cricket club: 2011 yearbook |last=warner |first=david |coauthor=|year=2011 |edition=113th |publisher=great northern books |location=ilkley, yorkshire |isbn=978-1-905080-85-4 |page=378 |page=|url= |accessdate=9 july 2011}}</ref> and for t emmett\'s xi in 1881, plus an england xi against the [[australia cricket team|australians]] in 1902, when he was aged 48.\n\nborn in [[great horton]], [[bradford]], [[yorkshire]], [[england]], and registered as abram sowden, he was a successful batsman for bingley c.c. from 1875 to 1893 and for bradford c.c. from 1893 to 1901.\n\nin ten first-class matches he scored 163 runs, with a best score of 37 against [[kent county cricket club|kent]], and he took one catch.  he bowled right arm fast with a round arm action, but conceded 70 runs without success. \n\nsowden was a worsted manufacturer by trade, and died in july 1921 in [[heaton, west yorkshire|heaton]], yorkshire.\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==external links==\n*[http://content-www.cricinfo.com/england/content/player/20939.html cricinfo profile]\n*[http://www.cricketarchive.com/archive/players/32/32940/32940.html cricket archive statistics]\n\n{{england-cricket-bio
<page> <title>abraham_staphorst</title><text>[[file:colonel alexander popham, of littlecote, wiltshire, by abraham staphorst (circa 1638-1696).jpg|thumb|colonel [[alexander popham]], of [[littlecote house]], wiltshire, by abraham staphorst]]\n\n\'\'\'abraham staphorst\'\'\', or \'\'\'staphortius\'\'\' (ca. 1638, [[edam, north holland|edam]] &ndash; 1696, [[dordrecht]]), was a [[dutch golden age]] painter.\n\n==biography==\naccording to houbraken he was a good portrait painter and the son of johannes staphortius, a well known preacher of dordrecht, whose portrait he often sketched with chalk or charcoal on the walls of the taverns he visited with the remark, \"do you want to see my father?\".<ref name=houbraken>{{languageicon|nl|middle dutch}} [http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/houb005groo01_01/houb005groo01_01_0314.htm abraham staphorst biography] in \'\'de groote schouburgh der nederlantsche konstschilders en schilderessen\'\' (1718) by [[arnold houbraken]], courtesy of the [[digital library for dutch literature]]</ref>\n\naccording to the rkd he moved to dordrecht in 1643. <ref name=rkd>[http://www.rkd.nl/rkddb/dispatcher.aspx?action=search&database=choiceartists&search=priref=74701 abraham staphorst] in the [[rkd]]</ref> he visited rome as a young man, and worked in london, the hague, amsterdam, and norwich before settling in dordrecht.<ref name=rkd/>\n\n{{commonscat}}\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n*[http://www.artnet.com/artists/abraham-staphorst/past-auction-results abraham staphorst] on [[artnet]]\n\n{{persondata <!-- metadata: see [[wikipedia:persondata]]. -->\n| name              = staphorst, abraham\n| alternative names =\n| short description = dutch golden age painter\n| date of birth     = 1638\n| place of birth    = edam\n| date of death     = 1696\n| place of death    = dordrecht\n}}\n{{defaultsort:staphorst, abraham}}\n[[category:1630s births]]\n[[category:1696 deaths]]\n[[category:dutch golden age painters]]\n[[category:people from edam-volendam]]\n\n\n{{ne
<page> <title>abraham_trembley</title><text>{{infobox scientist\n|name              = abraham trembley\n|image             =abraham trembley.jpg\n|image_size       =150px\n|caption           = abraham trembley\n|birth_date        = 3 september 1710\n|birth_place       =\n|death_date        = 12 may 1784\n|death_place       =\n|residence         =\n|citizenship       =\n|nationality       = [[switzerland]]\n|field             = [[natural history|naturalist]]\n|work_institutions =\n|alma_mater        =\n|doctoral_advisor  =\n|doctoral_students =\n|known_for         = [[hydra (genus)|\'\'hydra\'\' (genus)]]\n|author_abbrev_bot =\n|author_abbrev_zoo =\n|influences        =\n|influenced        =\n|prizes            = [[copley medal]], 1743\n|footnotes         =\n|signature         =\n}}\n\'\'\'abraham trembley\'\'\' (3 september 1710 – 12 may 1784 geneva) was a [[switzerland|swiss]] [[natural history|naturalist]]. he is best known for being the first to study freshwater polyps or \'\'[[hydra (genus)|hydra]]\'\' and for being among the first to develop experimental [[zoology]]. his mastery of experimental method has led some historians of science to credit him as the \"father of [[biology]]\".<ref>see \'\'ratcliff\'\', op.cit., p. 556, n. 1.</ref>\n\n==biography==\ntrembley came from an officer\'s family from [[geneva]], [[switzerland]].\nhe was uncle to [[charles bonnet]], with whom he corresponded regularly, as well as to [[rené-antoine ferchault de réaumur]] (1683-1757) and [[lazzaro spallanzani]] (1729-1799). trembley acted as tutor to the children of count willem bentinck (1704-1774), a prominent dutch politician at the time. they were 3 and 6 when trembley, during his lessons, discovered the regenerative powers of the hydra with the boys. those were conducted at the count\'s summer residence of zorgvlied nearby [[the hague]].<ref>{{cite book|last=stott|first=rebecca|title=darwin\'s ghosts|year=2012|publisher=spiegel& grau|location=new york|isbn=978-1-4088-0908-2

<page> <title>abraham_woods</title><text>{{distinguish|abraham wood}}\n\n\'\'\'abraham lincoln woods, jr.\'\'\' (october 7, 1928 – november 7, 2008) was an [[united states|american]] [[civil rights]] leader, who helped coordinate the 1963 [[march on washington for jobs and freedom]] and stood behind [[martin luther king, jr.]] during his historic \"[[i have a dream]]\" speech.<ref name=montobit/>\n\n==early life==\n\nwoods was born on october 7, 1928 in [[birmingham, alabama]].<ref name=nbc13>pollone, chris. [http://www.nbc13.com/vtm/news/local/article/the_life_and_legacy_of_rev_abraham_woods_jr/45555/ \"the life and legacy of rev. abraham woods, jr.\"], \'\'[[wvtm-tv]]\'\', november 7, 2008. accessed november 9, 2008.</ref> he was one of 11 children born to his parents, rev. abraham woods sr. and the former maggie wallace. he attended [[morehouse college]] with martin luther king, jr., and later received a [[bachelor of theology]] at birmingham baptist college, a bachelor\'s in sociology at [[miles college]] and a master\'s degree from the [[university of alabama]] in american history.<ref name=nytobit>hevesi, dennis. [http://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/13/us/13woods.html \"abraham woods, civil rights pioneer, dies at 80\"], \'\'[[the new york times]]\'\', november 12, 2008. accessed november 12, 2008.</ref>\n\n==civil rights movement==\n\nwoods had been pastor of the first metropolitan baptist church in the early 1960s and led the st. joseph baptist church starting in 1967 as its pastor.<ref name=montobit>via the \'\'[[associated press]]\'\'. [http://www.montgomeryadvertiser.com/article/20081109/news02/811090347 \"birmingham civil rights leader woods dies\"], \'\'[[montgomery advertiser]]\'\', november 9, 2008. accessed november 9, 2008.</ref>\n\nin addition to his service as the president of the birmingham chapter of the [[southern christian leadership conference]], woods would often lead community marches to protest community violence, police shootings and [[sluml
<page> <title>abraham_yagel</title><text>\'\'\'abraham yagel\'\'\'<ref>abraham ben hananiah dei galicci yagel or jagel</ref> ([[monselice]] 1553 &ndash; 1623) was an italian jewish catechist, philosopher, and [[kabbalah|cabalist]]. he lived successively at [[luzzara]], [[venice]], [[ferrara]], and [[sassuolo]].\n\n==life and identity==\n[[giulio bartolocci]],<ref>\"bibliotheca magna rabbinica,\" i. 26.</ref> followed by de rossi,<ref>\"dizionario,\" i. 160.</ref> wolf,<ref>\"bibl. hebr.\" i., no. 78.</ref> and [[julius fürst]],<ref>\"bibl. jud.\" ii. 10.</ref> erroneously identified abraham yagel with the christian censor [[camillo jagel]], declaring that abraham jagel embraced christianity and changed his name to \"camillo jagel.\" the untenability of this identification has been proved by later scholars, including [[hananiah coèn]].<ref>\"saggio di eloquenza ebrea,\" p. 25, florence, 1827</ref> \n\ncoèn\'s chief argument is that many books dated as early as 1611 bear the signature of \"inquisitor camillo jagel,\" while abraham yagel was known in 1615 as a pious jew, as is shown by the following adventure related by himself. in 1615 he was captured by bandits soon after leaving luzzara, between [[reggio emilia|reggio]] and [[guastalla]]. his traveling companion, raphael modena, a rich jew of sassuolo, to whose house yagel acted as family adviser, was captured with him. yagel was sent back by the bandits to modena\'s family for a ransom; the sum being too high, the rabbis and influential jews of modena came to his aid, and, supported by the duke and his brother, the cardinal, obtained modena\'s liberty.\n\n==works==\nmany details of yagel\'s life are given in his \"ge Ḥizzayon,\" the first part of which was published by [[baruch mani]] (alexandria, 1880). it purports to be the relation of a dream in which he saw his deceased father, to whom he narrated the events of his life. after his father\'s death he went, an inexperienced youth, to luzzara, where he became
<page> <title>abraham_ben_nathan</title><text>\'\'\'abraham ben nathan ha-yarhi\'\'\' ([[hebrew]]: \'\'\'אברהם בן נתן הירחי\'\'\') was a [[provençal rabbi]] and scholar born in the second half of the 12th century, probably at [[lunel]], [[languedoc]], where he also received his education.  it is for this reason that he is sometimes also called \"ha-yarḥi\" (\"of lunel\") since the hebrew \"yareaḥ\" is the equivalent of the french \"lune\", or moon in english.\n\nin lunel, abraham  may have studied under [[rabad iii]] ([[abraham ben david of posquières]]), but his regular rabbinical studies, were pursued at [[dampierre, aube|dampierre]], in northern [[france]], at the academy of r. [[isaac ben samuel]], called r. isaac ha-zaḳen. abraham subsequently left his birthplace, and, after much traveling, finally settled in [[toledo, spain|toledo]] in 1204, where his learning quickly gained for him the favor of the rich and learned [[joseph ibn shushan]] and that of his sons, solomon and isaac. to these patrons he dedicated his work \'\'ha-manhig\'\'<ref>[http://openlibrary.org/b/ol20096624m/sefer_ha-manhig sefer ha-manhig]</ref> (\'\'the guide\'\'), or as the author called it, \'\'manhig \'olam,\'\' which he began in 1204 and completed some years later. in its present form the book consists of two distinct portions, the first of which comprises a collection of responsa, compiled from his numerous written and oral decisions, some of the former of which still bear the usual epistolary conclusion: \"shalom! a. b. n.\" (greeting! abraham ben nathan). the second part contains extracts from the halakic works of [[alfasi]], [[isaac ibn giat]], and [[isaac ben abba mari]], a relative of abraham\'s.\n\nthe \'\'manhig\'\' did not exert any important influence on halakic literature and is only occasionally mentioned by rabbis of the [[middle ages]]. however, it must be considered as of some importance in the history of [[jewish literature]], for it contains numer
<page> <title>abraham_ibn_daud</title><text>{{other uses|rabad (disambiguation)}}\n\n\'\'\'abraham ibn daud\'\'\' ([[hebrew language|hebrew]]: אברהם אבן דאוד; [[arabic language|arabic]]: ابراهيم بن داود) was a [[history of the jews in spain|spanish-jewish]] [[astronomy|astronomer]], [[historian]], and [[philosopher]]; born at [[cordoba, spain]] about 1110; died in [[toledo, spain]], according to common report, a [[martyr]] about 1180. he is sometimes known by the abbreviation \'\'\'\'\'rabad i\'\'\'\'\' or \'\'\'\'\'ravad i\'\'\'\'\'. his mother belonged to a family famed for its learning. \n==works==\n*his chronicle, a work written in 1161 under the title of \'\'[[sefer ha-kabbalah]]\'\' (book of tradition), in which he fiercely attacked the contentions of [[karaite judaism|karaism]] and justified [[rabbinical judaism]] by the establishment of a chain of traditions from [[moses]] to his own time, is replete with valuable general information, especially relating to the time of the [[geonim]] and to the history of the jews in spain. \n*an astronomical work written by him in 1180 is favorably noticed by [[isaac israeli the younger]] (\"yesod \'olam,\" iv. 18). \n*his philosophical work, \'\'al-\'akidah al-rafiyah\'\' (the sublime faith), written in 1168, in arabic, has been preserved in two hebrew translations: one by [[solomon ben labi]], with the title \'\'emunah ramah\'\'; the other by [[samuel motot]]. labi\'s translation was retranslated into [[german language|german]] and published by [[simshon weil]].\n\n==philosophy==\nibn daud was the first to introduce the phase of [[jewish philosophy]] which is generally attributed to [[maimonides]] and which differs from former systems of philosophy mainly in its more thorough systematic form derived from aristotle. accordingly, [[hasdai crescas]] mentions ibn daud as the only jewish philosopher among the predecessors of maimonides (\'\'or adonai\'\', ch. i.). but having been completely overshadowe
<page> <title>abraham_of_strathearn</title><text>[[image:abraham of dunblane seal.jpg|thumb|bishop abraham\'s [[seal (device)|seal]], attached to a charter of 1211.]]\n\'\'\'abraham\'\'\' was an early 13th-century scottish cleric who held the position of [[bishop of dunblane]]. he was a [[chaplain]] to the [[mormaer of strathearn]], [[gille brigte, earl of strathearn|gille brígte]].<ref>cynthia j. neville, \'\'native lordship in medieval scotland: the earldoms of strathearn and lennox, c. 1140–1365\'\', (dublin, 2005), p. 64; james hutchison cockburn, \'\'the medieval bishops of dunblane and their church\'\', (edinburgh, 1959) p. 37.</ref> \n\nthere are no exact accounts of his origin, but his name and the background suggest he was a [[native scot]] from [[strathearn]]. there is no evidence to the contrary. neville wrote that his \"hebrew name conceals an english provenance\",<ref>neville, \'\'native lordship\'\', p. 64.</ref> but in fact the hebrew name is more consistent with established gaelic-naming patterns than with english or french ones.<ref>thomas owen clancy, \"scotland, the ‘nennian’ recension of the historia brittonum, and the lebor bretnach\", in simon taylor (ed.), \'\'kings, clerics and chronicles in scotland, 500–1297\'\', (portland, 2000), p. 91.</ref> \n\nhe was a son of a priest, and had at least one son of his own, arthur by name.<ref>william alexander lindsay, john dowden, and john maitland thomson (eds.), \'\'charters, bulls and other documents relating to the abbey of inchaffray chiefly from the originals in the charter chest of the earl of kinnoull\'\', (publications of the scottish history society, vol. 56, 1908), pp. 24, 260,; cockburn, \'\'the medieval bishops of dunblane\'\', pp. 36-7; [[augustin theiner]], \'\'vetera monumenta hibernorum et scotorum historiam illustrantia, quae ex vaticani neapolis ac florentiae\'\', (rome, 1864), no. 6.</ref> evidence from the charters of [[inchaffray abbey]] shows that he was bishop-elect by s
<page> <title>abraham_van_olst</title><text>{{unreferenced|date=august 2007}}\n\n\'\'\'abraham van olst\'\'\' (24 september 1897, [[amsterdam]] – 9 april 1964, amsterdam) was a [[netherlands|dutch]] [[water polo]] player who competed in the [[1928 summer olympics]].\n\nhe was part of the dutch team in the [[water polo at the 1928 summer olympics|1928 tournament]]. he played both matches as goalkeeper.\n\n{{persondata <!-- metadata: see [[wikipedia:persondata]]. -->\n| name              = olst, abraham van\n| alternative names =\n| short description = dutch water polo player\n| date of birth     = september 24, 1897\n| place of birth    =\n| date of death     = april 9, 1964\n| place of death    =\n}}\n{{defaultsort:olst, abraham van}}\n[[category:1897 births]]\n[[category:1964 deaths]]\n[[category:dutch water polo players]]\n[[category:water polo players at the 1928 summer olympics]]\n[[category:olympic water polo players of the netherlands]]\n[[category:sportspeople from amsterdam]]\n\n\n{{netherlands-waterpolo-bio-stub}}</text> </page>

[[manama]], the capital city of [[bahrain]]. the entire project consists of three large towers, two of which have 50 floors and one with 40. the three towers (\'\'gold pearl\'\', \'\'silver pearl\'\' and the \'\'black pearl\'\') are located next to the [[king faisal highway]], which is close to popular landmarks such as the [[pearl roundabout]], [[national bank of bahrain|nbb tower]], [[bahrain world trade center|bahrain wtc]] and the [[bahrain financial harbour|bahrain financial harbor]]. the entire project covers a land area of over {{convert|23230|m2|sqft|abbr=on}}.\n\n== design ==\n\'\'\'abraj al lulu\'\'\' w
<page> <title>abram_colby</title><text>\'\'\'abram colby\'\'\' was an american slave and politician who served in the [[georgia house of representatives]] during the [[georgia during reconstruction|reconstruction era]]. a resident of [[greene county, georgia]], colby was the son of an enslaved woman and a white planter. he was free for fifteen years prior to [[emancipation]]. he was an early organizer of freed slaves. colby and minister [[henry mcneal turner]] helped form a chapter of the [[american equal rights association]]. colby was known for eloquent oratory and represented greene county in 1865 at a freeman\'s convention. a [[radical republican]], colby was first elected in 1866.<ref name=\"greene\">{{cite web|url=http://mgagnon.myweb.uga.edu/students/3090/04sp3090-hull.htm|title=greene county blacks|accessdate=2 february 2013}}</ref> in 1868, he was bribed by the [[ku klux klan]] not to seek re-election, but refused to do so. in october 1869, he was beaten by the ku klux klan in front of his family. faced with debilitating injury, he was unable to work and did not seek re-election. in 1872, he was called before a  joint u.s. house and senate committee investigating reports of southern violence.<ref name=\"pbs\">{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/reconstruction/kkk/ps_colby.html|title=american experience – reconstruction: the second civil war – white men unite |work=[[pbs]]|accessdate=1 february 2013}}</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{persondata <!-- metadata: see [[wikipedia:persondata]]. -->\n| name              = colby, abram\n| alternative names =\n| short description = american slave and politiican\n| date of birth     =\n| place of birth    =\n| date of death     =\n| place of death    =\n}}\n{{defaultsort:colby, abram}}\n[[category:year of birth missing]]\n[[category:year of death missing]]\n[[category:members of the georgia house of representatives]]\n[[category:african-american politicians]]\n[[category:georgia (u.s. state) repub
<page> <title>abrams_building</title><text>{{infobox_nrhp | name =abrams building\n  | nrhp_type = \n  | image = abrams building albany 1979.png\n  | caption = south profile and east elevation, 1979\n refnum=80002577<ref name=\"nris\">{{nrisref|2009a}}</ref>\n}}\nthe \'\'\'abrams building\'\'\' was located at south pearl street ([[new york state route 32]]) and hudson avenue in [[albany, new york|albany]], new york, united states. it was a brick commercial building constructed in the 1880s. in 1980 it was listed on the [[national register of historic places]].<ref name=nris/>\n\noriginally it was part of a row of similar buildings. by the time it was listed, all of the adjoining buildings had been demolished, and it was one of the few 19th-century commercial building in albany\'s downtown that retained its original storefront.<ref name=\"nrhp nom\" /> seven years later, in 1987, it was demolished to make way for the future knickerbocker arena (now known as the [[times union center]]).<ref name=\"t-u d
<page> <title>abraxas_gephyra</title><text>{{taxobox\n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| classis = [[insect]]a\n| ordo = [[lepidoptera]]\n| familia = [[geometridae]]\n| genus = \'\'[[abraxas (moth)|abraxas]]\'\'\n| species = \'\'\'\'\'a. gephyra\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'abraxas gephyra\'\'\n| binomial_authority = west, 1929\n| synonyms =\n}}\n\'\'\'\'\'abraxas gephyra\'\'\'\'\' is a species of [[moth]] belonging to the family [[geometridae]]. it was described by west in 1929. it is known from [[luzon]] in the [[philippines]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nic.funet.fi/pub/sci/bio/life/insecta/lepidoptera/ditrysia/geometroidea/geometridae/ennominae/abraxas/index.html |title=abraxas at funet.fi |publisher=nic.funet.fi |date= |accessdate=2011-12-16}}</ref> \n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n[[category:abraxini]]\n\n{{ennominae-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>abraxas_intermedia</title><text>{{taxobox\n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| classis = [[insect]]a\n| ordo = [[lepidoptera]]\n| familia = [[geometridae]]\n| genus = \'\'[[abraxas (moth)|abraxas]]\'\'\n| species = \'\'\'\'\'a. intermedia\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'abraxas intermedia\'\'\n| binomial_authority = warren, 1888\n| synonyms =\n*\'\'abraxas determinata\'\' <small>warren, 1894</small>\n}}\n\'\'\'\'\'abraxas intermedia\'\'\'\'\' is a species of [[moth]] belonging to the family [[geometridae]]. it was described by warren in 1888. it is known from subathu in [[india]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nic.funet.fi/pub/sci/bio/life/insecta/lepidoptera/ditrysia/geometroidea/geometridae/ennominae/abraxas/index.html |title=abraxas at funet.fi |publisher=nic.funet.fi |date= |accessdate=2011-12-16}}</ref> \n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n[[category:abraxini]]\n\n{{ennominae-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>abraxas_suspecta</title><text>{{taxobox\n| image = abraxas suspecta.jpg\n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| classis = [[insect]]a\n| ordo = [[lepidoptera]]\n| familia = [[geometridae]]\n| genus = \'\'[[abraxas (moth)|abraxas]]\'\'\n| species = \'\'\'\'\'a. suspecta\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'abraxas suspecta\'\'\n| binomial_authority = (warren, 1894)\n| synonyms =\n}}\n\'\'\'\'\'abraxas suspecta\'\'\'\'\' is a species of [[moth]] belonging to the family [[geometridae]]. it was described by warren in 1894.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nic.funet.fi/pub/sci/bio/life/insecta/lepidoptera/ditrysia/geometroidea/geometridae/ennominae/abraxas/index.html |title=abraxas at funet.fi |publisher=nic.funet.fi |date= |accessdate=2011-12-16}}</ref> it is known from [[china]].\n\nthere are four generations per year.\n\nthe larvae feed on \'\'[[euonymus japonicus]]\'\'. the species overwinters as a pupa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.cnki.com.cn/article_en/cjfdtotal-slbc200904008.htm |title=bionomics and control of abraxas suspecta |publisher=en.cnki.com.cn |date= |accessdate=2011-12-16}}</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n[[category:abraxini]]\n\n{{ennominae-stub}}</text> </page>

<page> <title>abronia_graminea</title><text>{{italictitle}}{{taxobox\n|name=\'\'abronia graminea\'\'\n| image = arboreal alligator lizard abronia graminea 2900px.jpg\n| image_caption = \'\'abronia graminea\'\'\n|status=en\n|status_system=iucn3.1\n| status_ref = <ref> {{iucn2008 | assessors=flores-villela, o. & santos-barrera, g. | year=2007 | title=abronia graminea | id=63678 | downloaded=18 february 2009}} </ref>\n|regnum=[[animalia]]\n|phylum=[[chordata]]\n|classis=[[reptilia]]\n|ordo=[[squamata]]\n|familia=[[anguidae]]\n|genus=\'\'[[abronia (animal)|abronia]]\'\'\n|species=\'\'\'\'\'a. graminea\'\'\'\'\'\n|species_authority=[[edward drinker cope|cope]], 1864\n|binomial=\'\'\'\'\'abronia graminea\'\'\'\'\'\n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'abronia graminea\'\'\'\'\' is an [[endangered]] [[arboreal alligator lizard]] described in 1864 by [[edward drinker cope|cope]].\n\nthis species is endemic to the highlands of the states of veracruz and adjacent puebla, mexico.\nit is considered to be moderately common and is regularly recorded, but its abundance is decreasing.\nanimals inhabit bromeliads in the canopy of montane pine-oak and cloud forest.\nit seems unlikely that this species can be found in degraded habitat.\nthis is a viviparous species.\nthe species is threatened by deforestation and degradation of habitat, largely through the conversion of land to agricultural use. the pet trade is a potential aid to the preservation of this species through captive breeding programs.\n\n==references==\n\n<references/>\n\n{{lizard-stub}}</text> </page>

<page> <title>absence_seizure</title><text>{{infobox disease\n| name           = absence seizure\n| icd10          = {{icd10|g|40|3|g|40}}\n| icd9           = {{icd9|345.0}}\n| icdo           =\n| image          =\n| caption        =\n| omim           =\n| omim_mult      =\n| medlineplus    = 000696\n| emedicinesubj  = neuro\n| emedicinetopic = 3\n| diseasesdb     = 32994\n| meshid         = d004832\n}}\n\'\'\'absence seizures\'\'\' are one of several kinds of [[seizure]]s. these seizures are sometimes referred to as \'\'\'petit mal seizures\'\'\' (from the french for \"little illness\", a term dating from the late 18th century<ref>{{cite journal |pages=175–8 |doi=10.1111/j.1528-1157.1968.tb04618.x |title=reflections on the concept of petit mal |year=1968 |last1=daly |first1=d. d. |journal=epilepsia |volume=9 |issue=3 |pmid=4975023}}</ref>).\n\nabsence seizures are brief (usually less than 20&nbsp;seconds), generalized epileptic seizures of sudden onset and termination.  when someone experiences an absence seizure they are often unaware of their episode.<ref>{{cite book |last=carlson |first=neil r. |authorlink=neil r. carlson |year=2013 |title=physiology of behavior}}</ref> those most susceptible to this are children and the first episode usually occurs between 4–12 years old. it is very rare that someone older will experience their first absence seizure. episodes of  absence seizures can often mistaken for inattentiveness when misdiagnosed and can occur 50-100 times a day. they can be so difficult to detect that some people may go months or years before given a proper diagnosis. there are no known before or after effects of absence seizures.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.epilepsyfoundation.org/aboutepilepsy/seizures/genconvulsive/absenceseizures/ |title = absence seizures |last = epilepsy therapy project |publisher = epilepsy foundation |accessdate= 8 may 2013 }}</ref>\nthey have two essential components:<ref name=\"electroencephalographic1981\">{{cite journ

<page> <title>absolute_currency_strength</title><text>{{blacklisted-links|1=\n*http://www.articlesbase.com/currency-trading-articles/how-to-trade-with-relative-rcs-and-absolute-acs-currency-strength-3100840.html\n*:\'\'triggered by <code>\\\\barticles(?:base&#124;vana)\\\\.com\\\\b</code> on the global blacklist\'\'|bot=cyberbot ii}}\n{{multiple issues|cleanup = august 2010|unreferenced = august 2010}}\n\n[[file:percentage currency strength - flowindi.png|thumb|500px||width=450|length=330|percentage currency strength for usd/eur/gbp/jpy/aud currencies]]\n\nthe \'\'\'absolute currency strength (acs)\'\'\' is a [[technical indicator]] used in the [[technical analysis]] of [[forex]] markets. it is intended to chart the current and historical  gain or loss of a currency based on the closing prices of a recent trading period. it\'s based on mathematical [[decorrelation]] of 28 cross currency pairs.it shows absolute strength momentum of selected [[currency pair|major currency]].(eur,gbp,aud,nzd,usd,cad,chf,jpy)\n\nthe acs is typically used on a 15*period timeframe,calculated as a percentage gain or loss.this indicator is not measured on a scale like [[relative currency strength]].\nshorter or longer timeframes are used for alternately shorter or longer outlooks.extreme high and low percentage values occur less\nfrequently but indicate stronger momentum of currency.\n\nacs is in most cases used as support indicator for [[relative currency strength]] indicator.but it can be used by itself for currency trading.\nyou can use absolute currency strength for pattern trading as well.combination of rcs and acs indicators gives you entry and exit signals for currency trading.\n\n==basic idea==\nindicator basic idea is \"\'\'\'buy strong currency and sell weak currency\'\'\'\". \nif is x/y currency pair in uptrend,it shows you if it\'s due to x strength or y weakness.\non this signals you can choose the most worth pair to trade.\n\n==indicator==\n<gallery>\nfile:rcs-acs.png|combinat
<page> <title>absolute_monarchy</title><text>{{original research|date=january 2013}}\n{{monarchism|expanded = varieties}}\n{{forms of government}}\n\n\'\'\'absolute monarchy\'\'\' is a monarchial form of government in which the [[monarch]] exercises ultimate governing authority as [[head of state]] and [[head of government]]; his or her powers are not limited by a constitution or by the law. an absolute monarch wields unrestricted [[political power]] over the [[sovereign state]] and its people. absolute monarchies are often hereditary but other means of transmission of power are attested. absolute monarchy differs from [[constitutional monarchy|limited monarchy]], in which the monarch’s authority is legally bound or restricted by a [[constitution]]; consequently, an absolute monarch is an [[autocracy|autocrat]].\n\nin theory, the absolute monarch exercises total power over the land and its subject people, yet in practice the monarchy is counterbalanced by political groups from among the social classes and castes of the realm, such as the [[aristocracy (government)|aristocracy]], [[clergy]] (see [[caesaropapism]]), [[bourgeoisie]], and [[proletariat|proletarians]].\n\nsome [[monarchies]] have weak or symbolic [[legislatures]] and other governmental bodies that the monarch can alter or dissolve at will. countries where the monarch still maintains absolute power are [[brunei]],<ref name=brunei-abs>{{cite news|title=lavish birthday for brunei ruler|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/5182520.stm|publisher=bbc news}}</ref> [[qatar]],<ref name=qat-abs>{{cite web|title=qatar: regional backwater to global player|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20890765|publisher=bbc news}}</ref> [[oman]],<ref name=oman-abs>{{cite web|title=q&a: elections to oman\'s consultative council|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-15288960|publisher=bbc news}}</ref> [[saudi arabia]],<ref name=\"cavendish78\"/> [[swaziland]],<ref name=swazi-abs>{{cite web|title=sw
<page> <title>absolute_reach</title><text>{{multiple issues|orphan = december 2008|unreferenced = december 2008}}\n\n\'\'\'absolute reach\'\'\' stands for the total number of people in the overall [[population]] of a [[market segment|market]]/[[country]], reached by a [[website]]. it is calculated by taking the number of [[unique visitor]]s and putting it into relation to the number of the total population.\n\n{{defaultsort:absolute reach}}\n[[category:internet access]]\n\n{{web-stub}}</text> </page>

<page> <title>absorbing_the_disarray</title><text>{{multiple issues|\n{{notability|music|date=may 2008}}\n{{refimprove|article|date=may 2008}}\n}}\n\n{{infobox album <!-- see wikipedia:wikiproject_albums -->\n| name        = absorbing the disarray\n| type        = studio\n| artist      = [[visceral bleeding]]\n| cover       = absorbing the disarray.jpg\n| released    = 9 may 2007\n| recorded    = studio flatpig, in june 2006\n| genre       = [[technical death metal]]\n| length      = 39:30\n| label       = [[neurotic records|neurotic]]\n| producer    = robert ahrling\n| last album  = \'\'[[transcend into ferocity]]\'\'<br />(2004)\n| this album  = \'\'\'\'\'absorbing the disarray\'\'\'\'\'<br />(2007)\n| next album  = \n}}\n{{album ratings\n| rev1 = \'\'[[decibel (magazine)|decibel]]\'\'\n| rev1score = favorable<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.decibelmagazine.com/reviews/nov2007/visceralbleeding.aspx |title=decibel magazine -
