<page> <title>absorption_heat_pump</title><text>\'\'\'absorption heat pump\'\'\' is essentially an air-source [[heat pump]] driven not by electricity, but by a heat source such as solar-heated water, or [[geothermal heat pump|geothermal-heated water]].  there are also absorption coolers available that work on the same principle, but are not reversible and cannot serve as a heat source.\n[[image:absorption heat pump.jpg|thumb|14,000 kw absorption heat pump]]\n\n== solar thermal==\nsingle, double or triple iterative absorption cooling cycles are used in different solar-thermal-cooling system designs. the more cycles, the more efficient they are.\n\nin the late 19th century, the most common [[phase transition|phase change]] [[refrigerant]] material for absorption cooling was a solution of [[ammonia]] and water. today, the combination of [[lithium bromide]] and water is also in common use. one end of the system of expansion/condensation pipes is heated, and the other end gets cold enough to make ice. originally, natural gas was used as a heat source in the late 19th century. today, [[propane]] is used in recreational vehicle absorption chiller refrigerators. innovative hot water solar thermal energy collectors can also be used as the modern \"free energy\" heat source.\n\nefficient absorption chillers require water of at least 190 °f (88 °c).  common, inexpensive flat-plate [[solar thermal collector]]s only produce about 160 °f (70 °c) water, but several successful commercial projects in the us, asia and europe have shown that flat plate solar collectors specially developed for temperatures over 200 °f (featuring double glazing, increased backside insulation, etc.) can be effective and cost efficient.<ref>[http://www.solid.at/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=53&itemid=73 \"solar cooling.\"] www.solid.at. accessed on 1 july 2008</ref> evacuated-tube solar panels can be used as well. concentrating solar collectors required for absorption chillers are less ef
<page> <title>abstract_illusionism</title><text>\'\'\'abstract illusionism\'\'\', a name coined by art historian and critic [[barbara rose]],<ref>[http://www.charlottejackson.com/archives/abstract%20illusionism%20barbara%20rose%201967%20artforum.pdf barbara rose. \"abstract illusionism.\"] artforum, october 1967, pp. 33-37.</ref> is an artistic movement that came into prominence in the [[united states]] during the mid-1970s. works consisted of both [[hard-edge]] and [[abstract expressionism|expressionistic]] abstract painting styles that employed the use of perspective, artificial light sources, and simulated cast shadows to achieve the illusion of three-dimensional space on a two-dimensional surface. abstract illusionism differed from traditional [[trompe-l\'œil]] (fool the eye) art in that the pictorial space seemed to project in front of, or away from, the canvas surface, as opposed to receding into the picture plane as in traditional painting. primarily, though, these were abstract paintings, as opposed to the realism of trompe l\'oeil. by the early 1980s, many of the visual devices that originated in abstract illusionism were appropriated into the commercial world and served a wide variety of applications in graphic design, fabric design and the unlikely decoration of recreational vehicles. this proliferation of abstract illusionist imagery eventually led to the disintegration of the original artistic movement and its transition into the mainstream.\n\npre-1970 forerunners and practitioners of the style include [[ronald davis]], [[allan d\'arcangelo]], and [[al held]]. documented artists associated with the 1970s abstract illusionism movement include [[james havard]], [[jack lembeck]], tony king, [[george d. green]], [[michael b. gallagher]], [[jack reilly (artist)|jack reilly]] and richard johnson.\n\nthe first major museum exhibitions to survey abstract illusionism were \"abstract illusionism,\" paul mellon arts center, wallingford, ct, 1977; \"seven new yor
<page> <title>abstract_polytope</title><text>[[image:isomorphic tetragons.svg|thumb|275px|as abstract polytopes, these quadrilaterals are all the same.]]\nin [[mathematics]], an \'\'\'abstract polytope\'\'\', informally speaking, is a structure which considers only the \'\'[[combinatorics|combinatorial]]\'\' properties of a traditional [[polytope]], ignoring many of its other properties, such as angles, edge lengths, etc. no space, such as [[euclidean space]], is required to contain it.\n\nthe term \'\'polytope\'\' is a generalisation of [[polygon]]s and [[polyhedron|polyhedra]] into any number of dimensions. \n\nwe shall present a precise, formal definition of an abstract polytope [[abstract polytope#formal definition|below]]. in fact, this definition is \'\'more general\'\' than the traditional concept of a polytope, and allows many new objects that have no counterpart in traditional theory.\n\n== traditional versus abstract polytopes ==\n\nin euclidean geometry, the six [[quadrilateral]]s above are all different.  yet they have something in common that is not shared by a triangle or a cube, for example.\n\nthe elegant, but geographically inaccurate, [[tube map|london tube map]] provides all the \'\'relevant\'\' information to go from \'\'a\'\' to \'\'b\'\'. an even better example is an electrical [[circuit diagram]] or schematic; the final layout of wires and parts is often unrecognisable at first glance. \n\nin each of these examples, the \'\'connections\'\' between elements are the same, regardless of the \'\'physical layout\'\'. the objects are said to be \'\'combinatorially equivalent\'\'. this equivalence is what is encapsulated in the concept of an abstract polytope. so, combinatorially, our six quadrilaterals are all the “same”. more rigorously, they are said to be [[isomorphic]] or “structure preserving”. \n\nproperties, particularly measurable ones, of traditional polytopes such as angles, edge-lengths, skewness, and convexity \'\'have no meaning
<page> <title>abstraction_model_checking</title><text>{{context|date=october 2009}}\n\'\'\'abstraction model checking\'\'\' is for systems where an actual representation is too complex in developing the model alone. so, the design undergoes a kind of translation to scaled down \"abstract\" version.\n\nthe set of [[variable (mathematics)|variables]] are partitioned into visible and invisible depending on their change of values. the real [[state space]] is summarized into a smaller set of the visible ones.\n\n==galois connected==\nthe real and the abstract state spaces are [[galois connection|galois connected]]. this means that if we take an element from the [[abstract space]], concretize it and abstract the concretized version, the result will be equal to the original. on the other hand, if you pick an element from the real space, abstract it and concretize the abstract version, the final result will be a super set of the original.\n\nthat is, \n\n<math>\\\\eta</math>(<math>\\\\theta</math>(abstract)) = abstract  <br/>\n<math>\\\\theta</math>(<math>\\\\eta</math>(real))  <math>\\\\supset</math> real\n\n==abstraction refinement loop==\na problem with abstraction [[model checking]] is that although the abstraction simulates the real, when the abstraction does not satisfy a property, it does not mean that this property actually fails in the real model. counter examples are checked against the real state space because we obtain \"spurious\" counter examples. so a part of the abstraction refinement loop is:\n#obtain the abstract model \n#model check and see if everything is ok. \n#if there is a counter example, then go back to the real state space and find out if it actually a counter model. \n#if not, return and continue model checking. \n\nspurious examples are mostly generated because dead end states and bad states are abstracted to the same kind. to solve this we need to create a segregation between the 2 kinds. the next step is to find the subset of invisible variabl

<page> <title>abu_basma_regional_council</title><text>{{ for|the [[haifa district]] local government|basma }}\n[[file:abu basma emblem.jpg|thumb|right|an official symbol of abu basma regional council]]\n[[file:abu basma map.jpg|thumb|right|abu basma regional council on the map]]\n\'\'\'abu basma regional council\'\'\' ({{lang-he|מועצה אזורית אבו בסמה}}, \'\'moatza ezorit abu basma\'\', {{lang-ar|مجلس إقليمي أبو بسمة}}, \'\'majlis iqlimi abu basma\'\') was a [[regional council (israel)|regional council]] operating in 2003-2012 and covering several [[negev bedouins|bedouin]] villages in the northwestern [[negev]] desert of [[israel]]. following the minister of interior decision on november 5, 2012 it was split into two newly created bodies: [[neve midbar regional council]] and [[al-kasom regional council]].<ref>[http://abubasma.org.il/index.php?m=ar&artd=6282 information for the citizens], abu basma regional council official site (hebrew)</ref>\n\n==list of communities==\nthere were 11 recognized communities in the abu basma regional council, and their population is 30,000 residents. there were also approximately 50,000 “diaspora” bedouins living in unrecognized villages outside the council’s jurisdiction.<ref name=\"jpost.com\">sharon udasin, [http://www.jpost.com/sci-tech/article.aspx?id=250315 \'gov’t must bring basic needs to beduins\'] jerusalem post, december 21, 2011</ref>\n\n{|\n|-\n|valign=top|\'\'\'recognised\'\'\'\n*[[abu qrenat]] (abu quraynat)\n*[[al-sayyid]]\n*[[bir hadaj]]\n*[[drijat]] (durayjat)\n*[[makhul]]\n*[[mulada]]\n*[[qasr al-sir]]\n*[[tirabin al-sana]]\n*[[umm batin]]\n*[[kukhleh]] (abu rubaiya)\n*[[abu talul]]<ref>[http://abubasma.org.il/ abu basma regional council. localities] official site (hebrew)</ref>\n||\n|valign=top|\'\'\'unrecognised\'\'\'\n*[[al-atrash, israel|al-atrash]] \n*[[al-hawashla]]\n*[[bir hil]]\n|}\n\n==history==\n\n===legal background===\nprior to the establishment of israel, the n

<page> <title>abu_khalil_qabbani</title><text>\'\'\'abu khalil qabbani\'\'\' ({{lang-ar|أبو خليل القباني}} / [[ala-lc]]: \'\'abū khalīl al-qabbānī\'\'; 1835–1902) was a [[syria]]n playwright and composer of [[turkish people|turkish]] origin.<ref name=\"sadgrove 2010 loc=267\">{{citation |last=sadgrove|first=philip|year=2010|chapter=ahmad abu khalil al-qabbani (1833-1902)|title=essays in arabic literary biography: 1850-1950|editor1-last=allen|editor1-first=roger m. a.|editor2-last=lowry|editor2-first=joseph edmund|editor3-last=stewart |editor3-first=devin j. (eds.)|place=|publisher=otto harrassowitz verlag|page=267|isbn=3447061413}}</ref> he is considered the founder of the short musical play (the [[operetta]])<ref name=\"las\">{{cite book\n  | last = hamdan\n  | first = masud\n  | authorlink = masud hamdan\n  | title = poetics, politics and protest in arab theatre\n  | publisher = [[sussex academic press]]\n  | series = \n  | isbn=1-84519-106-4\n  | year = 2006 }}\n</ref> in arabic theatre. his play \'\'abu al-hassan al-mughaffal\'\' caused a wave of protest as a result of his mockery of [[caliph]] [[harun al-rashid]], and ended with a decree by the [[ottoman empire|ottoman]] government to close his theatre and prevent theatrical performances in syria.<ref name=\"las\"/> qabbani left for [[egypt]] and produced his plays there until 1900. he returned to syria and died two years later in 1902.<ref name=\"las\"/> he is considered the \"father of syrian theatre\", and has influenced later generations including the famous [[duraid lahham]].<ref name=\"las\"/> his brother is the grandfather of [[nizar qabbani]].\n\n==see also==\n*[[list of syrians]].\n*[[list of playwrights]].\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{persondata <!-- metadata: see [[wikipedia:persondata]]. -->\n| name              = qabbani, abu khalil\n| alternative names =\n| short description = syrian writer\n| date of birth     = 1835\n| place of birth    =\n| date of death     = 1902\n|
<page> <title>abu_mikhnaf</title><text>{{infobox muslim scholar |      \n    \n     \n notability = [[list of islamic historians|muslim historian]]|    \n era = [[islamic golden age]]|\n\n   \n image = |          \n caption = |   \n \n      \n name = \'\'\'lut ibn yahya ibn sa\'id ibn mikhnaf al-kufi\'\'\'|       \n title= \'\'\'abi mekhnaf\'\'\'| \n birth_date = |       \n death_date = {{ah|157|774}} <ref name=kitab/>|       \n maddhab = [[shia]]|     \n school_tradition|= | \n ethnicity = |\n region = |     \nmain_interests = [[history of islam]]|      \n notable_ideas= |\n works = <small>kitab al-saqifa, kitab al-ridda, kitab al-shura, kitab al-jamal, kitab al-siffin, kitab maqtal [[hasan ibn ali|al-hasan]], kitab [[maqtal al-husayn]], sirat al-hussayn, ...<ref name=kitab/> </small>|\n influences = |          \n influenced = [[muhammad ibn jarir al-tabari|tabari]]<ref>abu mihnaf: ein beitrag zur historiographie der umaiyadischen zeit by ursula sezgin</ref>|          \n}}\n\n{{muslim scholars-02}}\n\'\'\'abi mekhnaf\'\'\' (lut ibn yahya ibn sa\'id ibn mikhnaf al-kufi) (\'\'\'{{lang|ar|لوط ابن يحيٰ ابن سعيد ابن مخنّف الكوفي }}\'\'\')  was a classical shia [[muslim historians|muslim historian]]  from the 8th century. he lived in [[kufa]] and died in {{ah|157|774}} .<ref name=kitab >[http://www.sicm.org.uk/knowledge/kitab%20maqtal%20al-husayn.pdf kitab maqtal al-husayn, translator\'s forward]</ref> he attributes to [[shiism]] by some [[rijal]] scholars but it\'s doubtful  and not accepted with all of them. however his works represent great tendency to [[ali]] and his sons [[hasan ibn ali|hasan]] and [[husayn ibn ali|husayn]].\n\n==biography==\n{{empty section|date=july 2010}}\n\n==style==\nin \"islamic historiography\", \"chase f. robinson\" has put him in the class of [[ibn ishaq]] and among the first muslim historians.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?vid=isbn0521629365&id=czbkcuvfdocc&pg=ra1-pa27&lpg=ra1-pa27&ots=atmfcokzqn&dq=%22a
<page> <title>abu_turab</title><text>{{unreferenced|date=december 2009}}\n{{islam}}\n\'\'\'abu turab\'\'\' ({{lang-ar|\'\'\'أبو تراب\'\'\'}}) or \'\'father of soil\'\', is a title attributed to [[imam ali ibn abi talib]], the fourth [[sunni]] [[caliph]],  and the first [[shia]] [[imam]]. according to narrations the title was given to ali by [[muhammad]], when he found ali sleeping while covered with soil. \n\nabu turab means \"father of the mud\". he received this name because of his lengthy sujoods (placing of the forehead on the ground in prayer).\n\n==see also==\n*[[ali ibn abi talib]]\n*[[shia islam]]\n*[[shia imam]]s\n\n[[category:arabic words and phrases]]</text> </page>	
<page> <title>abu_zayd</title><text>\'\'\'abu zayd\'\'\' could refer to:\n\n*[[ibn khaldun|abū zayd ‘abdu r-raḥman bin muḥammad bin khaldūn al-hadrami]] (1332&ndash;1406), arab polymath\n*[[abu zayd al-balkhi]] (b. 850), persian muslim polymath\n* abu zayd hassan, 9 c. merchant known for leaving an account on the [[guangzhou massacre]]\n*[[abu zayd al-hilali]], 11th-century arab leader\n*[[hunayn ibn ishaq|’abū zayd Ḥunayn ibn ’isḥāq al-‘ibādī]] (809&ndash;873), nestorian scholar, physician, and scientist\n*[[abū zayd ibn muḥammad ibn abī zayd]] (fl. 1186 - 1219), persian potter\n\n== modern era ==\n*[[abu zayd al-hilali (film)]], 1947 egyptian film about the 11th-century arab leader\n*[[abuzed omar dorda]] (b. 1944), libyan prime minister and permanent representative to the united nations\n*[[hikmat abu zayd]] (b. 1922), egyptian minister of social affairs and first female cabinet member\n* [[nasr abu zayd]], (b. 1943, d. 2010), an egyptian qur\'anic scholar persecuted for his liberal interpretation of islam\n*[[abu zaid al-kuwaiti]] (d. 2005), kuwaiti salafist jihad fighter and suspected al-qaeda agent\n\n{{disamb}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>abugida</title><text>{{use dmy dates|date=june 2013}}\n[[image:winnipeg forks - plains cree inscription.jpg|thumb|300px|an inscription of [[swampy cree language|swampy cree]] using [[canadian aboriginal syllabics]], an abugida developed by christian missionaries for aboriginal canadian languages]]\n{{indictextright}}\n{{contains canadian text}}\n{{contains ethiopic text}}\nan \'\'\'abugida\'\'\' {{ipac-en|ˌ|ɑː|b|uː|ˈ|ɡ|iː|d|ə}} (from [[ge\'ez language|ge‘ez]] አቡጊዳ \'\'’äbugida\'\'), also called an \'\'\'alphasyllabary\'\'\', is a [[writing systems#segmental writing system|segmental writing system]] in which consonant–vowel sequences are written as a unit: each unit is based on a [[consonant]] letter, and [[vowel]] notation is secondary. this contrasts with a full [[alphabet]], in which vowels have status equal to consonants, and with an [[abjad]], in which vowel marking is absent or optional. (in less formal contexts, all three types of script may commonly be termed as alphabets.) abugidas include the extensive [[brahmic family of scripts]] of south and southeast asia.\n\n\'\'abugida\'\' as a term in linguistics was proposed by [[peter t. daniels]] in his 1990 [[linguistic typology|typology]] of [[writing system]]s.<ref>{{citation|jstor=602899|title=fundamentals of grammatology|author=peter t. daniels|date=oct. - dec, 1990|volume=119|issue=4|pages=727–731 |journal=journal of the american oriental society |url=http://isites.harvard.edu/fs/docs/icb.topic129948.files/daniels.pdf}}</ref> \'\'’abugida\'\' is an ethiopian name for the [[ge\'ez alphabet|ge‘ez script]], taken from four letters of that script, \'\'’ä bu gi da\'\', in much the same way that \'\'[[abecedary]]\'\' is derived from latin \'\'a be ce de\'\', and \'\'[[alphabet]]\'\' is derived from the names of the two first letters in the greek alphabet, \'\'alpha\'\' and \'\'beta\'\'. as daniels used the word, an abugida is in contrast with a [[syllabary]], where let
<page> <title>abuhena_saifulislam</title><text>[[file:chaplainsaif bush.jpg|thumb|right| chaplain saifulislam shaking hands with president bush]]\n \n\'\'\'abuhena saifulislam\'\'\' (in [[u.s.]]  records) or \'\'\'abu hena saiful islam\'\'\', ({{lang-bn| আবু হেনা সাইফুল ইসলাম}}), (born 1963), a [[bangladesh]]i by birth, is the first [[muslim]] appointed as an [[imam]] [[military chaplain|chaplain]] in the [[united states military]].<ref>[http://www.dailynayadiganta.com/fullnews.asp?news_id=67031&sec=2 \"daily naya diganta\"] {{dead link|date=october 2012}}</ref> born in 1963, abu hena went to the usa in 1989 for [[higher education in the united states|higher studies]]. he studied at the [[southern new hampshire university]] and received his [[mba]] degree in 1992. that same year he joined the [[united states marine corps]]. earlier he had applied for immigration to america by participating in the [[dv lottery]]. he was granted us [[citizenship]] towards the end of 1995 while he was working in the [[u.s. navy]] in the payroll and accounting department.\n\nafter obtaining citizenship, saiful launched his drive to become an imam in the [[united states navy chaplain corps|navy chaplain corps]], which provides chaplains to the marine corps, a part of the department of the navy. saiful attended a course for muslim chaplains in the marine corps, organized jointly by the [[united states department of defense|defense department]] and the [[graduate school of islamic and social sciences]] in [[leesburg, virginia]]. he studied hard for two years to complete the course in time. in 1998, he took the opportunity of the process of recruiting navy chaplains and was commissioned in the same rank in 1999. after commissioning, the navy assigned him to the marines as the corps\' first muslim chaplain. in this position his main task is to teach about [[islam]] so that an understanding of the religion is built up across the us military. on his appointm
<page> <title>abul_khair_litu</title><text>{{orphan|date=june 2011}}\n\n\'\'\'abul khair litu \'\'\'(born october 7, 1950) is a prominent [[bangladesh|bangladeshi]] industrialist and entrepreneur.<ref>hossain, t. [http://www.thedailystar.net/story.php?nid=158195 “showcasing a staggering art collection”], “the daily star”, october 13, 2010, accessed june 3, 2011</ref> he is known for his involvement in the promotion of the country’s culture, art, music, theatre and literature.<ref name=anon>[http://www.bengalfoundation.org/index.php?view=aboutus.php “about us”] “bengal foundation website”, accessed june 3, 2011</ref>\n\n[[file:abul khair litu.jpg|thumb|right|alt=a abul khair litu.|abul khair litu]]\n\n== life and business ventures ==\n\nabul khair litu was born on october 7, 1950 in [[dhaka]], [[bangladesh]]. he obtained a bachelors degree in commerce from [[dhaka university]] in 1972. he went on to help establish ab bank, the country’s first private banking institution, in association with dubai bank. mr. abul khair is currently the chairman of the bengal group,<ref>rahman, s. [http://www.probenewsmagazine.com/index.php?index=2&contentid=4271 “art collectors and connoisseurs”], “probe news magazine”, accessed june 3, 2011</ref> a business house with interests in jute, cable television, electronic media, real estate, hospitality, media and advertising etc.<ref>[http://www.bengalgroup.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=204&itemid=83], “bengal group website”, accessed june 3, 2011]</ref>\n\n== bengal foundation ==\n\nabul khair’s interest in the art and culture of bangladesh was sparked off by his uncle - professor abdur razzaque, an eminent academic and social scientist. professor razzaque introduced abul to some of bangladesh’s most well-known artists, including shilpacharya [[zainul abedin]]. abul’s interaction with the artists whom he met through his uncle soon inspired him to start his own art collection. he boug

<page> <title>abulfaz_elchibey</title><text>{{use dmy dates|date=december 2012}}\n{{infobox president|name=abulfaz elchibey<br><small>Əbülfəz elçibəy</small>\n| nationality= [[azerbaijan]]i\n| image= [[file:abulfaz elchibey.jpg|175px]]\n| order= [[list of leaders of azerbaijan|2nd]]\n| office= president of azerbaijan\n| primeminister=[[rahim huseynov]] <br> [[ali masimov]] <br> \n[[panakh huseynov]]\n| term_start=16 june 1992\n| term_end=1 september 1993\n| predecessor=[[isa gambar]]\n| successor=[[heydar aliyev]]\n| birth_date={{birth date|1938|6|7|df=y}}\n| birth_place=[[nakhchivan assr]], [[azerbaijan ssr]], [[soviet union]]\n| death_date={{death date and age|2000|8|22|1938|6|24|df=y}}\n| death_place=[[ankara]], [[turkey]]\n| spouse=\n| party=[[azerbaijan popular front party|azerbaijan popular front]]\n| vicepresident=\n| religion=[[shia islam]]\n}}\n\n\'\'\'abulfaz elchibey\'\'\', ({{lang-az|Əbülfəz elçibəy}}; 24 june 1938, [[nakhchivan (city)|nakhchivan]] – 22 august 2000, [[ankara]])<ref>http://www.britannica.com/ebchecked/topic/182183/abulfaz-elchibey</ref> was an azerbaijani [[political figure]] and a former [[soviet union|soviet]] dissident. his real name was \'\'\'abulfaz qadirqulu oglu aliyev\'\'\' (azerbaijani: \'\'Əbülfəz qədirqulu oğlu Əliyev\'\'; {{lang-ru|Абульфа́з Гадиркули́ оглы́ Али́ев}}), but he assumed the nickname of \"elçibəy\" ([[azerbaijani language|azerbaijani]] for the \"\'\'noble messenger\'\'\") upon his leadership of the [[azerbaijani popular front]] in 1990. elchibey was the second president of azerbaijan, serving from 16 june 1992 until his overthrow in a [[coup d\'état]] in june 1993.\n\n== presidency ==\nelchibey\'s rise to presidency came after the first round of heavy losses of [[azerbaijan]] in the war against [[armenia]] over the [[nagorno-karabakh war|nagorno-karabakh]] region. after the [[khojaly massacre]] (26-27 february 1992), the fall of [[shusha]] (8 may 1992) and [[lachi

<page> <title>abuse_reporting_format</title><text>{{use dmy dates|date=april 2012}}\nthe \'\'\'abuse reporting format (arf)\'\'\' is a standard format for reporting spam via email.\n\n==history==\na draft describing a standard format for [[feedback loop (email)|feedback loop]] (fbl) reports was posted by [[yakov shafranovich]] in april 2005<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.shaftek.org/blog/2005/04/14/new-abuse-draft/ |title=new abuse draft |accessdate=17 november 2008 |author=yakov shafranovich |date=14 april 2005 |publisher=shaftek.org}}</ref> and evolved to the current rfc 5965.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.circleid.com/posts/20100901_arf_is_now_an_ietf_standard/ |title=\narf is now an ietf standard  |accessdate=12 september 2010 |author=[[john levine]] |date=1 september 2010 |publisher=circleid| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20100905001824/http://www.circleid.com/posts/20100901_arf_is_now_an_ietf_standard/| archivedate= 5 september 2010 <!--dashbot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[aol]], who pioneered the field in 2003, initially used a different format, and converted to this \'\'de facto\'\' standard in 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://postmaster-blog.aol.com/2008/06/27/aol-converting-all-fbls-to-arf-on-9-2-08/ |title=aol converting all fbls to arf on 9/2/08 |accessdate=17 november 2008 |author=christine borgia |date=27 june 2008 |publisher=aol| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081202002406/http://postmaster-blog.aol.com/2008/06/27/aol-converting-all-fbls-to-arf-on-9-2-08/| archivedate= 2 december 2008 <!--dashbot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> feedback loops don\'t \'\'have\'\' to use arf, but most do.\n\nin january 2010, the [[ietf]] chartered<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ietf.org/dyn/wg/charter/marf-charter.html |title=marf charter |accessdate=26 january 2010 |author=ietf}}</ref> a new working group working towards the goal of standardizing the arf format. the new wg is called messaging abuse reporting format wg or marf.\n\n==purpose==\nthe arf format is 
<page> <title>abzakh_people</title><text>{{distinguish|abkhaz people}}\n\'\'\'abzakhs\'\'\'/\'\'\'abadzekh\'\'\' ([[adyghe language|adyghe]]: абдзах, [[russian language|russian]]: абадзехи) are a people of [[adyghe people|adyghe]] branch. \n\na significant part of them live in [[diaspora]] in turkey - about 500 thousand people, which are descendants of refugees (\'\'[[muhajir (caucasus)|muhajir]]s\'\') from the [[caucasian war]] with the [[imperial russia|russian empire]]. their dominant religion is [[sunni islam]]. they were among the first muhajir, starting their exodus in 1879.\n==israel==\nabout 1,123 abzakhs live in the [[rehaniya]], in [[galilee]] ([[north district (israel)|north district]], [[israel]]).  rehaniya has an adyghe museum.\n\nin 1958, abzakhs (and other adyghe) of israel were allowed to enter military service, which gives a number of privileges.\n\n==language==\nthe abzakhs people speak the [[abzakh language]] ({{lang-ady|Абдзахэбзэ}}), a dialect of the [[adyghe language]].\n\n==history==\nbefore the caucasian war abzakhs inhabited the northern slope of the caucasus mountain range, near the land of the [[shapsug]]s. major settlements or villages were located in the river valleys kurdzhips, pchehe, pshish and psekups. they were divided into nine companies. geographically, they lived in the mountainous part of the modern adygea and krasnodar territory.\n\nafter the caucasian war, most abzakhs (and other circassians) were deported to the ottoman empire, the remaining abzakhs are relocated to the present-day steppe shovgenovsky district.\nabadzekhs, being the second most numerous tribe (the first was the [[shapsug]]s).\nwithout merging with other groups of circassians, retain their identity to the expulsion of the ottoman empire at the end of the caucasian war.\n\nthe tribe was divided into society, a society divided into communities, managed by elected elders. in discussing and resolving important issues elders agreed in a gen

<page> <title>acacia_dealbata</title><text>{{italic title}}\n{{taxobox\n|image = acacia dealbata-1.jpg\n|image_caption = foliage and flowers\n|regnum = [[plant]]ae\n|unranked_divisio = [[angiosperms]]\n|unranked_classis = [[eudicots]]\n|unranked_ordo = [[rosids]]\n|ordo = [[fabales]]\n|familia = [[fabaceae]]\n|genus = \'\'[[acacia]]\'\'\n|species = \'\'\'\'\'a. dealbata\'\'\'\'\'\n|binomial = \'\'acacia dealbata\'\'\n|binomial_authority = [[johann heinrich friedrich link|link]]<ref name=apni>{{cite web |url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/cgi-bin/apni?taxon_name=acacia+dealbata|title=\'\'acacia dealbata\'\' |accessdate=4 december 2012 |work= [[australian plant name index]] (apni), ibis database|publisher = centre for plant biodiversity research, australian government, canberra}}</ref>\n|}}\n\'\'\'\'\'acacia dealbata\'\'\'\'\' (known as \'\'\'silver wattle\'\'\' or \'\'\'blue wattle\'\'\'<ref name=\"s&s\">{{cite book|title=simon & schuster\'s guide to herbs and spices |editor=stanley schuler |isbn=0-671-73489-x |author=gualtiero simonetti |year=1990 |publisher=simon & schuster, inc}}</ref>) is a species of \'\'[[acacia]]\'\', [[native plant|native]] to southeastern australia in new south wales, victoria, tasmania, and the australian capital territory and widely introduced in mediterranean, warm temperate, and highland tropical landscapes.<ref name=anbg>australian plant name index: [http://www.anbg.gov.au/cgi-bin/apni?taxon_name=acacia%20dealbata%25 \'\'acacia dealbata\'\']</ref><ref name=kull2011>[http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1472-4642.2011.00783.x kull, c. a. et al. (2011)] adoption, use and perception of australian acacias around the world. diversity and distributions 17 (5):822-836.</ref>\n\n==description==\nit is a fast growing [[evergreen]] [[tree]] or [[shrub]] growing up to 30 m tall, typically a pioneer species after fire. the [[leaf|leaves]] are bipinnate, glaucous blue-green to silvery grey, 1–12&nbsp;cm (occasionally to 17&nbsp;cm) long and 1–11&nbsp;cm broad, w
<page> <title>acacia_robynsiana</title><text>{{taxobox\n|status = lr/nt\n|status_system = iucn2.3\n|regnum = [[plant]]ae\n|unranked_divisio = [[angiosperms]]\n|unranked_classis = [[eudicots]]\n|unranked_ordo = [[rosids]]\n|ordo = [[fabales]]\n|familia = [[fabaceae]]\n|genus = \'\'[[acacia]]\'\'\n|species = \'\'\'\'\'a. robynsiana\'\'\'\'\'\n|binomial = \'\'acacia robynsiana\'\'\n|binomial_authority = merxm. & a.schreib.\n|}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acacia robynsiana\'\'\'\'\' (\'\'\'whip stick acacia\'\'\') is a species of [[legume]] in the [[fabaceae]] family. it is found only in [[namibia]].\n\n==source==\n* hilton-taylor, c. & craven, p. 1998. <page> <title>acacia_stictophylla</title><text>{{taxobox\n|image = acacia stictophylla.jpg\n|image_caption = \'\'acacia stictophylla\'\', [[dandenong ranges]], victoria\n|regnum = [[plant]]ae\n|unranked_divisio = [[angiosperms]]\n|unranked_classis = [[eudicots]]\n|unranked_ordo = [[rosids]]\n|ordo = [[fabales]]\n|familia = [[fabaceae]]\n|genus = \'\'[[acacia]]\'\'\n|species = \'\'\'\'\' a. stictophylla\'\'\'\'\'\n|binomial = \'\'acacia stictophylla\'\'\n|binomial_authority = [[court]] ex [[maslin]] & [[d.j.murphy]]<ref name=apni>{{cite web |url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/cgi-bin/apni?taxon_name=acacia+stictophylla|title=\'\'acacia stictophylla\'\' |accessdate=2010-08-14 |work= [[australian plant name index]] (apni), ibis database|publisher = centre for plant biodiversity research, australian government, canberra}}</ref>\n|synonyms = *\'\'acacia leprosa\'\' (dandenong range variant) \n*\'\'acacia leprosa\'\' var. \'\'elongata\'\' <small>guilf. nom. inval.</small>\n*\'\'acacia leprosa\'\' var. reclinata <small>(b.r.maslin 5868) vic. herbarium </small>\n*\'\'acacia leprosa\'\' (second variant) </small>\n|}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acacia stictophylla\'\'\'\'\', also known as \'\'\'dandenong range cinnamon wattle\'\'\',  is a species of \'\'[[acacia]]\'\' that is [[endemism|endemic]] to [[victoria (australia)|victoria]], [[australia]].<ref name=apni/> the species was first formally described in the botanical journal \'\'[[muelleria (journal)|muelleria]]\'\' in 2009.<ref name=apni/> previous to this it was included in the species \'\'[[acacia leprosa]]\'\' and was often referred to as the \"[[dandenong ranges|dandenong range]] variant\".<ref name=apni/>\n\nthe dandenong range cinnamon wattle is listed as  \"rare in victoria\" on the department of sustainability and environment\'s \'\'advisory list of rare or threatened plants in victoria\'\'. <ref name=dse>{{cite web|title=advisory list of rare or threatened plants in victoria - 2005|publisher=department of sustainability and environme
<page> <title>acacia_terminalis</title><text>{{italic title}}\n{{taxobox\n|name = sunshine wattle\n|image = acacia_terminalis.jpg\n|regnum = [[plant]]ae\n|unranked_divisio = [[angiosperms]]\n|unranked_classis = [[eudicots]]\n|unranked_ordo = [[rosids]]\n|ordo = [[fabales]]\n|familia = [[fabaceae]]\n|genus = \'\'[[acacia]]\'\'\n|species = \'\'\'\'\'a. terminalis\'\'\'\'\'\n|binomial = \'\'acacia terminalis\'\'\n|binomial_authority = ([[salisb.]]) [[j.f. macbr.]]\n|}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acacia terminalis\'\'\'\'\' (\'\'\'sunshine wattle\'\'\') is a [[shrub]] or small [[tree]] to 6 m in height. it\'s an [[australia]]n native whose range extends through [[new south wales]], [[victoria (australia)|victoria]] and [[tasmania]].\n\nfour [[subspecies]] have been recognised, although there are additional hybrids, especially around sydney:\n* \'\'a. terminalis\'\' subsp. \'\'angustifolia\'\'\n* \'\'a. terminalis\'\' subsp. \'\'aurea\'\'\n* \'\'a. terminalis\'\' subsp. \'\'longiaxialis\'\'\n* \'\'a. terminalis\'\' subsp. \'\'terminalis\'\': listed as an [[endangered species]]. it is rare and confined to the eastern suburbs of [[sydney]],between cronulla and manly.\n[[image:acacia terminalis flower.jpg|thumb|left|200px]]\n==references==\n* [http://www.nationalparks.nsw.gov.au/npws.nsf/content/acacia+terminalis+a+shrub+-+endangered+species+listing acacia terminalis subsp. terminalis (a shrub) - endangered species listing]\n==external links==\n* [http://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/nswfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=acacia~terminalis nsw flora online]\n* [http://www.threatenedspecies.environment.nsw.gov.au/tsprofile/profile.aspx?id=10028 nsw threatened species]\n[[category:acacia|terminalis]]\n[[category:fabales of australia]]\n[[category:flora of new south wales]]\n[[category:flora of tasmania]]\n[[category:flora of victoria (australia)]]\n\n\n{{acacia-stub}}\n{{australia-rosid-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>academia_mexicana_de_la_lengua</title><text>{{refimprove|date=june 2010}}\nthe \'\'\'academia mexicana de la lengua\'\'\' (variously translated as the \'\'\'mexican academy of language\'\'\', the \'\'\'mexican academy of the language\'\'\', the \'\'\'mexican academy of letters\'\'\', or glossed as the \'\'\'mexican academy of the spanish language\'\'\'; acronym \'\'\'aml\'\'\') is the [[association of spanish language academies|correspondent academy]] in [[mexico]] of the [[real academia española|royal spanish academy]]. it was founded in [[mexico city]] on 11 september 1875 and, like the other academies, has the principal function of working to ensure the purity of the [[spanish language]]. its members have included many of the leading figures in mexican letters, including philologists, grammarians, philosophers, novelists, poets, historians and humanists. \n\nthe academia mexicana organized the first congress of the spanish language academies that was celebrated at [[mexico city]] in april 1951. this gave birth, through its permanent commission, to the association of spanish language academies, confirmed in the second congress, celebrated in [[madrid]] five years later.\n\n==objectives==\naccording to its statutes, approved in the plenay session of 2 december 1931, and what is disposed in the text of constitution as a civil association, from 1952, the objectives of the academy are as follows:\n\n# to watch over the conservation, the purity and the improvement of the spanish language.\n# to keep constant communication of scientific or literary nature with the similar academies and institutions.\n# to form and increase its library, especially with those scientific and literary works that best favor the achievements of the purposes of the academia.\n# to promote and propagate the study of the spanish language though periodic private sessions; public sessions and conferences; congresses and any other acts typical of the institute, being able to send del
<page> <title>academic_grading_in_denmark</title><text>{{danisheducation}}\n{{grading}}\nin \'\'\'[[denmark]]\'\'\', the [[education in denmark|educational system]] has historically used a number of different systems of \'\'\'[[grade (education)|grading]]\'\'\' student performances, several of which are described below. the current grading system is the \'\'7-trins-skala\'\' (7-step-scale) which replaced the \'\'13-skala\'\' in 2006.\n\n== current scale ==\nstarting with the academic year 2005-06, a new scale was introduced, \'\'7-trins-skalaen\'\' (\"7-step-scale\"; colloquially dubbed the \'\'12-scale\'\'), designed to be compatible with the [[ects grading scale|ects-scale]]:\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n!rowspan=\"2\"| grade\n!rowspan=\"2\" colspan=\"2\"| description<ref>{{cite web|title=bekendtgørelse om karakterskala og anden bedømmelse|url=https://www.retsinformation.dk/forms/r0710.aspx?id=25308#b2|work=retsinformation.dk|publisher=the danish department of civil affairs|author=danish ministry of education|language=danish}}</ref>\n!colspan=\"3\"| equivalents\n|-\n! 13-scale\n! ects\n! u.s.\n|-\n! 12 \n| \'\'excellent\'\'\n| high level of command of all aspects &ndash; no or only a few minor weaknesses<ref group=\"n\">\"12: for an excellent performance displaying a high level of command of all aspects of the relevant material, with no or only a few minor weaknesses.\"</ref>\n| align=\"center\" | 11/13\n| align=\"center\" | a\n| align=\"center\" | a+, a\n|-\n! 10 \n| \'\'very good\'\'\n| high level of command of most aspects &ndash; only minor weaknesses<ref group=\"n\">\"10: for a very good performance displaying a high level of command of most aspects of the relevant material, with only minor weaknesses.\"</ref>\n| align=\"center\" | 10\n| align=\"center\" | b\n| align=\"center\" | a-, b+\n|-\n! {{0}}7 \n| \'\'good\'\'\n| good command &ndash; some weaknesses<ref group=\"n\">\"7: for a good performance displaying good command of the relevant material but als
<page> <title>academic_grading_in_israel</title><text>{{grading}}\n\'\'\'academic grading in israel\'\'\' refers to the main [[grade (education)|grading scale]] used in [[israel]]i schools. the scale, from 0 to 100, is employed at virtually all levels of [[education in israel]], from elementary school, through high school and undergraduate academic studies, to graduate university degrees.\n\nthe 100-point grading scale is as follows:\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! percentage !! description\n|-\n| 95–100 || {{rtl-lang|he|מצוין}} (excellent)\n|-\n| 85–94 || {{rtl-lang|he|טוב מאוד}} (very good)\n|-\n| 75–84 || {{rtl-lang|he|טוב}} (good)\n|-\n| 65–74 || {{rtl-lang|he|כמעט טוב}} (almost good)\n|-\n| 55–64 || {{rtl-lang|he|מספיק}} (sufficient)\n|-\n| 45–54 || {{rtl-lang|he|מספיק בקושי}} (barely sufficient)\n|-\n|   <44 || {{rtl-lang|he|בלתי מספיק/נכשל}} (insufficient/failed)\n|}\n\nin secondary school (years 7–12), any grade below 55 is considered a failing grade. in the [[bagrut examination]]s, any grade below 55 equals failure. in most universities{{cn|date=february 2013}}{{dubious|date=february 2013}} and colleges, any grade below 60 is considered as failure.\n\nin israeli academic institutions, [[latin honors|honors]] are bestowed upon graduates with 88 or better, with \'\'summa cum laude\'\' associated with a grade of 95 or higher.\n\nit may be worth mentioning that the israeli education system rarely employs curved grading at any stage (including at the academic level). to compensate for this, most academic institutions require that candidates undergo the [[psychometric entrance test]], which in israel provides examinees with an overall score of 200–800, the average being 535.<ref>[http://www.nite.org.il national institute of scoring and evaluation]\'s report of 2005.</ref>\n\n==law school grading==\nalthough the vast majority of israeli academic institutions refrain from grading on a curve, the situa

<page> <title>academy_of_performing_arts_in_sarajevo</title><text>{{infobox university\n|image_name = \n|name = academy of performing arts in sarajevo\n|established = 1981\n|type = [[faculty (division)|faculty]]\n|dean= [[zijad mehić]]\n|city = [[sarajevo]]\n|state = \n|country = [[bosnia and herzegovina]]\n|students = \n|staff= 30\n|campus = [[urban area|urban]]\n|website= [http://www.asu.unsa.ba/ www.asu.unsa.ba]\n|endowment= \n}}\n\'\'\'academy of performing arts in sarajevo\'\'\' (\'\'local: akademija scenskih umjentosti sarajevo\'\') is a faculty within the [[university of sarajevo]] in [[sarajevo]], [[bosnia and herzegovina]], dedicated to the [[performing arts]].<ref>[http://www.detail.de/artikel_archipelagos-academy-of-performing-arts-sarajevo_22467_en.htm/ detail.de: \'\'academy of performing arts in sarajevo\'\'(in bosnian) &#91;cited february 21, 2012&#93;]</ref> \n\nthe academy of performing arts in sarajevo was officially opened in 1981 with the inaugural department of [[acting]]. this was followed by the opening of the department of [[theatre director|directing]] in 1989, the department of [[dramaturgy]] in 1994 and the department of [[production]] in 2010 .<ref>http://www.asu.unsa.ba/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=105&itemid=160&lang=hr</ref> \n\nan important segment of the academy\'s practice is its cooperation with the open stage \"obala\", a prominent sarajevo theater, where students present their works along with professional actors, directors and writers.\n\nthe need for the [[academy for performing arts]] arose because, according to data from the year 1981, bosnia and herzegovina theaters had around 180 employees of which only 24 had the appropriate academic qualifications. therefore it was decided to establish academy for performing arts in sarajevo which was open for students from bosnia and herzegovina and other republics of [[former yugoslavia]]. academy of performing arts officially started working on december 2, 1981.<ref>[h
<page> <title>acadia</title><text>{{about|the land in north america}}\n{{redirect|l\'acadie|the canadian wine grape|l\'acadie blanc}}\n{{use mdy dates|date=june 2013}}\n\n{{infobox former subdivision\n|native_name = \'\'acadie\'\'\n|conventional_long_name = acadia\n|common_name = acadia\n|subdivision = division\n|nation = new france\n|image_flag = pavillon louisxiv.svg\n|image_coat =\n|image_map = acadia 1754.png\n|image_map_caption = acadia (1754)\n|national_anthem=\n|capital = principally [[port royal, annapolis county, nova scotia|port-royal]]\n|stat_area1=\n|stat_year1 =\n|stat_pop1 =\n|p1=\n|image_p1 =\n|s1 = nova scotia\n|flag_s1 = union flag 1606 (kings colors).svg\n|year_start = 1604\n|event_end = [[treaty of utrecht|british conquest]]\n|year_end = 1713\n|political_subdiv =\n}}\n\n\'\'\'acadia\'\'\' ({{lang-fr|link=no|acadie}}) was a [[colony]] of [[new france]] in northeastern [[north america]] that included parts of eastern [[quebec]], the [[maritimes|maritime provinces]], and modern-day [[maine]] to the [[kennebec river]].<ref name=\"william williamson 1832. p. 27\">william williamson. the history of the state of maine. vol. 2. 1832. p. 27; p. 266 (la corne declares such to lawrence in 1750); p. 293</ref> during much of the 17th and early 18th centuries, [[norridgewock]] on the kennebec river and [[castine, maine|castine]] at the end of the [[penobscot river]] were the southern-most settlements of acadia.<ref>griffiths, e. from migrant to acadian. mcgill-queen\'s university press. 2005. p.61; john ried. international region of the northeast. in buckner, campbell, and frank (eds). the acadiensis reader: volume one: atlantic canada before confederation. 1998. p. 40</ref>  the actual specification by the french government for the territory refers to lands bordering the [[atlantic ocean|atlantic]] coast, roughly between the [[40th parallel north|40th]] and [[46th parallel north|46th parallels]]. later, the territory was divided into the british colonies which
<page> <title>acadian_house_museum</title><text>{{infobox building\n|name=acadian house museum\n|location=79 hill rd,<br/> [[west chezzetcook, nova scotia|west chezzetcook]], [[nova scotia]]\n|location_country = [[canada]]\n}}\n\n\'\'\'acadian house museum\'\'\' is a [[museum]] in [[west chezzetcook, nova scotia]], [[canada]]. it opened in 1997 and is both a [[living museum|living]] and interpretive museum.<ref>[http://www.museevirtuel-virtualmuseum.ca/getmuseumprofile.do?lang=en&chincode=guaeli acadian house museum], [[virtual museum of canada]].</ref> the house is believed to have been built in 1850 by joseph bellefontaine. it passed through seven different owners before coming into the hands of the west chezzetcook & grand desert community interest group, who then converted the house into a museum.\n\n==history of the house==\nthe acadian house was built in 1850 by joseph bellefontaine, who left the house to his wife, céleste (bonnevie) bellefontaine upon his death in 1897. céleste then passed the house to her brothers, georges and oliver bonnevie. georges\' daughter, jenny, bought the house from her father and uncle in 1919. jenny and her husband ran a small store from the side porch from 1919 until 1946. in 1946, jenny passed the house on to james redmond, who was a distant relative. in 1960, eugène bellefontaine bought the house, and then passed it on to his son, benjamin bellefontaine, in 1973. the west chezzetcook & grand desert community interest group bought the house from benjamin in 1997, converting it into a museum and officially opening in 2000.\n\n==museum==\nvery little renovation has been done to the house since it was purchased in 1997. the upstairs, which was unfinished, was finished to be used as storage for artifacts. ceilings and floors have been redone, all under the advice of a consultant\'s report and the research of a local historian. fortunately, the layout of the house remains untouched.\n\nthe museum is a combination living and interp
<page> <title>acaena_rorida</title><text>{{italic title}}\n{{taxobox\n|name = \'\'acaena rorida\'\'\n|regnum = [[plant]]ae\n|unranked_divisio = [[angiosperms]]\n|unranked_classis = [[eudicots]]\n|unranked_ordo = [[rosids]]\n|ordo = [[rosales]]\n|familia = [[rosaceae]]\n|genus = \'\'[[acaena]]\'\'\n|species = \'\'\'\'\'a. rorida\'\'\'\'\'\n|binomial = \'\'acaena rorida\'\'\n|binomial_authority = [[bryony macmillan|macmillan]]\n|}}\n\'\'\'\'\'acaena rorida\'\'\'\'\' is a species of mat-forming [[perennial plant]] known only from grassy uplands on the [[mangaohane plateau]] in the northwestern part of the [[ruahine range]] on  [[north island]], [[new zealand]].\n\nwithin its range, this plant occurs in areas with moist, stable soils such as in hollows in tussocklands and the floors of ravines. it can be distinguished from its closest congeners by the purple or dull green (rather than bright green) foliage and the [[sessility (botany)|sessile]] [[fruit]]s which are often hidden among the leaves rather than being borne above. [[flower]]ing occurs in december and january with fruit being produced in february.\n\n==references==\n*{{cite journal |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/0028825x.1991.10416716 |title=\'\'acaena rorida\'\' and \'\'acaena tesca\'\' (rosaceae) - two new species from new zealand |journal=[[new zealand journal of botany]] |volume=29 |year=1991 |author=b. h. macmillan |pages=131–138}}\n[[category:acaena|rorida]]\n[[category:flora of new zealand]]\n[[category:plants described in 1991]]\n\n{{rosales-stub}}\n{{newzealand-plant-stub}}</text> </page>

<page> <title>acallistus</title><text>{{italic title}}\n{{taxobox\n| name = \'\'acallistus\'\'\n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| classis = [[insect]]a\n| ordo = [[beetle|coleoptera]]\n| subordo = [[adephaga]]\n| familia = [[carabidae]]\n| genus = \'\'\'\'\'acallistus\'\'\'\'\'\n| genus_authority = sharp, 1886\n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acallistus\'\'\'\'\' is a genus of [[beetle]]s in the family [[carabidae]], containing the following species:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://carabidae.org/carabidae/acallistus-sharp-1886.html |title=\'\'acallistus\'\' sharp, 1886 |date=2011 |work=carabidae of the world |accessdate=24 jun 2011}}</ref>\n\n* \'\'[[acallistus cuprescens]]\'\' <small>(sloane, 1920)</small>\n* \'\'[[acallistus longus]]\'\' <small>(sloane, 1920)</small>\n* \'\'[[acallistus plebius]]\'\' <small>(sloane, 1920)</small>\n* \'\'[[acallistus tasmanicus]]\'\' <small>(castelnau, 1867)</small>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n[[category:broscinae]]\n{{broscinae-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>acantharctia_vittata</title><text>{{taxobox\n| image = \n| image_width = 230px\n| image_caption = \n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| classis = [[insect]]a\n| ordo = [[lepidoptera]]\n| familia = [[arctiidae]]\n| subfamilia = \n| tribus = \n| genus = \'\'[[acantharctia]]\'\'\n| species = \'\'\'\'\'a. vittata\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'acantharctia vittata\'\'\n| binomial_authority = aurivillius, 1899\n| synonyms =\n}}\n\'\'\'\'\'acantharctia vittata\'\'\'\'\' is a [[moth]] of the [[arctiidae]] family. it was described by aurivillius in 1899. it is found in [[botswana]] and [[south africa]].<ref>[http://www.afromoths.net/species/show/25700 afro moths]</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n[[category:animals described in 1899]]\n[[category:arctiidae]]\n\n{{arctiidae-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>acanthocyclops</title><text>{{italic title}}{{taxobox\n| name = \'\'acanthocyclops\'\'\n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| subphylum = [[crustacean|crustacea]]\n| classis = [[maxillopoda]]\n| subclassis = [[copepod]]a\n| ordo = [[cyclopoida]]\n| familia = [[cyclopidae]]\n| genus = \'\'\'\'\'acanthocyclops\'\'\'\'\'\n| genus_authority = [[friedrich kiefer|kiefer]], 1927\n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acanthocyclops\'\'\'\'\' is a [[genus]] of [[copepod]] [[crustacean]]s in the [[family (biology)|family]] [[cyclopidae]].<ref name=\"worms\">{{cite web |author=worms |year=2010 |title=\'\'acanthocyclops\'\' kiefer, 1927 |editor=t. c. walter & g. boxshall |work=world copepoda database |publisher=[[world register of marine species]] |url=http://www.marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id=149771 |accessdate=april 14, 2010}}</ref> it was originally described by [[friedrich kiefer]] as a [[subgenus]] of \'\'[[cyclops (genus)|cyclops]]\'\',<ref>{{cite book |author=mary d. balcer, nancy l. korda & stanley i. dodson |year=1984 |title=zooplankton of the great lakes: a guide to the identification and ecology of the common crustacean species |publisher=[[university of wisconsin press]] |isbn=978-0-299-09820-9 |chapter=cyclopoid copepods |pages=93–103 |url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=fqmps5xupaac&pg=pa93}}</ref> and contains the following species:<ref name=\"worms\"/>\n{{div col|colwidth=24em}}\n*\'\'[[acanthocyclops abyssicola]]\'\' <small>(lilljeborg, 1901)</small>\n*\'\'[[acanthocyclops agamus]]\'\' <small>kiefer, 1938</small>\n*\'\'[[acanthocyclops alticola]]\'\' <small>(kiefer, 1935)</small>\n*\'\'[[acanthocyclops americanus]]\'\' <small>(marsh, 1893)</small>\n*\'\'[[acanthocyclops arenosus]]\'\' <small>mazepova, 1950</small>\n*\'\'[[acanthocyclops balcanicus]]\'\' <small>naidenov & pandourski, 1992</small>\n*\'\'[[acanthocyclops biarticulatus]]\'\' <small>monchenko, 1972</small>\n*\'\'[[acanthocyclops bicuspidatus]]\'\' <small>(claus, 1857)</sma
<page> <title>acanthogobius</title><text>{{italic title}}{{taxobox\n| name = \'\'acanthogobius\'\'\n| image = mahaze0811.jpg\n| image_caption = yellowfin goby \'\'(a. flavimanus)\'\'\n| domain = [[eukaryota]]\n| regnum = [[animalia]]\n| phylum = [[chordata]]\n| classis = [[actinopterygii]]\n| ordo = [[perciformes]]\n| subordo = [[gobioidei]]\n| familia = [[gobiidae]]\n| subfamilia = [[gobionellinae]]\n| genus = \'\'\'\'\'acanthogobius\'\'\'\'\'\n| genus_authority = [[theodore nicholas gill|t. n. gill]], 1859\n| type_species = \'\'gobius flavimanus\'\'\n| type_species_authority = temminck & schlegel, 1845\n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acanthogobius\'\'\'\'\' is a genus of [[gobies]] native to marine, fresh and brackish waters of eastern [[asia]].\n\n==species==\nthere are currently three recognized species in this genus:<ref>{{fishbase genus | genus = acanthogobius| month = april | year = 2013}}</ref>\n* \'\'[[acanthogobius flavimanus]]\'\' <small>([[coenraad jacob temminck|temminck]] & [[hermann schlegel|schlegel]], 1845)</small> (yellowfin goby)\n* \'\'[[acanthogobius lactipes]]\'\' <small>([[franz martin hilgendorf|hilgendorf]], 1879)</small>\n* \'\'[[acanthogobius luridus]]\'\' <small>[[ni yong|y. ni]] & [[wu han-ling|h. l. wu]], 1985</small>\n\n== references ==\n{{reflist}}\n\n[[category:gobionellinae]]\n\n{{gobiidae-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>acantholepis</title><text>{{taxobox\n|image = \n|image_caption = \n|regnum = [[plantae]]\n|unranked_divisio = [[angiosperms]]\n|unranked_classis = [[eudicots]]\n|unranked_ordo = [[asterids]]\n|ordo = [[asterales]]\n|familia = [[asteraceae]]\n|genus = \'\'\'\'\'acantholepis\'\'\'\'\'\n|genus_authority = lessing\n|type_species = \'\'acantholepis orientalis\'\'\n|type_species_authority = lessing \n|subdivision_ranks = species\n|subdivision = \n|}}\n\'\'\'\'\'acantholepis\'\'\'\'\' is a [[genus]] of flowering plants in the [[asteraceae|daisy family]].\n\n[[category:asteraceae genera]]\n\n{{asteraceae-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>acanthoodes</title><text>{{italic title}}\n{{taxobox\n| name = \'\'acanthoodes centrosternis\'\'\n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| classis = [[insect]]a\n| ordo = [[beetle|coleoptera]]\n| subordo = [[adephaga]]\n| familia = [[carabidae]]\n| genus = \'\'\'\'\'acanthoodes\'\'\'\'\'\n| genus_authority = basilewsky, 1953\n| species = \'\'\'\'\'a. centrosternis\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'acanthoodes centrosternis\'\'\n| binomial_authority = (chaudoir, 1882)\n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acanthoodes centrosternis\'\'\'\'\' is a species of [[beetle]] in the family [[carabidae]], the only species in the genus \'\'\'\'\'acanthoodes\'\'\'\'\'.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://carabidae.pro/carabidae/acanthoodes-basilewsky-1953.html |title=\'\'acanthoodes\'\' basilewsky, 1953 |date=2011 |work=carabidae of the world |accessdate=19 jul 2011}}</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n[[category:licininae]]\n[[category:monotypic arthropod genera]]\n\n\n{{licininae-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>acanthopholis</title><text>{{italic title}}\n{{taxobox\n| name = \'\'acanthopholis\'\'\n| fossil range = early [[cretaceous]]\n| image = acanthopholis suposed.jpg\n| image_width = 200px\n| image_caption = artist\'s rendering of \'\'acanthopholis\'\'\n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[chordate|chordata]]\n| classis = [[reptile|sauropsida]]\n| superordo = [[dinosaur]]ia\n| ordo = [[ornithischia]]\n| subordo = [[thyreophora]]\n| infraordo = [[ankylosauria]] \n| familia = [[nodosauridae]]\n| genus = \'\'\'\'\'acanthopholis\'\'\'\'\'\n|genus_authority=[[thomas huxley|huxley]], 1867\n|subdivision_ranks=[[species]]\n|subdivision=\n*\'\'a. horrida\'\' <small>huxley, 1867 ([[type species|type]])</small>\n}}\n\'\'\'\'\'acanthopholis\'\'\'\'\' ({{ipac-en|ˌ|æ|k|ən|ˈ|θ|ɒ|f|ɵ|l|ɨ|s}}; meaning \"spiny scales\") is a [[genus]] of [[ankylosaurian]] [[dinosaur]] in the family [[nodosauridae]] that lived during the early [[cretaceous]] [[period (geology)|period]]  of [[england]].\n\n==history==\naround 1865 commercial fossil collector [[john griffiths (fossil collector)|john griffiths]] found some dinosaurian remains, including [[osteoderm]]s, at the shoreline near [[folkestone]] in [[kent]], which he sold to the [[metallurgist]] dr. [[john percy (metallurgist)|john percy]]. percy brought them to the attention of [[thomas henry huxley]], who paid griffiths to dig up all fossils he could find at the site. despite being hampered by the fact that it was located between the tidemarks, he managed to uncover several additional bones and parts of the body armour.\n\nin 1867 huxley named the genus and species \'\'acanthopholis horridus\'\'.<ref>huxley, t.h., 1867, \"on \'\'acanthopholis horridus\'\', a new reptile from the chalk-marl\", \'\'geological magazine\'\', \'\'\'4\'\'\': 65-67</ref> the dinosaur\'s generic name refers to its [[armour (zoology)|armour]], being derived from [[ancient greek|greek]] ακανθα \'\'akantha\'\' meaning \'spine\' or \'thorn\' and
<page> <title>acanthopleuroceras</title><text>{{italic title}}\n{{unreferenced|date=march 2007}}\n{{taxobox\n|name = \'\'acanthopleuroceras\'\'\n|status = fossil\n|fossil_range =\n|regnum = [[animal]]ia\n|phylum = [[mollusc]]a\n|classis = [[cephalopod]]a\n|subclassis = [[ammonoidea]]\n|genus = \'\'\'\'\'acanthopleuroceras\'\'\'\'\'\n| genus_authority =\n|subdivision_ranks =\n|subdivision =\n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acanthopleuroceras\'\'\'\'\' is an extinct genus of cephalopod belonging to the [[ammonite]] subclass.\n\n[[category:ammonites]]</text> </page>	
<page> <title>acantopsis_octoactinotos</title><text>{{italic title}}\n{{portal|aquarium fish}}\n{{taxobox\n| image =\n| image_caption =\n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[chordata]]\n| classis = [[osteichthyes]]\n| ordo = [[cypriniformes]]\n| familia = [[cobitidae]]\n| genus = [[acantopsis]]\n| species = \'\'\'a. octoactinotos\'\'\'\n| binomial = acantopsis octoactinotos\n| binomial_authority = [[darrell j. siebert|siebert]], 1991\n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acantopsis octoactinotos\'\'\'\'\' or the \'\'\'long-nosed loach\'\'\' is a freshwater fish from [[indonesia]], commonly found in aquariums.<ref name=\"long\">{{cite web | url=  http://www.loaches.com/species-index/acantopsis-octoactinotos | title = \'\'acantopsis octoactinotos\'\' | author = martin thoene | date = november 14, 2006 | publisher = loaches online - community edition | accessdate = april 27, 2009 | archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090425180539/http://www.loaches.com/species-index/acantopsis-octoactinotos| archivedate= 25 april 2009 <!--dashbot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>\n\n\'\'acantopsis octoactinotos\'\' has a long straight snout, unlike the similar [[horseface loach]] (\'\'acantopsis choirorhynchus\'\'), in which the snout has a down-turned shape.<ref name=\"long\" /> the long-nosed loach reaches {{convert|4.5|in}} in length, males typically being smaller and slenderer than females.<ref name=\"long\" />\n\n==references==\n<references/>\n\n==external links==\n* [http://www.loaches.com/species-index/acantopsis-octoactinotos loaches online - community edition: \'\'acantopsis octoactinotos\'\']\n\n{{defaultsort:acantopsis octoactinotos}}\n[[category:cobitidae]]</text> </page>

<page> <title>acca_larentia</title><text>\'\'\'acca larentia\'\'\' or \'\'\'acca larentina\'\'\' was a mythical woman, later goddess, in [[roman mythology]] whose festival, the [[larentalia]], was celebrated on december 23.\n\n==foster mother==\nin one mythological tradition (that of [[licinius macer]], et al.), she was the wife of the shepherd [[faustulus]], and therefore the adoptive mother of [[romulus and remus]], whom she is said to have saved after they were thrown into the [[tiber]] on the orders of [[amulius]].  she had twelve sons, and on the death of one of them romulus took his place, and with the remaining eleven founded the college of the arval brothers ([[fratres arvales]]).<ref>according to [[massurius sabinus]] in [[aulus gellius]] (i. c.)</ref>  she is therefore identified with the [[dea dia]] of that collegium. the [[flamen]] [[quirinalis]] acted in the role of [[romulus]] (deified as [[quirinus]]) to perform funerary rites for his foster mother.<ref>[[licinius macer|macer]], apud macrob. i.e.; [[ovid]] fast. iii. 55, &c. ; plin. pi. n. xviii. 2</ref>\n\n==benefactor of rome==\nanother tradition holds that larentia was a beautiful girl of notorious reputation, roughly the same age as [[romulus and remus]], during the reign of [[ancus marcius]] in the 7th century bc.  she was awarded to [[hercules]] as a prize in a game of dice by the guardian of his temple, and locked in it with his other prize, a feast.  when the god no longer had need of her, he advised her to marry the first man she met as she stepped out that morning, who turned out to be a wealthy etruscan named carutius (or [[tarutius|tarrutius]], according to [[plutarch]]).  larentia later inherited all his property and bequeathed it to the roman people.  ancus, in gratitude for this, allowed her to be buried in the [[velabrum]], and instituted an annual festival, the [[larentalia]], at which sacrifices were offered to the [[lares (roman deities)|lares]].<ref>compare varro, \'\'de lingua lat
<page> <title>accademia_musicale_chigiana</title><text>{{refimprove|date=january 2009}}\nthe \'\'\'accademia musicale chigiana\'\'\' (\'\'english\'\': chigiana musical academy) is a music institute in [[siena]], [[italy]].<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.chigiana.it/default.aspx?idpagina=home&livello=0| title = accademia musicale chigiana | accessdate = 9 march 2011}}</ref> it was founded by count guido chigi saracini in 1932 as an international centre for advanced musical studies. it organises master classes in the major musical instruments as well as singing, conducting and composition. during the summer months a series of concerts are held under the title of \'\'estate musicale chigiana\'\'. \n\nin 1983 the accademia musicale chigiana, fulvia casella nicolodi and guido turchi created an international composition competition named after [[alfredo casella]], for the one hundredth anniversary of his birth. the international \'\'accademia musicale chigiana prize\'\' has been assigned, and among the winners’ names are some of the most famous ones in international concert circles: the violinists [[gidon kremer]] (1982), [[shlomo mintz]] (1984), [[anne-sophie mutter]] (1986), [[viktoria mullova]] (1988), [[frank peter zimmermann]] (1990), [[gil shaham]] (1992), [[maxim vengerov]] (1995), [[julian rachlin]] (2000), [[hilary hahn]] (2002) and [[sarah chang]] (2005), the pianists [[peter serkin]] (1983), [[krystian zimerman]] (1985), [[andras schiff]] (1987), [[andrei gavrilov]] (1989), [[evgeny kissin]] (1991), [[andrea lucchesini]] (1994), [[lilya zilberstein]] (1998), [[leif ove andsnes]] (2001) and [[arcadi volodos]] (2003), as well as the orchestral conductor [[esa-pekka salonen]] (1993), the [[hagen quartet]] (1996) and the [[artemis quartet]] (2004), the violist [[tabea zimmermann]] (1997) and the violoncellist [[matt haimovitz]] (1999). these names join the history of the accademia chigiana, already studded with illustrious presences. in (2006) the prize has bee

<page> <title>acceptable_daily_intake</title><text>\'\'\'acceptable daily intake\'\'\' or \'\'\'adi\'\'\' is a measure of the amount of a specific substance (originally applied for a [[food additive]], later also for a residue of a veterinary drug or pesticide) in [[food]] or [[drinking water]] that can be ingested (orally) on a daily basis over a lifetime without an appreciable health risk.<ref name=who1987>{{cite journal | last = who | title = principles for the safety assessment of food additives and contaminants in food | journal = environmental health criteria 70. | year = 1987 | url = http://www.inchem.org/documents/ehc/ehc/ehc70.htm | postscript = <!-- bot inserted parameter. either remove it; or change its value to \".\" for the cite to end in a \".\", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> adis are expressed usually in milligrams (of the substance) per kilograms of body weight per day.<ref name=\"lu\">{{cite book|last=lu|first=frank c. |coauthors=sam kacew|title=lu\'s basic toxicology: fundamentals, target organs and risk assessment|publisher=taylor & francis|year=2002|isbn=0-415-24855-8|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9vczmebxtscc&pg=pa364&dq=%22acceptable+daily+intake%22|page=364}}</ref><ref name=faustman>{{cite book |last1=faustman |first1=elaine m. |last2=omenn |first2=gilbert s. |chapter=risk assessment |editor1-first=curtis d. |editor1-last=klaassen |title=casarett & doull\'s toxicology: the basic science of poisons |edition=6th |publisher=mcgraw-hill |location=new york |year=2001 |pages=92–4 |isbn=978-0-07-134721-1}}</ref>\n\n== history ==\nthis concept was first introduced in 1961 by the [[council of europe]] and later, the [[joint fao/who expert committee on food additives]] (jecfa), a committee maintained by two united nations bodies: the [[food and agriculture organization]] (fao) and the [[world health organization]] (who).<ref name=\"lu\" />\n\n== concept ==\nan adi value is based on current research, with long-term studies 
<page> <title>access_linux_platform</title><text>{{update|date=november 2010}}\nthe \'\'\'access linux platform\'\'\' (alp), once referred to as a \"next-generation version of the [[palm os]]\" is an open source-based [[operating system]] for mobile devices developed and marketed by [[access co.]], of [[tokyo]], [[japan]]. the platform includes execution environments for [[java (programming language)|java]], classic palm os, and [[gtk+]]-based native [[linux]] applications. alp has been demonstrated in devices<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.linuxdevices.com/news/ns9247878814.html|title=reference design targets linux mobile phones|archiveurl=http://archive.is/8f2dc|archivedate=2013-01-03}}, linuxdevices.com, august 7, 2007.</ref> at a variety of conferences, including [[3gsm]],<ref>[http://www.engadget.com/2007/02/12/access-linux-platform-on-display-at-3gsm/ access linux platform on display at 3gsm], [[engadget]], february 12, 2007.</ref> [[linuxworld conference and expo|linuxworld]],<ref>[http://www.palminfocenter.com/news/8921/access-linux-platform-at-linuxworld-sf/ access linux platform at linuxworld sf], palminfocenter.com, august 20, 2006.</ref> [[guadec]], and open source in mobile.\n\nthe access linux platform was first announced in february 2006.<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20130901134714/http://www.access-company.com/ access and palmsource announce the access linux platform], [[access co.|access]]/[[palmsource]] [[press release]], february 14, 2006.</ref> the initial versions of the platform and software development kits for the access linux platform were officially released in february 2007.<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20130901134714/http://www.access-company.com/ access releases access linux platform pdk and sdk to licensees and developers], [[access co.|access]] [[press release]], february 12, 2007.</ref> as of february 2009, the access linux platform has yet to ship on devices, however development kits exist and public demonstrations have been sho
<page> <title>access_magazine</title><text>{{infobox magazine\n | title          = access magazine\n | image_file     = access magazine cover.jpg\n | image_size = 200px\n | image_caption = \n | editor         = donald shoup (editor in chief)\n                    john a. mathews (managing editor)\n | frequency      = biannual\n | category       = transportation, urban planning\n | company        = uctc\n | firstdate      = 1990\n | country        = united states\n | language       = [[english language|english]]\n | website        = [http://www.uctc.net/access access website]\n}}\n\'\'\'\'\'access magazine\'\'\'\'\' publishes research at the university of california transportation center. its goal is to translate academic writing into readable prose that is useful for policymakers and practitioners. articles in access are intended to catapult academic research into debates about public policy, and convert knowledge into action. \n\naccess was founded in 1992 by melvin webber, professor of city and regional planning at the university of california, berkeley, and has grown to become one of the most widely read publications of transportation research. {{as of|2013}}, the magazine has over 8,500 subscribers.  \n\naccess is regularly referenced, reprinted, and translated inpublications, including:  \n* [http://www.aialosangeles.org american institute of architects, los angeles chapter] \n* [https://asunews.asu.edu/20120117_chesterparkingcosts asu news] \n* atlantic cities group ([http://www.theatlanticcities.com/commute/2013/01/case-against-one-way-streets/4549/ 2012], [http://www.theatlanticcities.com/commute/2013/06/seriously-we-have-stop-giving-away-free-parking-disabled/5946/ 2013]) \n* [http://www.austincontrarian.com/austincontrarian/2012/05/the-coming-robocar-apocalypse.html austin contrarian] \n* [http://www.beagreencommuter.com/?p=9161 be a green commuter] \n* [http://www.bikewalk.org/centerlines/centerlines2012/cl_issue_297.htm bikewalk centerlines newsl
<page> <title>access_modifiers</title><text>{{refimprove|date=march 2013}}\n\n\'\'\'access modifiers\'\'\' (or \'\'\'access specifiers\'\'\') are [[keywords]] in [[object-oriented language]]s that set the accessibility of classes, methods, and other members. access modifiers are a specific part of programming language syntax used to facilitate the [[encapsulation (object-oriented programming)|encapsulation]] of components.{{sfn|mayo|2002|pp=199}}\n\nin [[c++]] are only three access modifiers. [[c sharp (programming language)|c#]] extends the number of them to five, while [[java (programming language)|java]] has four access modifiers,<ref>http://javapapers.com/core-java/access-modifiers-in-java-explain/</ref> but three keywords for this purpose. having no keyword before defaults to the package private modifier.\n\n== names of keywords ==\nc++ uses the three modifiers called \'\'<code>public</code>\'\', \'\'<code>protected</code>\'\', and \'\'<code>private</code>\'\'. [[c sharp (programming language)|c#]] has the modifiers \'\'<code>public</code>\'\', \'\'<code>internal</code>\'\', \'\'<code>protected</code>\'\', \'\'<code> private</code>\'\', and \'\'<code>protected internal</code>\'\'. [[java (programming language)|java]] has \'\'<code>public</code>\'\', \'\'package\'\', \'\'<code>protected</code>\'\', and \'\'<code>private</code>\'\'. the access modifier \"package\" is the default and used, if any other access modifier keyword is missing. this is not the case in c++, where an absence means that the object is accessed privately. the meaning of these modifiers may differ from one language to another. a comparison of the keywords, ordered from the most restrictive to the most open, and their meaning in these three languages follows. their visibility ranges from the same class to the package where the class is defined to a general access permission. below, the maximal access is written into the table.\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! keyword !! c# !! c++ !! java\n|-\n|
<page> <title>accessory_olfactory_cortical_areas</title><text>{{one source|date=september 2011}}\n{{orphan|date=september 2011}}\n\'\'\'accessory olfactory cortical areas\'\'\' are portions of the [[human]] [[amygdala]] that are homologous to those areas in other species that receive afferents from the accessory [[olfactory bulb]]. they include the caudal part of the medial amygdalar nucleus, and the cortical amygdalar nucleus.<ref>{{citebook|author=price jl|year=1990|chapter=olfactory system|title=the human nervous system|editor= g. paxinos|publisher=academic press|location=san diego|oclc= 2830021034614 }}</ref>\n\n== references ==\n{{reflist}}\n\n== external links ==\n* more information at [http://braininfo.rprc.washington.edu/centraldirectory.aspx?id=2277 braininfo] \n\n<!--- categories --->\n[[category:neuroanatomy]]\n{{neuroanatomy-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>accessory_pigment</title><text>\'\'\'accessory pigments\'\'\' are [[pigment|light-absorbing]] compounds, found in [[photosynthetic]] [[organism]]s, that work in conjunction with [[chlorophyll a|chlorophyll \'\'a\'\']]. they include other forms of this pigment, such as chlorophyll \'\'b\'\' in [[green alga]]l and [[higher plant]] antennae, while other algae may contain chlorophyll \'\'c\'\' or \'\'d\'\'. in addition, there are many non-chlorophyll accessory pigments, such as [[carotenoid]]s or [[phycobiliprotein]]s, which also absorb light and transfer that light [[energy]] to [[photosystem]] chlorophyll. some of these accessory pigments, in particular the carotenoids, also serve to absorb and dissipate excess light energy, or work as [[antioxidants]]. the large, physically associated group of chlorophylls and other accessory pigments is sometimes referred to as a \'\'pigment bed\'\', though this term is no longer supported by what we know of photosystem and antenna complex structures.{{citation needed|date=august 2007}}\n\nthe different chlorophyll and non-chlorophyll pigments associated with the photosystems all have different [[absorption spectrum|absorption spectra]], either because the spectra of the different chlorophyll pigments are modified by their local protein environment or because the accessory pigments have intrinsic structural differences. the result is that, [[in vivo]], a composite absorption spectrum of all these pigments is broadened and flattened such that a wider range of [[visible light|visible]] and [[infrared]] radiation is absorbed by plants and algae. most photosynthetic organisms do not absorb green light well, thus most remaining light under leaf canopies in forests or under water with abundant plankton is green, a spectral effect called the \"green window\". organisms such as some [[cyanobacteria]] and [[red algae]] contain accessory [[phycobiliprotein]]s that absorb green light reaching these habitats.{{citation needed|date
<page> <title>accidental_death_of_an_anarchist</title><text>{{infobox play\n| name       = accidental death of an anarchist\n| image      = \n| image_size = \n| image_alt  = \n| caption    = \n| writer     = [[dario fo]]\n| chorus     = \n| characters = \n| mute       = \n| setting    = \n| premiere   =  5 december 1970\n| place      = \n| orig_lang  = [[italian language|italian]]\n| series     = \n| subject    = \n| genre      = \n| web        = \n| playbill   = \n| ibdb_id    = \n| iobdb_id   = \n| theatricalia_id = \n}}\n{{infobox book <!-- see wikipedia:wikiproject_novels or wikipedia:wikiproject_books -->\n| name           = accidental death of an anarchist\n| image          = [[file:morteaccidentale.jpg|150px]]\n| caption        = cover of the 2004 edition of<br/>\'\'morte accidentale di un anarchico\'\'\n| author         = [[dario fo]]\n| country        = [[italy]]\n| language       = [[italian language|italian]]\n| genre          =\n| publisher      = einaudi, [[turin]]\n| release_date   = 10 december 1970\n| media_type     = print\n| pages          = 89\n}}\n\'\'\'\'\'accidental death of an anarchist\'\'\'\'\' ([[italian language|italian]] title: \'\'morte accidentale di un anarchico\'\') is the most internationally recognised [[play (theatre)|play]] by [[dario fo]], recipient of the 1997 [[nobel prize in literature]]. considered a classic of twentieth-century theatre, it has been performed across the world in more than 40 countries, including argentina, chile, england, india, romania, south africa and south korea.<ref>mitchell 1999, p. 101</ref>\n\n==background==\nthe play is a [[farce]] based on events involving a real person, [[giuseppe pinelli]], who fell - or was thrown - from the fourth floor window of a milan police station in 1969. he was accused of bombing a bank (the [[piazza fontana bombing]]) but then has been cleared of the charge.\n\n==plot summary==\nthe events of the play itself, however, are fictional. the play opens with [[inspector]] bert
<page> <title>acco_festival_of_alternative_israeli_theatre</title><text>[[file:acco festival - 1995 program.pdf|thumb|program of the 1995 acco festival of alternative israeli theatre]]\n[[file:acco festival 2012 - 4.jpg|thumb|acco festival, 2012]]\n[[file:acco festival 2012.jpg|thumb|festival goers in old akko]]\nthe \'\'\'acco festival of alternative israeli theatre\'\'\' (also \'\'\'acco fringe theatre festival\'\'\', \'\'\'israel fringe theatre festival\'\'\') is  a four-day [[performing arts]] [[fringe theatre|festival]] held annually in the city of [[acre, israel|acre]], [[israel]] during the intermediate days of the [[sukkot]] holiday in early autumn.\n\n==history==\n\nfounded in 1980, the festival features a competition for original plays that premier during the festival, along with local and foreign theatre productions, street theatre and open-air performances. there are also concerts, arts and crafts workshops, and lectures.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-26011389_itm|title=we recommend|last=davis|first=barry|date=23 august 2002|work=jerusalem post via asia africa intelligence wire |accessdate=13 october 2009}}</ref>\n\nthe majority of the festival\'s plays come from outside the mainstream of establishment israeli theatre, some having avantgarde characteristics and subjects giving outlet to their creators\' personal statements. some combine media and genres such as pantomime, clowning, video, dance, and performance art rarely seen in the conventional theatre. many are staged in historic venues within the [[acre, israel#conservation projects|old city of acre]], such as its crusader-era citadel and knights\' halls that have undergone conservation.\n\nthe festival has been produced by the municipality of akko since the year 2000. it is supported by the israel [[ministry of culture]], the old acre development company and overseas [[foundation (nonprofit organization)|philanthropic foundations]].\n\nthe acre festival has be
<page> <title>accordion_cut</title><text>an \'\'\'accordion cut\'\'\' is a technique in butchery, similar to [[butterflying]], in which a thick piece of meat is extended into a thin one with a larger surface area. a series of parallel cuts are made from alternating sides of a roast almost all the way through, creating \"hinges\" which allow the meat to unfold into a long, flat, piece.\n\nthis technique is often used in conjunction with pounding with a [[meat mallet]], to further thin and even out the cut.\n\n==see also==\n* [[butterflying]] \n\n==external links==\n* [http://www.themeatsource.com/howtocutkoreanribs.html how to cut korean ribs]\n\n[[category:cutting techniques (cooking)]]\n\n\n{{cooking-stub}}</text> </page>
