<page> <title>accurizing</title><text>{{refimprove|date=june 2008}}\n[[file:unmodified and modified ruger 10 22 rifles.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[ruger 10/22]] [[carbine]]s, before accurizing (top) and after (below). externally visible changes are the target style stock, the bull barrel, and a [[muzzle brake]].]]\n\n\'\'\'accurizing\'\'\' is the process of improving the accuracy of a [[firearm]] or [[airgun]].<ref name=glossary>{{cite web |url=http://saami.org/glossary/index.cfm |title=saami glossary |accessdate=2007-08-30| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20070828104328/http://www.saami.org/glossary/index.cfm?cfid=6127413&cftoken=94218953&jsessionid=bc302984421186575542868| archivedate= 28 august 2007 <!--dashbot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>\n\nfor firearms, accuracy is defined as the ability to hit exactly what one is aiming at. further, [[accuracy and precision]], or the ability to hit the same place over and over again in a repeatable fashion, are the goals of accurizing.<ref>\"[http://www.chuckhawks.com/accuracy_gun_cartridge_shooter.htm accuracy: gun, cartridge, and shooter]\" by bob beers at chuck hawks web site</ref>\n\naccurizing generally concentrates on four different areas:\n*\'\'\'usability\'\'\': enhancements that give the shooter a more consistent hold on the firearm, and a more consistent trigger pull.\n*\'\'\'tolerances\'\'\': parts that fit together better will shift less or shift more consistently under recoil. moving parts still have to move, however, and finding the right compromise is more art than science.{{citation needed|date=february 2013}}\n*\'\'\'harmonics\'\'\': barrels vibrate under the shock of firing. these vibrations can be minimized or tuned to minimize their impact on accuracy. generally the harmonic effects are proportional to the square of the barrel length, and so are generally only of concern in [[rifle]]s but not [[handgun]]s.\n*\'\'\'projectile propulsion consistency\'\'\': unlike firearms, airguns provide the propulsive force 
<page> <title>ace_enders</title><text>{{infobox musical artist\n|image=ace_enders_-_2007_-_detroit,_michigan.jpg  |\n| name            = ace enders\n| background      = solo_singer\n| birth_name      = arthur carl enders iii\n| birth_date            = {{birth date and age|1982|4|19}}\n| death_date            = \n| origin          = [[hammonton, new jersey|hammonton]], [[new jersey]], [[united states]]\n| genre           = [[alternative rock]], [[indie rock]], [[folk music|folk]]\n| occupation      = [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]], [[instrumentalist]], [[record producer]]\n| years_active    = 1999–present\n| label           = [[drive-thru records]], regular music, [[rise records]]\n| associated_acts = [[the early november]], [[i can make a mess like nobody\'s business]], ace enders and a million different people\n}}\n\'\'\'arthur carl \"ace\" enders\'\'\' (born april 19, 1982 in [[hammonton, new jersey]]) is an [[united states|american]] [[musician]]. enders is the lead singer and guitarist of the band [[the early november]].  he is also the lead musician, songwriter and co-producer in his band, [[i can make a mess like nobody\'s business]]. he has also released music under the name ace enders and a million different people.\n\n==biography==\n\n===introduction to music and the early november===\nenders began playing guitar after being inspired by watching his step dad, robert gazzara play in a band. enders taught himself how to play his step dad\'s old guitar.<ref>[http://www.sing365.com/music/lyric.nsf/the-early-november-biography/85289bcad13b489248256c76001388e8 the early november biography]</ref>\n\nin february 2001, enders along with guitarist jim sacco, bassist sergio anello and drummer jeff kummer formed [[the early november]]. in 2003, after the release of their first two eps for all of this, and the acoustic ep, the band released their debut full length album \'\'[[the room\'s too cold]]\'\'.\n\nin 2004, enders started his own solo project [[i can make

<page> <title>ace_vergel</title><text>{{ref improve|date=january 2013}}\n{{infobox person\n| name                    = ace vergel\n| image                   = ace vergel, form the 1996 filipino motion picture, \'seth corteza\'.jpg\n| caption                 = ace vergel, from the 1996 filipino motion picture, \'seth corteza\'\n| birthname               = ace york aguilar vergel\n| birth_date              = {{birth date|mf=yes|1952|01|23}}\n| birth_place             =\n| death_date              = {{death date and age|mf=yes|2007|12|15|1952|01|23}}\n| death_place             = [[manila]], [[philippines]]\n| restingplace            =\n| restingplacecoordinates =\n| othername               = alas, the original bad boy of philippine movies\n| occupation              = actor\n| yearsactive             = 1959 - 2003\n| spouse                  =\n| domesticpartner         =\n| children                =\n| parents                 = [[alicia vergel]] and [[césar ramírez (actor)|césar ramirez]]\n| nationality             = [[filipino people|filipino]]\n| website                 =\n| awards                  = [[gawad urian|gawad urian best actor]] 1989 \'\'anak ng cabron\'\'}}\n\n\'\'\'ace york aguilar vergel\'\'\' (january 23, 1952 &ndash; december 15, 2007), was a filipino actor dubbed \"the original bad boy of philippine movies\".{{fact|date=may 2013}} he was the son of film actors, [[alicia vergel]] and [[césar ramírez (actor)|césar ramirez]], brother of actress [[beverly vergel]].\n\n==personal life==\nhe was married to maya dela cuesta and had a son, alejandro king aguilar.{{fact|date=september 2012}}\n\n==film career==\nhe appeared in his first movie at the age of seven, where he played the friend of a giant bird in the 1959 film \'\'anak ng bulkan\'\'. the movie starred [[fernando poe jr.]] and edna luna.\n\nin 1989, vergel won best actor at the [[gawad urian]] for his role in the film \'\'anak ng cabron\'\'.\n\n==controversies==\nin august 2007, a warrant of arre

<page> <title>acer_toradense</title><text>{{automatic taxobox\n|image = \n|image_caption =\n|fossil_range = {{fossilrange|ypresian}}\n|taxon = acer toradense\n|binomial = \'\'acer toradense\'\'\n|binomial_authority = [[jack a. wolfe|wolfe]] &  tanai, 1987\n|}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acer toradense\'\'\'\'\' is an extinct [[maple]] [[species]] in the family [[sapindaceae]] described from two [[fossil]] [[samara (fruit)|samara]]s.  the species is solely known from the [[early eocene]] sediments exposed in northeast [[washington (state)|washington state]], usa and the adjacent area of south central [[british columbia]], canada.  it is one of three species belonging to the extinct section \'\'[[list of acer species|torada]]\'\'.<ref name=\"wolfe1987\">{{cite journal |last1=wolfe |first1=j.a. |last2=tanai |first2=t. |year=1987 |title=systematics, phylogeny, and distribution of \'\'acer\'\' (maples) in the cenozoic of western north america |journal= journal of the faculty of science, hokkaido university. series 4, geology and mineralogy |volume=22 |issue=1 |pages=1–246 |url=http://biblioteca.universia.net/html_bura/ficha/params/title/systematics-phylogeny-and-distribution-of-acer-maples-in-the-cenozoic/id/39790012.html}}</ref>\n\n==history and classification==\nthe species was described from a pair of complete fruit specimens.  the [[holotype]] fossil was recovered from resner canyon, location [[national museum of natural history]] usnm 11018 in the toroda creek graben of northeast washington state.  location usnm 11018 is an outcropping of early eocene, [[ypresian]],<ref name=\"moss2005\"/> shale belonging to the [[klondike mountain formation]].<ref name=\"wolfe1987\"/>  the [[paratype]] specimen was recovered from sediments of the ypresian [[allenby formation]] exposed in the blue flame mine near [[princeton, british columbia]].  both the allenby and klondike mountain formations preserve upland temperate floras which were first interpreted as being [[microthermal]],<ref name=\"
<page> <title>aceratheriinae</title><text>{{taxobox\n| name = aceratheriinae\n| image = \n| image_width = 250px\n| image_caption = \n| fossil_range = {{fossil range|oligocene|pliocene}}\n| status = fossil\n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[chordate|chordata]]\n| classis = [[mammal]]ia\n| ordo = [[perissodactyla]]\n| familia = [[rhinocerotidae]]\n| subfamilia = †aceratheriinae\n| genus = \n| genus_authority = dollo, 1885\n| subdivision_ranks = [[genera]]\n| subdivision = \n*\'\'[[aceratherium]]\'\'\n*\'\'[[alicornops]]\'\'\n*\'\'[[aphelops]]\'\'\n*\'\'[[chilotheriini]]\'\'\n*\'\'[[floridaceras]]\'\'\n*\'\'[[peraceras]]\'\'\n}}\n\'\'\'aceratheriinae\'\'\' is an extinct [[subfamily]] of [[rhinoceros]] endemic to [[asia]], [[africa]], [[europe]], and [[north america]] during the [[oligocene]] through [[pliocene]] living from 33.9—3.4 [[annum|mya]], existing for approximately {{mya|33.9-3.4|million years}}.<ref>[http://paleodb.org/cgi-bin/bridge.pl?action=checktaxoninfo&taxon_no=55473&is_real_user=1 paleobiology database: \'\'aceratheriinae\'\', basic info]</ref>\n\nit consists of 6 [[genera]]:\n\n*\'\'[[aceratherini]]\'\' - europe, eurasia, asia, africa\n*\'\'[[alicornops]]\'\' - europe, eurasia, asia\n*\'\'[[aphelops]]\'\' - north america\n*\'\'[[chilotheriini]]\'\' - eurasia and asia\n*\'\'[[floridaceras]]\'\' - north america\n*\'\'[[peraceras]]\'\' - north america\n\n==taxonomy==\naceratheriinae was named by dollo (1885). it was assigned to [[rhinocerotida]] by codrea (1992); and to [[rhinocerotidae]] by prothero (1998), antoine et al. (2000), kaya and heissig (2001), sach and heizmann (2001) and deng (2005).<ref>v. codrea. 1992. new mammal remains from the sarmatian deposits an minisu de sus (taut, arad county). studia universitatis babes-bolyai, geologica 2:35-41</ref><ref>d. r. prothero. 1998. rhinocerotidae. in c. m. janis, k. m. scott, and l. l. jacobs (eds.), evolution of tertiary mammals of north america 595-605</ref><ref>p.-o. antoine, c. bulot, and l
<page> <title>acerbia</title><text>{{italictitle}}\n{{taxobox\n| name = \'\'acerbia\'\'\n| image = acerbia alpina.jpg\n| image_width = 220px\n| image_caption = \'\'[[acerbia alpina]]\'\'\n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| classis = [[insect]]a\n| ordo = [[lepidoptera]]\n| familia = [[arctiidae]]\n| subfamilia = [[arctiinae]] \n| tribus = [[arctiini]] \n| subtribus = [[arctiina]] \n| genus = \'\'\'\'\'acerbia\'\'\'\'\'\n| genus_authority = sotavalta, 1963\n| subdivision_ranks = [[species]]\n| subdivision = see text.\n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acerbia\'\'\'\'\' is a [[genus]] of [[moth]]s in the [[arctiidae]] family.<ref>{{butmoth|id=144.0}}</ref>\n\n==species==\n*\'\'[[acerbia alpina]]\'\' <small>(quensel, 1802)</small>\n*\'\'[[acerbia churkini]]\'\' <small>saldaitis, ivinskis & witt, 2003</small>\n*\'\'[[acerbia cornuta]]\'\' <small>saldaitis, ivinskis & witt, 2004</small><ref>{{aut|saldaitis, a. , p. ivinskis & t.j. witt}} 2004: \'\'acerbia cornuta\'\' spec. nov. and \'\'acerbia seitzi micropuncta\'\' subspec. nov. from central asia (lepidoptera: arctiidae). \'\'atalanta\'\' \'\'\'35 (3/4)\'\'\': 415-425.</ref>\n*\'\'[[acerbia khumbeli]]\'\' <small>(bang-haas 1927)</small>\n*\'\'[[acerbia kolpakofskii]]\'\' <small>(alpheraky, 1882)</small>\n*\'\'[[acerbia seitzi]]\'\' <small>(a. bang-haas, 1910)</small>\n\n==references==\n<references/>\n\n[[category:arctiini]]\n\n\n{{arctiinae-stub}}</text> </page>

<page> <title>achaea_nigristriata</title><text>{{taxobox\n| name = achaea nigristriata\n| image = \n| image_caption = \n| image_width = 100px\n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| classis = [[insect]]a\n| ordo = [[lepidoptera]]\n| familia = [[noctuidae]]\n| familia_authority =\n| subfamilia_authority = \n| genus = \'\'[[achaea (moth)|achaea]]\'\'\n| genus_authority =\n| species = \'\'\'\'\'a. nigristriata\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'achaea nigristriata\'\'\n| binomial_authority =  laporte, 1979<ref>[http://www.afromoths.net/species/show/29806 afromoths]</ref>\n| synonyms = \n\n}}\n\'\'\'\'\'achaea nigristriata\'\'\'\'\' is a species of [[moth]] of the [[noctuidae]] family. it is found in [[tanzania]].\n\nthis species has a wingspan from 55mm and a length of the forewings of 25mm.<ref>{{fr icon}} laporte, b. 1979. [http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/28200015#page/123/mode/1up descriptions de nouvelles espèces de noctuelles de l\'afrique (lepidoptera, noctuidae). - spixiana 2]:105–112</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n[[category:animals described in 1979]]\n[[category:achaea (moth)]]\n\n{{catocalini-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>achaean_league</title><text>{{infobox former country\n|native_name = κοινὸν τῶν Ἀχαιῶν<br/>\'\'koinon ton achaion\'\'\n|conventional_long_name = league of the achaeans\n|common_name            = achaean league\n|continent              = europe\n|region                 = mediterranean\n|era                    = [[classical antiquity]]\n|status                 =\n|status_text            =\n|empire                 =\n|government_type        = [[republic]]an [[confederation|confederacy]]\n|year_start             = 280 bc\n|year_end               = 146 bc\n|year_exile_start       =\n|year_exile_end         =\n|event_start            = re-founded under the leadership of aigion, with the aim to \"expel the macedonians\"\n|date_start             =\n|event_end              = conquered by the [[roman republic]] in the [[battle of corinth (146 bc)|achaean war]]\n|date_end               =\n|event1                 = [[philopoemen]] conquers [[sparta]]\n|date_event1            = 188 bc\n|event2                 =\n|date_event2            =\n|event3                 =\n|date_event3            =\n|event4                 =\n|date_event4            =\n|event_pre              =\n|date_pre               =\n|event_post             =\n|date_post              =\n|p1                     = league of corinth\n|s1                     = achaea (roman province)\n|flag_s1                =\n|image_s1               =\n|s2                     =\n|flag_s2                =\n|s3                     =\n|flag_s3                =\n|s4                     =\n|flag_s4                =\n|s5                     =\n|flag_s5                =\n|image_flag             =\n|flag                   =\n|flag_type              =\n|image_coat             =\n|symbol                 =\n|symbol_type            =\n|image_map              = la liga aquea en 150 ac.jpg\n|image_map_caption      = achaean league in 150 bc\n|capital                = [[aigion]] (meeting place)\n|capital_exile      
<page> <title>achal_das_bohra</title><text>{{unreferenced|date=january 2008}}\n{| class=\"infobox biography\" style=\"width: 21em; text-align: center;\"\n|-\n! colspan=\"2\" style=\"font-size: larger;\" | a. d. bohra\n|-\n|[[image:adbohra1.jpg|thumbnail]]\n| colspan=\"2\" style=\"font-size: normal;\" |\n|-\n| [[jodhpur]], [[rajasthan]], [[india]]</small>\n|-\n|}\n\n\'\'\'achal das bohra\'\'\' (december 23, 1918 – february 17, 2007) was a prominent indian engineer, academician, author, educator and philanthropist hailing from the town of [[jodhpur]], [[rajasthan]]. bohra, affectionately known as \"papaji\" and \"bohra saab\", was a leader of the [[pushkarna]] brahmin community in rajasthan and a tireless advocate of women\'s rights and the balance of modernity and traditional [[hindu]] philosophical thought.\n\n==personal==\nbohra was born to dau das and bachu bohra and was the third of four children.  his youngest sister died in childhood and he grew up with his two older sisters, ashi and gita, under the care of his father\'s sister. bohra was married to phool kaur purohit on april 26, 1934, but did not again meet her until october of that same year on dashera day.\n\nduring his childhood, bohra ran messages for [[jai narayan vyas]], a young freedom fighter and a future chief minister of rajasthan, during the nascent indian independence movement.\n\nbohra identified three gurus who guided and heavily influenced him throughout his life—his gyan (knowledge) guru was [[pandit madan mohan malaviya]], the founder of [[banaras hindu university]], his karma (action) guru was [[jai narayan vyas]], and his dharma (faith) guru was his holiness paramhans shri 1008 swami hari har ji maharaj, founder of the international federation of geeta ashrams.\n\nhe is survived by five of his eight children, sixteen grandchildren, twenty great-grandchildren, and two great great-grandchildren dispersed across india and the united states.\n\n==education==\nbohra graduated at the top of

<page> <title>acharya</title><text> {{other uses}}\nin [[indian religions]] and society, an \'\'\'acharya\'\'\' ([[iast]]: {{iast|ācārya}}; {{lang-sa|आचार्य}}; {{lang-ta|அசாரி}} {{iast|ācāri}}; [[pali]]: \'\'acariya\'\') is a guide or instructor in religious matters; founder, or leader of a sect; or one who sits of [[gadi]]; or a highly learned man or a title affixed to the names of learned men.<ref>{{cite book|last=platts|first=john t. |title=a dictionary of urdu, classical hindi, and english|publisher=w. h. allen & co.|location=london|year=1884|url=http://dsal.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.0:1:1246.platts}}</ref> the designation has different meanings in [[hinduism]], [[buddhism]], [[jainism]] and secular contexts. the surname is also very common in the indian state of [[west bengal]].\n\nacharya is also used to address a teacher or a scholar in any discipline, e.g.: [[bhaskaracharya]], the mathematician. it is also a common suffix in [[brahmin]] names, e.g.: [[krishnamacharya]], [[bhattacharya]]. in south india, this suffix is sometimes shortened to achar, e.g.: [[tkv desikachar]]. \nacharya is also used as surname. in the social order of some parts of india, acharyas are considered as the highest amongst the brahmin community, often described as the \"\nbrahman\" i.e. best in brahmins. \n\n==etymology==\nthe term \"acharya\" is most often said to include the root \"char\" or \"charya\" (conduct). thus it literally connotes \"one who teaches by conduct (example),\" i.e. an exemplar.\n\n==in hinduism==\nin [[hinduism]], an \'\'acharya\'\' (आचार्य) is a formal title of a teacher or guru, who have ownered the degree in the vedanga. in rare cases, the title may denote someone considered to be a \'\'mahāpuruśa\'\' (महापुरुश, \'\'divine personality\'\') who is believed to have descended as an \'\'[[avatar|avatāra]]\'\' (अवतार, \'\'incarnation\'\') to teach and establish \'\'[[bhakti]]\'
<page> <title>acharya_brojendra_nath_seal_college</title><text>{{infobox university |\nname           = acharya brojendra nath seal college|\nimage          = |\ntype           = [[public college]]|\nestablished    = 1888 |\nprincipal      =  |\naddress        = [[cooch behar]], [[west bengal]], [[india]]|\ncity           = [[cooch behar]] |\ncountry        = [[india]] |\nformer_names   = victoria college |\ncolors         =  |\naffiliations   = [[university of north bengal]]|\nwebsite        = {{url|http://abnsc.org/}}\n}}\n\n\'\'\'acharya brojendra nath seal college\'\'\' or \'\'\'abn seal\'\'\', earlier \'\'\'victoria college\'\'\', is a co-educational college in [[cooch behar]], [[west bengal]], [[india]]. it was established in 1888 and offers [[undergraduate education|undergraduate]] and [[postgraduate education]]. the college is affiliated to the [[university of north bengal]] and accredited as b by [[national assessment and accreditation council|naac]].<ref name=\"disclose\">{{cite web|url=http://abnsealcollege.org/disclosure.htm|title=disclosure about college|publisher=a.b.n. seal college|accessdate=2009-05-03}} {{dead link|date=october 2010|bot=h3llbot}}</ref> the college has been conferred \"centre of excellence\" status by the [[university grants commission (india)|university grants commission]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1100227/jsp/calcutta/story_12155330.jsp|title=cu scores perfect 5 on excellence podium|publisher=the telegraph|accessdate=2010-02-27}}</ref>\n\n==history==\nacharya brojendra nath seal college was established in 1888 as victoria college by [[nripendra narayan|maharaja nripendra narayan]] of [[koch bihar]] to enhance student capability in the kingdom.<ref name=\"history\">{{cite web|url=http://abnsealcollege.org/index.html|title=brief history|publisher=a.b.n. seal college|accessdate=2009-05-03}}</ref> the first principal was j.d. godley. later maharaja nripendra naryayan offered the post of principal to [[acharya br
<page> <title>achatinella_juncea</title><text>{{italictitle}}\n{{taxobox\n| name = \'\'achatinella juncea\'\'\n| image = \n| status = ex | status_system = iucn2.3\n| status_ref = <ref>mollusc specialist group (1996) [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/185/all \'\'achatinella juncea\'\']. [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 iucn red list of threatened species.] downloaded on 6 august 2007.</ref>\n| regnum = [[animalia]]\n| phylum = [[mollusca]]\n| classis = [[gastropoda]]\n| unranked_superfamilia=\nclade [[heterobranchia]]<br/>\nclade [[euthyneura]]<br/>clade [[panpulmonata]]<br/>\nclade [[eupulmonata]]<br/>\nclade [[stylommatophora]]<br/>\nclade [[orthurethra]]\n| superfamilia = [[achatinelloidea]]\n| familia = [[achatinellidae]]\n| genus = \'\'[[achatinella]]\'\'\n| subgenus = \'\'[[achatinellastrum]]\'\'\n| species = † \'\'\'\'\'a. juncea\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'achatinella juncea\'\'\n| binomial_authority = [[gulick]], 1856\n| synonyms = }}\n\n† \'\'\'\'\'achatinella juncea\'\'\'\'\' was a [[species]] of air-breathing [[land snail]], a [[terrestrial animal|terrestrial]] [[pulmonate]] [[gastropod]] [[mollusk]] in the family [[achatinellidae]]. this species was [[endemism|endemic]] to [[list of non-marine molluscs of hawaii|hawaii]]. \n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n[[category:achatinella|†juncea]]\n[[category:extinct gastropods]]\n[[category:molluscs of hawaii]]\n[[category:endemic fauna of hawaii]]\n\n{{achatinellidae-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>acheilognathus_barbatulus</title><text>{{italictitle}}\n{{taxobox\n| name = \'\'acheilognathus barbatulus\'\'\n| regnum = [[animalia]]\n| phylum = [[chordata]]\n| classis = [[actinopterygii]]\n| ordo = [[cypriniformes]]\n| familia = [[cyprinidae]]\n| genus = \'\'[[acheilognathus]]\'\'\n| species = \'\'\'\'\'a. barbatulus\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'acheilognathus barbatulus\'\'\n| binomial_authority = [[albert günther|günther]], 1873<ref>{{fishbase|acheilognathus|barbatulus}}</ref>\n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acheilognathus barbatulus\'\'\'\'\' is a species of freshwater [[ray-finned fish]] in the genus \'\'[[acheilognathus]]\'\'. it is endemic to the [[mekong|mekong river]] in [[laos]], northern [[vietnam]] and southern [[china]] in waters between 8-20 °c and its maximum length is 8.4cm.\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n[[category:acheilognathus]]\n\n{{acheilognathinae-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>acheilognathus_hondae</title><text>{{taxobox\n| name = \'\'acheilognathus hondae\'\'\n| regnum = [[animalia]]\n| phylum = [[chordata]]\n| classis = [[actinopterygii]]\n| ordo = [[cypriniformes]]\n| familia = [[cyprinidae]]\n| genus = \'\'[[acheilognathus]]\'\'\n| species = \'\'\'\'\'a. hondae\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'acheilognathus hondae\'\'\n| binomial_authority = ([[david starr jordan|d. s. jordan]] & [[charles wiliam metz|metz]], 1913)<ref>{{fishbase|acheilognathus|hondae}}</ref>\n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acheilognathus hondae\'\'\'\'\' is a species of freshwater [[ray-finned fish]] in the genus \'\'[[acheilognathus]]\'\'.  it is endemic to [[south korea]].\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n[[category:acheilognathus]]\n\n{{acheilognathinae-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>achel_abbey</title><text>{{use dmy dates|date=september 2011}}\n[[file:799px-hamont achel - sint-benedictusabdij.jpg|thumb|right|entrance gate of the abbey]]\nthe \'\'\'trappist abbey of achel\'\'\' or \'\'\'saint benedictus-abbey\'\'\' or also \'\'\'achelse kluis\'\'\' (which means [[hermitage (religious retreat)|hermitage]] of achel), which belongs to the [[trappists|cistercians of strict observance]], is located in [[achel]] in the [[campine]] region of the province of [[limburg (belgium)|limburg]] ([[flanders]], belgium). the abbey is famous for its spiritual life and its [[achel brewery|brewery]], which is one of few [[trappist beer]] breweries in the world. life in the abbey is characterised by prayer, reading and manual work, the three basic elements of trappist life.\n\n==history==\n===17th to 18th century===\non 30 january 1648, at the and of the [[eighty years war]], the [[peace of münster|treaty of munster]] was signed between spain and the [[netherlands]]. the result of the treaty was that the catholic [[mass (liturgy)|mass]] was not allowed in the [[dutch republic]]. therefore catholics from [[valkenswaard]] and schaft built a chapel in achel which was part of the [[prince-bishopric of liège]]. the early roots of the abbey date back to 1686, when [[petrus van eynatten]], a son of the mayor of [[eindhoven]], founded a community of [[hermit]]s of [[saint joseph]]. the community would flourish until 1789 when they were expelled from their convent after the [[french revolution|french revolutionary]] army invaded the [[austrian netherlands]]. the abbey was sold to jan diederik van tuyll van serooskerken (utrecht, 6 august 1773-heeze, 9 july 1843).\n\n===19th century===\non 21 march 1846 the [[trappists]] from [[westmalle abbey]] founded a [[priory]] in [[achel]] (first founded in [[hoogstraten|meersel-dreef]] on 3 may 1838 in a former monastery of the [[order of friars minor capuchin]]). the abbey and its 95 hectares of land had been bought b
<page> <title>achen_pass</title><text>{{infobox mountain pass\n| name = achen pass\n| photo = achenpass.jpg\n| photo_caption = \n| elevation_m = 941\n| elevation_ref = .\n| traversed = \n| location = [[miesbach (district)]], [[bavaria]], {{ger}}\n| range = [[alps]]\n| coordinates = {{coord|47|36|12|n|11|38|8|e|type:pass}}\n| topo = \n}}\n\n\'\'\'achen pass\'\'\' (el.&nbsp;941&nbsp;n.) is a [[mountain pass]] in the [[alps]] in the state of [[bavaria]] in [[germany]].\n\nthe pass is located in the southwest corner of the [[miesbach (district)|miesbach district (\'\'landkreis miesbach\'\')]], about 1 km north of the border with [[austria]] in the south of bavaria.  it connects the valley of the [[tegernsee]] in the north with the [[tiroler achen|achen]] valley in [[county of tyrol|tyrol]] in the south.  it divides the watershed of the [[danube]] and the [[inn river|inn]].\n\nas early as 1495, the pass road was an important commercial route for bringing salt to [[munich]].  it was also an important route for the bavarian army, which controlled tyrol at the time of [[napoleon]].  in the 19th century, it lost its commercial importance, but gained an important role in the tourist industry.\n\n==see also==\n* [[list of highest paved roads in europe]]\n* [[list of mountain passes#europe|list of mountain passes]]\n\n== references ==\n{{reflist}}\n{{iw-ref|de}}\n\n[[category:mountain passes of germany]]\n[[category:mountain passes of the alps]]\n\n{{bavaria-geo-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>achhut</title><text>{{infobox film\n| name           =achhut\n| image          = \n| image_size     = \n| caption        = \n| director       =\n| producer       =\n| writer         =\n| narrator       = \n| starring       =\n| music          =\n| cinematography = \n| editing        = \n| distributor    = \n| released       = 1940\n| runtime        = \n| country        = [[india]]\n| language       = [[hindi language|hindi]]\n| budget         = \n| gross          = \n| preceded_by    = \n| followed_by    = \n| website        = \n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'achhut \'\'\'\'\' is a [[bollywood films of 1940|1940]] indian [[bollywood]] film. it was the third highest grossing indian film of 1940.<ref>{{cite web|title=top earners 1940|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/showprod.php?itemcat=145&catname=mtk0ma==|publisher=box office india|accessdate=26 september 2011}}</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==external links==\n* {{imdb title|id=|title=achhut  }}\n\n[[category:1940 films]]\n[[category:hindi-language films]]\n[[category:indian films]]\n\n{{1940s-hindi-film-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>achillas</title><text>{{about|the egyptian general achillas|the eighteenth patriarch of alexandria|pope achillas of alexandria|the greek hero of the [[trojan war]]|achilles}}\n\'\'\'achillas\'\'\' (greek \'\'\'{{lang|grc|Αχιλλας}}\'\'\') was one of the guardians of the egyptian king [[ptolemy xiii theos philopator]], and commander of the king\'s troops, when [[pompey]] fled to egypt in 48 bc.  he was called by [[julius caesar]] a man of extraordinary daring, and it was he and [[lucius septimius]] who killed pompey at the suggestion of the [[eunuch (court official)|eunuch]] [[pothinus]] and [[theodotus of chios]].<ref>[[julius caesar]], \'\'[[commentarii de bello civili]]\'\' iii. 104</ref><ref>[[livy]], \'\'epit.\'\' 104</ref><ref>[[cassius dio]] xlii. 4</ref>\n\nhe subsequently joined pothinus in resisting caesar, and having had the command of the whole army entrusted to him by pothinus, he marched against [[alexandria]] with 20,000 on foot and 2,000 cavalry.<ref>{{citation\n  | last = smith\n  | first = william\n  | author-link = william smith (lexicographer)\n  | contribution = achillas\n  | editor-last = smith\n  | editor-first = william\n  | title = [[dictionary of greek and roman biography and mythology]]\n  | volume = 1\n  | pages = 9\n  | publisher = \n  | place = boston, ma\n  | year = 1867\n  | contribution-url = http://www.ancientlibrary.com/smith-bio/0018.html }}</ref>  caesar, who was at alexandria, did not have sufficient forces to oppose him, and sent ambassadors to negotiate with him.  however, achillas murdered the ambassadors to remove all hopes of reconciliation.  he then marched into alexandria and occupied most of the city ([[siege of alexandria (47 bc)]]).  meanwhile, [[arsinoe iv of egypt|arsinoe]], the younger sister of [[ptolemy xiii theos philopator|ptolemy]], escaped from caesar and joined achillas.  however, in 47 bc, dissension broke out between them, so arsinoe had achillas put to death by [[ganymedes (eunuch)|ganym
<page> <title>achille_bergevin</title><text>{{infobox officeholder\n| honorific-prefix = \n| name             = achille bergevin\n| honorific-suffix = \n| image            = achille bergevin 1900.jpg\n| imagesize        = \n| office           = member of the [[legislative assembly of quebec]] for [[beauharnois (provincial electoral district)|beauharnois]]\n| predecessor      = [[arthur plante]]\n| successor        = [[arthur plante]]\n| term_start       = 1900\n| term_end         = 1908\n| predecessor2     = [[edmund arthur robert]]\n| successor2       = [[arthur plante]]\n| term_start2      = 1919\n| term_end2        = 1923\n| office3          = member of the [[legislative council of quebec]] for repentigny \n| predecessor3     = [[horace archambeault]]\n| successor3       = [[georges-aimé simard]]\n| term_start3      = 1910\n| term_end3        = 1913\n| office4          = member of the [[legislative council of quebec]] for de salaberry\n| predecessor4     = [[jean-damien rolland]]\n| successor4       = [[alphonse racine]]\n| term_start4      = 1913\n| term_end4        = 1914\n| birth_date       = {{birth date|1870|03|03|df=y}}\n| birth_place      = salaberry-de-valleyfield, quebec\n| death_date       = {{death date and age|1933|04|16|1870|03|03|df=y}}\n| death_place      = montreal, quebec\n| nationality      = \n| spouse           = \n| party            = [[quebec liberal party|liberal]]\n| relations        = \n| children         = \n| residence        = \n| alma_mater       = \n| occupation       = \n| profession       = \n| religion         = \n}}\n\'\'\'achille bergevin\'\'\' (3 march 1870 &ndash; 16 april 1933) was a [[canada|canadian]] politician in the [[provinces of canada|province]] of [[quebec]].\n\nborn in [[salaberry-de-valleyfield]], [[quebec]], the son of gilbert bergevin and marie daoust, bergevin was educated at the commercial academy of varennes.\n\nhe was elected to the [[legislative assembly of quebec]] for the electoral district of [[beauharno
<page> <title>achille_simonetti</title><text>\'\'\'achille simonetti\'\'\' (12 june 1857 – 19 november 1928) was an [[italians|italian]] and [[english people|english]] [[violin|violinist]] and [[composer]].\n\n==early life and education==\nborn in [[turin]] on the 12th of june 1857,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.brainyhistory.com/events/1857/june_12_1857_53631.html |title=achille simonetti is born |accessdate=24 august 2010}}</ref> simonetti left his family in [[boulogne|bologna]] (this can be gleaned from his letter to mr hill (of hills and sons) written in 1922,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.montagnanabooks.com/parti-autographs.html |title= montagnana books: autographs catalogue |accessdate=24 august 2010}}</ref>) and completed his studies under francesco bianchi, [[eugenio cavallini]], giuseppe gamba, [[charles dancla]], regarded as the last exponent of the classical french school of violin playing,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.users.globalnet.co.uk/~leonid/charles_dancla_history.htm |title=charles dancla: his life & times |accessdate=24 august 2010}}</ref> and [[camillo sivori]], the only pupil of [[niccolo paganini]].<ref>walter starkie, \'\'scholars and gypsies\'\' (1963), p. 90-91.</ref>\n\n==career==\nsimonetti became part of the first london trio, an endeavour which occupied him from 1901 to 1907, <ref>http://www.concertprogrammes.org.uk/html/search/verb/getrecord/4928</ref> along with colleagues [[amina goodwin]] and [[william whitehouse]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mugi.hfmt-hamburg.de/a_lexartikel/lexartikel.php?id=good1867 |title=musik und gender im internet: amina goodwin |accessdate=16 january 2011}}</ref>\n\nfrom 1912 to 1919, he was a professor of violin at the [[royal irish academy of music]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dolmetsch.com/cdefss.htm |title=composers\' biographies letter s |accessdate=24 august 2010}}</ref> and served as a teacher for many distinguished violinists, including [[walter starkie]].\n\nsimonetti was also an early c
<page> <title>achilles_gasser</title><text>\'\'\'achilles pirmin gasser\'\'\'<ref>also gassar, gasserus, gassarus.</ref> (3 november 1505 – 4 december 1577) was a german physician and astrologer. he is now known as a well-connected humanist scholar, and supporter of both [[copernicus]] and [[rheticus]].\n[[file:achilles pirminius gasser.jpg|thumb|achilles gasser, 17th-century engraving.]]\n\n==life==\nborn in [[lindau]], he studied mathematics, history and philosophy as well as astronomy.<ref name=magnete>http://www.theiet.org/about/libarc/archives/biographies/peregrinus.cfm</ref> he was a student in [[sélestat]] under [[johannes sapidus]];<ref>peter g. bietenholz and thomas brian deutscher, \'\'contemporaries of erasmus: a biographical register of the renaissance and reformation\'\' (2003), volume 3, p. 196; [http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hruq386sffcc&pg=ra2-pa92&lpg=ra2-pa92&dq=%22thomas+venatorius%22&source=bl&ots=o5mido0f0r&sig=dvmz_hvdwpuilrmnvmv6h_xq4v4&hl=en&ei=xqn7tqg_asgo8qpvn_ddcq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0cdsq6aewbq#v=onepage&q=gasser&f=false google books].</ref> he also attended universities in wittenberg, vienna, montpellier, and avignon.<ref name=danielson>[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/full/2004jha....35..457d \'\'achilles gasser and the birth of copernicanism\'\']</ref>\n\nrheticus lost his physician father georg iserin in 1528, executed on sorcery charges. gasser later took over the practice in [[feldkirch, vorarlberg|feldkirch]], in 1538; he taught rheticus some [[astrology]], and helped his education, in particular by writing to the [[university of wittenberg]] on his behalf.<ref name=danielson/><ref>[http://www.gap-system.org/~history/biographies/rheticus.html mactutor page on rheticus]</ref><ref>repcheck, pp. 113–4.</ref>\n\nwhen rheticus printed his \'\'narratio prima\'\'—the first published account of the copernican [[heliocentric system]]—in 1540 (danzig), he sent gasser a copy. gasser then undertook a second editi
<page> <title>achilles_last_stand</title><text>{{infobox song <!-- see wikipedia:wikiproject_songs --> |\n| name           = achilles last stand\n| cover          =\n| artist         = [[led zeppelin]]\n| album          = [[presence (album)|presence]]\n| released       = 31 march 1976\n| track_no       = 1\n| recorded       = november–december 1975\n| genre          = [[hard rock]], [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]]\n| length         = 10:25\n| label          = [[swan song records|swan song]]\n| writer         = [[jimmy page|page]]/[[robert plant|plant]]\n| producer       = [[jimmy page]]\n| prev           =\n| prev_no        =\n| next           = \"[[for your life]]\"\n| next_no        = 2\n| misc           =\n{{audiosample\n| background=#e6e8fa\n| upper caption = audio sample\n| audio file  = led zeppelin achilles last stand.ogg\n}}\n}}\n\"\'\'\'achilles last stand\'\'\'\"{{refn|group=nb|the apostrophe, which should rightly be in the phrase \"achilles\' last stand\" in correct english, is not present in this song title.}} is a song by the english rock group [[led zeppelin]], featured as the opening track on their 1976 album \'\'[[presence (album)|presence]]\'\'. it was written by [[jimmy page]] and [[robert plant]] at page\'s house in [[malibu, california|malibu]], [[california]] where they stayed for a month while plant was recovering from injuries he sustained in a [[car accident]] in greece in 1975. the song was then recorded at [[musicland studios]] in [[munich, germany]].\n\n==overview==\n\"achilles last stand\", at 10 minutes and 25 seconds, is the third longest studio recording released by led zeppelin (after \"[[in my time of dying (led zeppelin song)|in my time of dying]]\" at 11:06 and \"[[carouselambra]]\" at 10:34). it is famous for [[john bonham]]\'s powerful drumming, [[john paul jones (musician)|john paul jones]]\'s galloping bass line (played on a custom-built [[alembic inc|alembic]] eight string bass) and jimmy page\'s overdubbed orchestral guit
<page> <title>achilles_bursitis</title><text>\'\'\'achilles bursitis\'\'\' is [[bursitis]] (inflammation of [[synovial sac]]) of [[bursa]] situated above the [[insertion (anatomy)|insertion]] of tendon to [[calcaneus]].<ref>{{cite book|last=fauci|first=anthony|title=harrison\'s rheumatology, second edition|year=2010|publisher=mcgraw-hill professional publishing; digital edition|isbn=9780071741460|pages=271}}</ref> it results from overuse and wearing of tight shoes.\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{soft tissue disorders}}\n\n[[category:foot diseases]]</text> </page>	
<page> <title>achint_kaur</title><text>{{infobox person\n| name           = achint kaur\n| image          = achint kaur.jpg\n| birth_place    = [[meerut]], [[uttar pradesh]], [[india]]\n| yearsactive    = 1995- present\n| othernames     = mandira<br>pallavi\n| known for      = \'\'[[kyunki saas bhi kabhi bahu thi]]\'\'<br>\'\'[[kahaani ghar ghar kii]]\'\'\n}}\n\n\'\'\'achint kaur\'\'\' is an indian television actress who comes from a [[punjabi culture|punjabi]] background and is best known for playing the [[antagonist]], \'\'mandira\'\', & \'\'pallavi\'\' in [[ekta kapoor]]\'s [[indian soap opera]]\'s \'\'[[kyunki saas bhi kabhi bahu thi]]\'\' & \'\'[[kahaani ghar ghar kii]]\'\' on [[star plus]].\n\n==personal life and education==\nkaur was born and raised in [[meerut]], [[uttar pradesh]];<ref>{{cite news|title=\nplaying historical character is not easy: achint kaur|publisher=indo-asian news service|place=mumbai|date=31 december 2010|url=http://movies.ndtv.com/movie_story.aspx?id=enten20100165067|accessdate=15 march 2012}}</ref> where she studied at sophia girls\' school.<ref>{{cite web|title=achint kaur biography|url=http://www.faltooclub.com/biography/detail/753/achint_kaur__.aspx|accessdate=15 march 2012}}</ref>\n\n==career==\nshe started her career with [[zee tv]]\'s popular show [[banegi apni baat]] in 1994, and later worked in [[swabhimaan]] in 1995 in which she plays the role of \'soha\'.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0307837/|title=swabhimaan|publisher=imdb.com|year=1995}}</ref>\n\nbesides working in some of the popular drama series, achint has also played prolific roles in [[bollywood]] movies, such as [[om jai jagadish]], [[corporate (film)|corporate]], & [[julie (2004 film)|julie]]. she has also won numerous awards for her strong character driven roles. these include <page> <title>achomawi_traditional_narratives</title><text>\'\'\'achomawi traditional narratives\'\'\' include myths, legends, tales, and oral histories preserved by the [[achomawi]] people of the [[pit river]] basin of northeastern california.\n\nachomawi oral literature reflects the group\'s position at the junction of cultural influences from central california, the great basin, the plateau, and the northwest coast regions of aboriginal north america.\n\n==see also==\n* [[traditional narratives (native california)]]\n\n==achomawi narratives==\n* angulo, jaime de, and lucy s. freeland. 1931. \"two achumawi tales\". \'\'journal of american folklore\'\' 44:125-136. (collected from mary martin.)\n* curtis, edward s. 1907-1930. \'\'the north american indian\'\'. 20 vols. plimpton press, norwood, massachusetts. (creation myth collected from henry wool, vol. 13, pp. 206-210.)\n* dixon, roland b. 1905. \"the mythology of the shasta-achomawi\". \'\'american anthropologist\'\' 7:607-612. (comparative notes.)\n* dixon, roland b. 1908. \"achomawi and atsugewi tales\". \'\'journal of american folklore\'\' 21:159-177. (twelve myths collected in 1900 and 1903.)\n* dixon, roland b. 1909. \"achomawi myths\". \'\'journal of american folklore\'\' 22:283-287. (five myths collected by [[jeremiah curtin]].)\n* gifford, edward winslow, and gwendoline harris block. 1930. \'\'california indian nights\'\'. arthur h. clark, glendale, california. (four previously published narratives, pp. 84-85, 134, 158, 285)\n* judson, katharine berry. 1912. \'\'myths and legends of california and the old southwest\'\'. a. c. mcclurg, chicago. (a version of the creation myth, p. 16)\n* kroeber, a. l. 1925. \'\'handbook of the indians of california\'\'. bureau of american ethnology bulletin no. 78. washington, d.c. (comparative comments on myths, p. 315)\n* margolin, malcolm. 1993. \'\'the way we lived: california indian stories, songs, and reminiscences\'\'. first edition 1981. heyday books, berkeley, cal

<page> <title>acico_twin_towers</title><text>{{use dmy dates|date=july 2013}}\n{{infobox building\n|name               = acico twin towers\n|image              = acico twin towers under construction on 7 march 2008.jpg\n|image_size         = 250px\n|caption            = nikko hotel dubai (on the left) and acico office tower (on the right) in late march 2008\n|building_type      = hotel and office\n|location           = [[dubai]], [[united arab emirates]]\n|roof               = \n|floor_count        = hotel tower - 60 <br> office tower - 49\n|start_date         = 2007\n|completion_date    = 2010\n|opening            = \n|elevator_count     = \n|floor_area         = \n|developer          = aerated concrete industries co. (acico)\n|architect          = bothe richter teherani architekten bda\n|latd               = 25\n|latm               = 13\n|lats               = 24.67\n|latns              = n\n|longd              = 55\n|longm              = 16\n|longs              = 56.58\n|longew             = e\n|iso_region         = ae\n|coordinates_display= title\n}}\n\n\'\'\'acico twin towers\'\'\' is a complex of two towers along [[sheikh zayed road]] in [[dubai]], [[united arab emirates]].  \'\'\'nikko hotel dubai\'\'\' (jal hotel) is the taller of the two, standing at 270&nbsp;m (886&nbsp;ft).  it is a hotel tower with 60 floors.  it will be operated by [[jal hotels|nikko hotels international]].  the shorter tower is \'\'\'acico office tower\'\'\' (nassima tower).  it has 55 floors and stands at 204&nbsp;m (656&nbsp;ft). construction began in 2005 and was expected in 2010.\n\n==see also==\n* [[list of tallest buildings in dubai]]\n\n==external links==\n{{commons|acico twin towers}}\n* [http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/cx/?id=112834 acico twin towers] on emporis.com\n* [http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingid=41397 nikko hotel dubai] on skyscraperpage.com\n* [http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingid=43042 acico office tower] on skyscraperpage.com\n* [http://www.fgould.com

purest form.<ref group=\"note\">due to acid techno in recent times being a sub-genre of a sub-genre of sorts, it is nearly impossible to truly verify even the opposite of these statements. there is little to no scholarly material on the subject.</ref>\n|derivatives=\n|subgenrelist=\n|subgenres=\n|fusiongenres=\n|regional_scenes=\n|other_topics=\n}}\n\n\'\'\'acid techno\'\'\' is a style of [[techno]] that developed out of late 1980s chicago [[acid house]].<ref name=\"all\">\"[{{allmusic|class=explore|id=style/d2895|pure_url=yes}} acid techno]\", \'\'[[allmusic]]\'\', macrovision corporation, retrieved 22 november 2009</ref> [[acid house]] was essentially house music made with a specific sound, obtained by using very distinctive instruments created mainly by [[roland corporation|roland]], such as the [[tb-303]] for bass and lead sounds, and the [[tr-909]] and [[tr-808]] for percussion.  \'\'acid\'\' specifically refers to the use of the roland [[tb-303]], or any other synthesizer designed to emulate its unique sound.<ref name=\"nash\">nash, rob (2009) \"[http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article5597864.ece?print=yes&randnum=1151003209000 techno: encyclopedia of modern music]\", \'\'the sunday times culture\'s <page> <title>acinos</title><text>{{taxobox\n|image = acinos arvensis01.jpg\n|image_caption = \'\'[[acinos arvensis]]\'\'\n|regnum = [[plantae]]\n|unranked_divisio = [[angiosperms]]\n|unranked_classis = [[eudicots]]\n|unranked_ordo = [[asterids]]\n|ordo = [[lamiales]]\n|familia = [[lamiaceae]]\n|genus = \'\'\'\'\'acinos\'\'\'\'\' [[carolus linnaeus|l.]]\n|subdivision_ranks = species\n|subdivision = see text.\n|}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acinos\'\'\'\'\' is a [[genus]] of ten species of [[annual plant|annual]] and short-lived [[evergreen]] [[perennial plant|perennial]] [[woody plant|woody]] [[plants]] native to southern [[europe]] and western [[asia]]. its name comes from the greek word \'\'akinos\'\', the name of a small aromatic plant. they are small, tufted, bushy or spreading plants growing to 10-45 cm tall. the 2-lipped, tubular flowers are in whorls borne on erect spike-like inflorescence produced in mid-summer.\n\n;selected species\n*\'\'[[acinos alpinus]]\'\'\n*\'\'[[acinos arvensis]]\'\'\n*\'\'[[acinos corsicus]]\'\'\n*\'\'[[acinos rotundifolius]]\'\'\n*\'\'[[acinos suaveolens]]\'\'\n\n==cultivation==\nmostly quite frost hardy, they will grow in poor soil as long as it is well drained (they do not like wet conditions) and need full sun.  propagate from seed or cuttings in spring. \n\n==external links==\n*[http://rbg-web2.rbge.org.uk/cgi-bin/nph-readbtree.pl/feout?family_xref=&genus_xref=acinos&species_xref=&taxon_name_xref=&rank= flora europaea: \'\'acinos\'\']\n\n[[category:lamiaceae]]\n\n{{lamiaceae-stub}}</text> </page>

<page> <title>acleros_bibundica</title><text>{{italic title}}\n{{taxobox\n| name = acleros bibundica\n| image = \n| image2 = \n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| classis = [[insect]]a\n| ordo = [[lepidoptera]]\n| familia = [[hesperiidae]]\n| genus = \'\'[[acleros]]\'\'\n| species = \'\'\'\'\'a. bibundica\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'acleros bibundica\'\' \n| binomial_authority = strand, 1913<ref>[http://www.nic.funet.fi/pub/sci/bio/life/insecta/lepidoptera/ditrysia/hesperioidea/hesperiidae/hesperiinae/acleros/index.html \'\'acleros\'\'] at funet.fi</ref>\n| synonyms =\n*\'\'acleros displacidus\'\' <small>rebel, 1914</small>\n}}\n\'\'\'\'\'acleros bibundica\'\'\'\'\' is a [[butterfly]] in the [[hesperiidae]] family. it is found in [[cameroon]] and the [[democratic republic of congo]].<ref name=atbut>[http://atbutterflies.com/downloads/hesperiidae_hesperiinae_2.doc afrotropical butterflies: hesperiidae - subfamily hesperiinae]</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{commons}}\n{{wikispecies}}\n{{refs}}\n\n[[category:animals described in 1913]]\n[[category:erionotini]]\n\n{{hesperiinae-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>acleros_mackenii</title><text>{{italic title}}\n{{taxobox\n| name = acleros mackenii\n| image = \n| image_width = 240px\n| image_caption = \n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| classis = [[insect]]a\n| ordo = [[lepidoptera]]\n| familia = [[hesperiidae]]\n| tribus = \n| genus = \'\'[[acleros]]\'\'\n| species = \'\'\'\'\'a. mackenii\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'acleros mackenii\'\' \n| binomial_authority = (trimen, 1868)<ref>[http://www.nic.funet.fi/pub/sci/bio/life/insecta/lepidoptera/ditrysia/hesperioidea/hesperiidae/hesperiinae/acleros/index.html \'\'acleros\'\'], site of markku savela</ref>\n| synonyms =\n*\'\'pamphila mackenii\'\' <small>trimen, 1868</small>\n*\'\'acleros nyassicola\'\' <small>strand, 1921</small>\n*\'\'acleros mackenii f. denia\'\' <small>evans, 1937</small>\n*\'\'apaustus olaus\'\' <small>plötz, 1884</small>\n*\'\'acleros instabilis\'\' <small>mabille, 1890</small>\n}}\n\'\'\'macken\'s skipper\'\'\' or \'\'\'macken\'s dart\'\'\' (\'\'acleros mackenii\'\') is a [[butterfly]] of the [[hesperiidae]] family. it is found from the east cape to [[kwazulu-natal]] and in [[zimbabwe]].\n\nthe [[wingspan]] is 27–32&nbsp;mm for males and 29-33 for females. adults are on wing year round but are more common in late summer, autumn and winter than in the hotter midsummer months.<ref>woodhall, s. field guide to butterflies of south africa, cape town: struik publishers, 2005.</ref>\n\nthe larvae feed on \'\'[[rhus]]\'\' species (including \'\'[[rhus corarius]]\'\') and \'\'[[acridocarpus]]\'\' species (including \'\'[[acridocarpus smeathmanni]]\'\').\n\n==subspecies==\n*\'\'acleros mackenii mackenii\'\' (possibly malawi, zambia, mozambique, zimbabwe, swaziland, south africa: limpopo province, mpumalanga, kwazulu-natal and the eastern cape province)\n*\'\'acleros mackenii olaus\'\' <small>(plötz, 1884)</small> (guinea, senegal, sierra leone, liberia, ivory coast, ghana, togo, nigeria, cameroon, central african republic, democrat

<page> <title>acom_international</title><text>the \'\'\'acom international\'\'\' was a [[golf]] tournament on the [[japan golf tour]] from 1990 to 2006. from 1990 to 1998, it was played with a [[stableford|modified stableford]] format similar to [[the international (golf)|the international]] on the u.s. [[pga tour]]. beginning in 1999, it was played at a standard [[stroke play]] format. the purse for the 2006 event was [[japanese yen|¥]]120,000,000, with ¥24,000,000 going to the winner.\n\n==tournament hosts==\n*1999–2006 ishioka golf club in [[ibaraki, ibaraki|ibaraki]]\n*1993–1998 seve ballesteros golf club in [[fukushima, fukushima|fukushima]]\n*1992 japan classic country club in [[mie prefecture|mie]]\n*1991 narita springs country club in [[chiba prefecture|chiba]]\n*1990 japan classic country club in [[mie prefecture|mie]]\n\n==winners==\n\'\'\'acom international\'\'\'\n*2006 [[mamo osanai]]\n*2005 [[david smail (golfer)|david smail]]\n*2004 [[toru suzuki]]\n*2003 [[masahiro kuramoto]]\n*2002 [[toru taniguchi]]\n*2001 [[kazuhiko hosokawa]]\n*2000 [[toru taniguchi]]\n*1999 [[hidemichi tanaka]]\n*1998 [[kaname yokoo]]\n*1997 [[kazuo kanayama]]\n*1996 [[kazuhiko hosokawa]]\n*1995 [[katsunori kuwabara]]\n*1994 [[naomichi ozaki]]\n*1993 [[todd hamilton]]\n*1992 [[hisao inoue]]\n*1991 [[masahiro kuramoto]]\n\n\'\'\'acom p.t.\'\'\'\n*1990 [[bob gilder]]\n\n\'\'\'acom team championship\'\'\' – unofficial event\n\n*1989 [[toshiaki sudo]] and [[kinya aoyagi]]\n*1988 [[bob gilder]] and [[doug tewell]]\n*1987 [[tomohiro maruyama]] and [[nobuo serizawa]]\n*1986 [[hajime meshiai]] and [[satoshi higashi]]\n*1985 [[brian jones (golfer)|brian jones]] and [[mike ferguson (golfer)|mike ferguson]]\n*1984 [[kosaku shimada]] and [[isao isozaki]]\n*1983 [[lu liang-huan]] and [[lu hsi-chuen]]\n\n==external links==\n*[http://www.jgto.org/pc/wg02090000init.do?year=2006&tournakbncd=0&conferencecd=31 coverage on japan golf tour\'s official site]\n\n{{former japan golf tour events}
<page> <title>acompsia_minorella</title><text>{{italic title}}\n{{taxobox\n| name = acompsia minorella\n| image = \n| image_caption = \n| image2 = \n| image2_caption = \n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| classis = [[insect]]a\n| ordo = [[lepidoptera]]\n| familia = [[gelechiidae]]\n| genus = \'\'[[acompsia]]\'\'\n| species = \'\'\'\'\'a. minorella\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'acompsia minorella\'\'\n| binomial_authority = (rebel, 1899)\n| synonyms =\n*\'\'brachycrossata minorella\'\' <small>rebel, 1899</small>\n}}\n\'\'\'\'\'acompsia minorella\'\'\'\'\' is a [[moth]] of the [[gelechiidae]] family. it is found in [[austria]], the [[czech republic]], [[france]], [[italy]], [[slovenia]] and [[switzerland]].<ref>[http://www.faunaeur.org/full_results.php?id=436851 fauna europaea]</ref> the habitat consists of warm forest steppes.\n\nthe [[wingspan]] is about 15 mm for males and females. the forewings are greyish brown, overlaid with yellow grey or light brown scales. the hindwings are dark grey. adults are on wing from may to june and again from july to september, probably in two generations per year.<ref>{{cite journal | last =  | first =   | year = 2002 | title = a review of the genus acompsia huebner, 1825, with description of new species (gelechiidae) | journal = nota lepidopterologica | volume = 25 | pages = 109-151 | url = http://biostor.org/reference/117974}}</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n{{wikispecies}}\n{{commons}}\n\n[[category:animals described in 1899]]\n[[category:dichomeridinae]]\n\n\n{{gelechiidae-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>aconitase</title><text>{{enzyme\n| name = aconitate hydratase\n| ec_number = 4.2.1.3\n| cas_number = 9024-25-3\n| iubmb_ec_number = 4/2/1/3\n| go_code = 0003994\n| image = 7acn.jpg\n| width = \n| caption = illustration of  pig aconitase in complex with the [fe<sub>4</sub>s<sub>4</sub>] cluster. the protein is colored by secondary structure, and iron atoms are blue and the sulfur red.<ref name=\"pmid1547214\">{{pdb|7acn}}; {{cite journal |pages=2735–48 |doi=10.1021/bi00125a014 |title=crystal structures of aconitase with isocitrate and nitroisocitrate bound |year=1992 |last1=lauble |first1=h. |last2=kennedy |first2=m. c. |last3=beinert |first3=h. |last4=stout |first4=c. d. |journal=biochemistry |volume=31 |issue=10 |pmid=1547214}}</ref>\n}}\n{{infobox protein family\n| symbol = aconitase\n| name = aconitase family<br />(aconitate hydratase)\n| image = pdb 1aco ebi.jpg\n| width = \n| caption = structure of aconitase.<ref name=\"pmid8151704\">{{pdb|1aco}}; {{cite journal |pages=437–51 |doi=10.1006/jmbi.1994.1246 |title=crystal structures of aconitase with trans-aconitate and nitrocitrate bound |year=1994 |last1=lauble |first1=h |journal=journal of molecular biology |volume=237 |issue=4 |pmid=8151704 |last2=kennedy |first2=mc |last3=beinert |first3=h |last4=stout |first4=cd}}</ref>\n| pfam = pf00330\n| interpro = ipr001030\n| smart = \n| prosite = pdoc00423\n| scop = 1aco\n| tcdb = \n| opm family = \n| opm protein = \n}}\n\'\'\'aconitase\'\'\' (aconitate hydratase; {{ec number|4.2.1.3}}) is an enzyme that catalyses the [[stereochemistry|stereo-specific]] [[isomerization]] of [[citrate]] to [[isocitrate]] via \'\'cis\'\'-[[aconitate]] in the [[tricarboxylic acid cycle]], a non-[[redox]]-active process.<ref name=\"pmid8262329\">{{cite journal |pmid=8262329 |year=1993 |last1=beinert |first1=h |last2=kennedy |first2=mc |title=aconitase, a two-faced protein: enzyme and iron regulatory factor |volume=7 |issue=15 |pages=1442–9 |journal=the faseb journal}}</r
<page> <title>acontia_nivipicta</title><text>{{italic title}}\n{{taxobox\n| name = \'\'acontia nivipicta\'\'\n| image = acontia_nivipicta.jpg\n| image_width = 220px\n| image_caption = \n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| subphylum = [[hexapoda]]\n| classis = [[insect]]a\n| ordo = [[lepidoptera]]\n| familia = [[noctuidae]]\n| tribus = \n| genus = \'\'[[acontia]]\'\'\n| species = \'\'\'\'\'a. nivipicta\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'acontia nivipicta\'\'\n| binomial_authority = butler, 1886\n| synonyms =\n*\'\'tarache nivipictoides\'\'\n}}\n\'\'\'\'\'acontia nivipicta\'\'\'\'\' is a [[moth]] of the [[noctuidae]] family. it is found in the northern two thirds of [[australia]].\n\nthe [[wingspan]] is about 20 mm. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://lepidoptera.butterflyhouse.com.au/acon/nivipic.html|title=acontia nivipicta|author=don herbison-evans & stella crossley|publisher=uts.edu.au|date=july 10, 2008|accessdate=2009-01-23}}</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{acontiinae-stub}}\n\n[[category:acontiinae]]</text> </page>	
<page> <title>acorn</title><text>{{other uses}}\n[[image:acorns small to large.jpg|thumb|acorns from small to large of the willow oak, \'\'quercus phellos\'\' (very small, at center); the southern red oak, \'\'quercus falcata\'\'; the white oak, \'\'quercus alba\'\'; and the scarlet oak, \'\'quercus coccinea\'\'; from southern greenville county, sc, usa. scale bar at upper right is 1.00 cm.]]\n[[file:acorn diagram.jpg|thumb|diagram of the anatomy of an acorn: a.) [[calybium and cupule|cupule]] b.) [[pericarp]] (fruit wall) c.) seed coat ([[testa (botany)|testa]]) d.) [[cotyledons]] (2) e.) [[plumule]] f.) [[radicle]] g.) remains of [[gynoecium|style]]. together d., e., and f. make up the embryo.]]\n\nthe \'\'\'acorn\'\'\', or \'\'\'oak nut\'\'\', is the [[nut (fruit)|nut]] of the [[oak]]s and their close relatives (genera \'\'[[quercus]]\'\' and \'\'[[lithocarpus]]\'\', in the family [[fagaceae]]). it usually contains a single [[seed]] (rarely two seeds), enclosed in a tough, leathery shell, and borne in a cup-shaped [[calybium|cupule]]. acorns vary from 1–6&nbsp;cm long and 0.8–4&nbsp;cm broad. acorns take between about 6 and 24 months (depending on the species) to mature; see [[list of quercus species]] for details of oak classification, in which acorn [[morphology (biology)|morphology]] and [[phenology]] are important factors.\n\n==ecological role==\n[[file:eastern grey squirrel in st james\'s park, london - nov 2006 edit.jpg|thumb|left|acorns are a vital food source for [[squirrel|squirrels.]]]]\nacorns play an important role in [[forest ecology]] when oaks are the dominant species or are plentiful.<ref name=usda>{{cite book|title=proceedings of the symposium on the ecology, management, and utilization of california oaks, june 26–28|year=1980|publisher=usda forest service general technical report psw-044|pages=1 to 368|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/psw/publications/documents/psw_gtr044/psw_gtr044.pdf|editor=plumb, timothy r.|quote=the symposium, held at scripps
<page> <title>acoso_y_derribo</title><text>\'\'\'acoso y derribo\'\'\' is a traditional sport in the [[doma vaquera]] tradition of spain, in which cattle are brought to the ground by two riders, the \'\'garrochista\'\' and the \'\'amparador\'\', using the \'\'[[garrocha]]\'\' or lance.<ref name=extre/> the horses used are often of [[hispano-Árabe]] stock.\nthe corral for this competition is divided into four areas.\nin 2010 the \'\'real federación hípica española\'\' decided to eliminate this competition from the official list.\n==external links==\n* [http://www.ctol.org/ladivisaarticles/an%20introduction%20to%20acoso%20y%20derribo.htm club taurino of london: an introduction to acoso y derribo (feria de caballo, jerez, 2006)], diana thurston\n*http://portaltaurino.net/especiales/otros_especiales/acoso_derribo.htm\n\n==references==\n\n{{reflist|refs=\n\n<ref name=extre>{{cite web|title=acoso y derribo|url=http://www.garrochistasextremadura.com/|publisher=asociación de garrochistas extremeños|accessdate=june 2011|language=spanish}}</ref> \n\n}}\n\n{{equestrian sports}}\n{{equine}}\n\n[[category:equestrian sports]]\n[[category:working stock horse sports]]\n\n{{horse-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>acosta</title><text>\'\'\'acosta\'\'\' is a [[spanish language|spanish]] and [[portuguese language|portuguese]] surname. originally it was used to refer to a person who lived by the seashore or from the mountains (\'\'encostas\'\'). it comes from the portuguese da costa ([[cognate]] of english \"coast\"), which in spanish became de acosta.\n\n==persons==\n*[[agustín acosta]], cuban baseball player\n*[[alberto acosta]] (born 1966), argentine footballer\n*[[alberto martín acosta martinez]] (born 1977), uruguayan footballer\n*[[alda ribiero acosta]] (contemporary), american terrorist in uruguay\n*[[armando acosta]] (contemporary), doom metal drummer, former member of the band saint vitus\n*[[bertrand blanchard acosta]] (1895&ndash;1954), american aviator who flew in the spanish civil war\n*[[carlos acosta]] (contemporary), cuban ballet dancer\n*[[cristóbal acosta]] (1515&ndash;1580), portuguese physician and natural historian\n*[[eliades acosta]] (born 1959), cuban politician\n*[[humberto acosta-rosario]] (1947&ndash;1968), puerto rican mia in vietnam\n*[[joaquín acosta]] (flourished 1800s), colombian explorer and author\n*[[joe acosta]] (born 1950), puerto rican salsa piano player\n*[[josé de acosta]] (1540&ndash;1600), spanish jesuit missionary and historian to latin america\n*[[josé julián acosta]] (1825&ndash;1891), puerto rican journalist and abolitionist\n*[[josephine acosta pasricha]] (1945&mdash;), filipino indologist and translator\n*[[juan f. acosta]] (1890&ndash;1968), puerto rican composer and music teacher\n*[[julio acosta garcía]] (1872&ndash;1954), president of costa rica 1920&ndash;1924\n*[[lautaro acosta]] (born 1988), argentine footballer\n*[[leopoldo acosta]] (born 1962), ecuadorian track and field athlete\n*[[manuel gregorio acosta]] (1921–1989), mexican-american painter\n*[[manuel da costa]] (1541&ndash;1604), portuguese jesuit priest, teacher, and missionary\n*[[manny acosta]] (born 1981) panamian baseball player\n*[[martha
<page> <title>acousmatic_music</title><text>\'\'\'acousmatic music\'\'\' is a form of [[electroacoustic music]] that is specifically composed for presentation using [[loudspeaker|speakers]], as opposed to a live performance. it stems from a compositional tradition that dates back to the introduction of [[musique concrète]] (a form of experimental music) in the late 1940s. unlike musical works that are realised using [[sheet music]] exclusively, [[musical composition|compositions]] that are purely acousmatic exist solely as [[audio format|audio recordings]] on media such as discs or tapes.{{citation needed|date=june 2013}}<!--does this mean, then, that stockhausen\'s \'\'studie ii\'\' and \'\'telemusik\'\', as well as ligeti\'s artikilation, all of which have been published as scores printed on paper, are not acousmatic music? does an acousmatic composition suddenly become non-acousmatic when a score is published of it? most importantly, who says so?-->\n\nthe compositional practice of acousmatic music features [[acousmatic sound]] as a central [[musical aspect]]. other aspects traditionally thought of as \'musical\' such as [[melody]], [[harmony]], [[rhythm]], [[meter (music)|metre]] may be present but more often consideration is given to sound-based characteristics such as [[timbre]] and [[spectral music|spectrum]]. compositional materials can include sounds derived from [[musical instruments]], [[voice]], electronically generated sound, audio that has been manipulated using various [[effects units|effect processors]], as well as general [[sound effects]] and [[field recordings]].\n\nthe music is produced with the aid of various [[music technology|music technologies]], such as [[digital recording|digital recorders]], [[digital signal processing]] tools and [[digital audio workstation]]s. using such technology various sound materials can be combined, juxtaposed, and transformed in any conceivable manner. in this context the compositional method can be seen as a pro
<page> <title>acoustic_gypsy_live</title><text>{{infobox album\n| name = acoustic gypsy live\n| type = live\n| artist = [[l.a. guns]]\n| cover = la guns acoustic gypsy live.jpg\n| released = september 27, 2011\n| genre = [[glam metal]]\n| label = [[favored nations entertainment]]\n}}\n\n\'\'\'\'\'acoustic gypsy live\'\'\'\'\' is an acoustic live album by [[tracii guns]]\'s version of [[l.a. guns]], which has since disbanded.<ref>http://www.amazon.com/acoustic-gypsy-live-guns/dp/b005f1qhqa/ref=sr_1_1</ref> \n\n\"little soldier\" is a new l.a. guns song. \"these arms of mine\" and \"love hurts\" are covers.\n\n==track listing==\n# crystal eyes\n# one way ticket\n# decide\n# dreamtime\n# electric gypsy\n# it\'s over now\n# never enough\n# over the edge\n# little soldier\n# sex action\n# these arms of mine\n# love hurts\n# the ballad of jayne\n# rip and tear\n\n==personnel== \n===band===\n* [[jizzy pearl]]: lead vocals\n* [[tracii guns]]: guitar\n* [[danny nordahl]]: bass\n* [[chad stewart]]: drums\n===additional musicians===\n* [[teddy andreadis]]: keyboards\n* [[muddy (bassist)|muddy]]: guitar\n* doni grey: percussion\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{l.a. guns}}\n\n[[category:2011 live albums]]\n[[category:l.a. guns live albums]]</text> </page>	
<page> <title>acoustic_foam</title><text>{{refimprove|date=august 2011}}\n\n\'\'\'acoustic foam\'\'\' is an open celled [[foam]] used for [[acoustic treatment]]. it attenuates airborne [[sound waves]] by increasing air resistance, thus reducing the [[amplitude]] of the waves. the energy is dissipated as [[heat]]. acoustic foam can be made in several different colors, sizes and thickness.\n\nacoustic foam comes in a variety of sizes and can be attached to walls, ceilings, doors, and other features of a room to control noise levels, vibration, and echoes. \n\nmany acoustic foam products are treated with [[dye]]s and/or [[fire retardant]]s.\n\n== uses ==\nthe objective of acoustic foam is to improve the sound quality by removing residual sound in any space. this purpose requires strategic placement of acoustic foam panels on walls, ceiling and floors, effectively eliminating all [[acoustic resonance|resonance]] within the room.\n\n=== acoustic enhancement ===\nthe objective is to enhance the properties of sound by improving speech clarity and [[sound quality]]. \n\nfor this reason, acoustic foam is often used in [[recording studio]]s. the purpose is to reduce, but not entirely eliminate resonance within the room. this is achieved by placing similar sized pieces of foam, often in the shape of cones or triangles, on opposite walls.\n\n=== how acoustic foam works ===\nacoustic foam is a lightweight material made from polyurethane foam either polyether or polyester, and also extruded [[melamine foam]]. it is usually cut into tiles - often with pyramid or wedge shapes - which are suited to placing on the walls of a recording studio or a similar type of environment to act as a sound absorber, thus enhancing the sound quality within a room. \n\nacoustic foam reduces or eliminates echoes and background noises by controlling the [[reverberation]] that sound can make by bouncing off walls. this type of sound absorption is different than soundproofing, which is typically used to 
<page> <title>acoustic_mirror</title><text>{{redirect|sound mirrors|the album by coldcut|sound mirrors}}\n{{multiple issues|\n{{lead too short|date=january 2013}}\n{{refimprove|date=january 2013}}\n}}\n\n[[image:ww1acousticmirrorkilnsea(paulglazzard)jan2007.jpg|right|thumb|300px|4.5 metre high ww1 concrete acoustic mirror near [[kilnsea]] grange, east yorkshire, uk. the pipe which held the \'collector head\' (microphone) can be seen in front of the structure]]\nan \'\'\'acoustic mirror\'\'\' is a passive device used to reflect and perhaps to focus (concentrate) [[sound wave]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=sound mirror|url=http://jonathanseary.blogspot.com/2011/02/sound-mirror.html|work=http://jonathanseary.blogspot.com/|publisher=jonathan seary development|accessdate=1 march 2013}}</ref>\n\n== acoustic aircraft detection ==\nprior to world war ii and the invention of [[radar]], acoustic mirrors were built as [[early warning]] devices around the coasts of great britain, with the aim of detecting incoming enemy aircraft by the sound of their engines.  the most famous of these devices still stand at [[denge]] on the [[dungeness (headland)|dungeness]] peninsula and at [[hythe, kent|hythe]] in [[kent]].  other examples exist in other parts of britain (including [[sunderland, tyne and wear|sunderland]], [[redcar]], [[boulby]], [[kilnsea]]) and [[selsey bill]], and [[baħar iċ-Ċagħaq]] in [[malta]]. the maltese sound mirror is known locally as \"the ear\" (il-widna) and appears to be the only sound mirror built outside great britain.\n\n[[image:listeningears(paulrusson)mar2005.jpg|thumb|right|acoustic mirrors at [[denge]]]]\n\nthe dungeness mirrors, known colloquially as the \"listening ears\", consist of three large [[concrete]] reflectors built in the 1920s&ndash;1930s.  their experimental nature can be discerned by the different shapes of each of the three reflectors: one is a long, curved wall about 5 m high by 70 m long, while the other two are dish-shaped constructions a
<page> <title>acoustic_radiation</title><text>{{infobox brain|\n  name            = auditory radiations |\n  latin           = radiatio acustica  |\n  graysubject     = |\n  graypage        = |\n  image           = |\n  caption         = |\n  image2          = |\n  caption2        = |\n  ispartof        = |\n  components      = |\n  artery          = |\n  vein            = |\n  braininfotype   = ancil |\n  braininfonumber = 393 |\n  meshname        = |\n  meshnumber      = |\n}}\nthe \'\'\'acoustic radiations\'\'\' or \'\'\'auditory radiations\'\'\' are structures found in the [[brain]], in the ventral [[cochlear pathway]], a part of the [[auditory system]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://neuro.psyc.memphis.edu/neuropsyc/np-ugp-audition.htm |title=audition |accessdate=2007-11-27 |format=htm |work=neuropsychology/behavioural neuroscience| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20071102042452/http://neuro.psyc.memphis.edu/neuropsyc/np-ugp-audition.htm| archivedate= 2 november 2007 <!--dashbot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fleshandbones.com/readingroom/viewchapter.cfm?id=1561 |title=thalamus |accessdate=2007-11-27 |format=pdf| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20071215032555/http://www.fleshandbones.com/readingroom/viewchapter.cfm?id=1561| archivedate= 15 december 2007 <!--dashbot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> lesions to the auditory radiations could be a cause of [[cortical deafness]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ivertigo.net/hearing/hrcen.html |title=central auditory disorders |accessdate=2007-11-27 |format=html |work=ivertigo.net}}</ref>\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{diencephalon}}\n{{auditory and vestibular pathways}}\n\n[[category:neuroscience]]\n\n\n{{anatomy-stub}}\n{{neuroscience-stub}}</text> </page>	
<page> <title>acoustical_oceanography</title><text>\'\'\'acoustical oceanography\'\'\' is the use of [[underwater sound]] to study the [[sea]], its boundaries and its contents.\n[[file:fish0204 - flickr - noaa photo library.jpg|thumb|a 38 khz hydroacoustic tow fin used to conduct acoustic surveys by noaa. alaska, southeast.]]\n==history==\n{{expand section|date=may 2008}}\nthe earliest and most widespread use of sound and [[sonar]] technology to study the properties of the sea is the use of an [[echo sounder]] to measure water depth.  the development of high resolution sonar in the second half of the 20th century made it possible to not just detect underwater objects but to classify them and even image them.\n\nimportant contributions to acoustical oceanography have been made by:\n* [[walter munk]]\n* [[hank medwin]]\n* [[john l spiesberger]]\n* [[c c leroy]]\n* [[david e weston]]\n* [[d. van holliday]]\n* [[charles greenlaw]]\n\n==theory==\n{{expand section|date=may 2008}}\nsee clay and medwin<ref name=\"claymedwin\">c. s. clay & h. medwin, fundamentals of acoustical oceanography (academic, boston, 1998).</ref>\n\n==measurements==\n{{expand section|date=may 2008}}\nsee clay and medwin<ref name=\"claymedwin\"/>\n\n==applications==\napplications of acoustical oceanography include:\n* fish population surveys\n* classification of fish species and other biota\n* rain rate measurement\n* wind speed measurement\n* [[echo sounder|water depth measurement]]\n* seabed classification\n* [[ocean acoustic tomography]]\n* [[acoustic thermometry|global thermometry]]\n* monitoring of ocean-atmospheric gas exchange\n\n===depth sounding===\n{{expand section|date=may 2008}}\n{{main|echo sounder}}\n\n===seabed classification===\n{{empty section|date=may 2008}}\n\n===marine biology===\n{{expand section|date=may 2008}}\n{{main|bioacoustics}}\nthe study of marine life, from [[plankton|microplankton]] to the [[blue whale]], uses [[bioacoustics]].<ref>e. j. simmonds & d. n. maclennan, fishe
<page> <title>acquanetta</title><text>{{use mdy dates|date=april 2012}}\n{{infobox person\n| name              = acquanetta\n| image             = \n| birthname         = burnu acquanetta \n| birth_date         = {{birth date|1921|7|17}}  \n| birth_place        = [[cheyenne, wyoming]], u.s.\n| death_date         = {{death date and age|2004|8|16|1921|7|17}}\n| death_place        = [[ahwatukee, arizona]], u.s.\n| othername         = \n| occupation        = actress\n| yearsactive       = 1942–1953\n| spouse            = jack ross\n| children          = \n| parents           = \n| influences        = \n| influenced        = \n| website           = \n| awards            = \n}}\n\'\'\'acquanetta\'\'\' (july 17, 1921 – august 16, 2004), nicknamed \"the venezuelan volcano,\" was a [[b-movie]] actress known for her exotic beauty.\n\n==early years==\nalthough accounts differ,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/2004-09-02/culture/acqua-blues/|title=acqua blues|date=september 2, 2004|work=[[phoenix new times]]|accessdate=december 23, 2010}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.flickr.com/photos/vieilles_annonces/2577937872/lightbox/|title=hollywood jungle girl - the actress aquanetta|date=february 14, 1952|work=[[jet magazine]] |accessdate=july 6, 2013}}</ref> acquanetta claimed she was born \'\'\'burnu acquanetta\'\'\' in [[ozone, wyoming]]. orphaned by her [[arapaho]] parents at the age of 2, she lived briefly with another family before being taken in by an artistic couple with whom she remained until she made the choice to live independently at the age of 15.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kzudaaaaibaj&sjid=hcmeaaaaibaj&pg=3234,1835551&dq=acquanetta&hl=en|title=billed as venezuela beauty,\' indian girl hoaxed filmdom|date=july 20, 1942|work=[[the milwaukee journal]]|accessdate=december 23, 2010}}</ref>\n\n==career==\nacquanetta started her career as a model in new york city with [[harry conover]]. she signed with [[universal stu
<page> <title>acraea_bomba</title><text>{{italic title}}\n{{taxobox\n| name = acraea bomba\n| image = grosesmithkirby1892rhopexotplate3.jpg\n| image_caption = figures 5,6\n| image2 = \n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| classis = [[insect]]a\n| ordo = [[lepidoptera]]\n| familia = [[nymphalidae]]\n| genus = \'\'[[acraea (genus)|acraea]]\'\'\n| species = \'\'\'\'\'a. bomba\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'acraea bomba\'\'\n| binomial_authority = [[henley grose-smith|grose-smith]], 1889<ref name=funet>[http://www.nic.funet.fi/pub/sci/bio/life/insecta/lepidoptera/ditrysia/papilionoidea/nymphalidae/heliconiinae/acraea/index.html \'\'acraea\'\'], site of markku savela</ref>\n| synonyms =\n*\'\'acraea (actinote) bomba\'\'\n*\'\'acraea anacreon bomba\'\'\n}}\n\'\'\'\'\'acraea bomba\'\'\'\'\', the \'\'\'bomba acraea\'\'\', is a [[butterfly]] in the [[nymphalidae]] family. it is found in [[kenya]], [[tanzania]], [[malawi]], [[zambia]] and on the eastern highlands of [[zimbabwe]].<ref name=atbut>[http://atbutterflies.com/downloads/nymphalidae_acraeini.doc afrotropical butterflies: nymphalidae - tribe acraeini]</ref> the habitat consists of grassland and open woodland.\n\nadults are on wing year round.\n\nthe larvae feed on \'\'[[alchemilla gracilipes]]\'\', \'\'[[aeschynomene]]\'\', \'\'[[adenia]]\'\' and \'\'[[wormskioldia]]\'\' species.\n\n==references==\n{{commons}}\n{{wikispecies}}\n{{refs}}\n\n[[category:animals described in 1889]]\n[[category:acraea (genus)]]\n\n{{heliconiinae-stub}}</text> </page>

<page> <title>acraea_induna</title><text>{{italic title}}\n{{taxobox\n| name = induna acraea\n| image = acraeainduna.jpg\n| image_width = 200px\n| image_caption = \n| regnum = [[animal]]ia\n| phylum = [[arthropod]]a\n| classis = [[insect]]a\n| ordo = [[lepidoptera]]\n| familia = [[nymphalidae]]\n| tribus = [[acraeini]]\n| genus = \'\'[[acraea]]\'\'\n| species = \'\'\'\'\'a. induna\'\'\'\'\'\n| binomial = \'\'acraea induna\'\'\n| binomial_authority = [[roland trimen|trimen]], 1895\n| synonyms =\n*\'\'hyalites induna\'\' <small>(trimen, 1895)</small>\n*\'\'actinote induna\'\' <small>(trimen, 1895)</small>\n*\'\'telchinia induna\'\' <small>(trimen, 1895)</small>\n*\'\'hyalites induna salmontana\'\' <small>henning & henning, 1996</small>\n}}\n\nthe \'\'\'induna acraea\'\'\' (\'\'acraea induna\'\') is a [[butterfly]] of the [[nymphalidae]] family. it is found in [[malawi]], [[zambia]], [[zimbabwe]] and [[south africa]]. the habitat consists of woodland and montane grassland.<ref name=atbut>[http://atbutterflies.com/downloads/nymphalidae_acraeini.doc afrotropical butterflies: nymphalidae - tribe acraeini]</ref>\n\nthe [[wingspan]] is 29–54&nbsp;mm for males and 54–62&nbsp;mm for females. adults are on wing from march to may. there is one generation per year.<ref>woodhall, s. field guide to butterflies of south africa, cape town: struik publishers, 2005.</ref>\n\nthe [[larva]]e feed on \'\'[[aeschynomene nodulosa]]\'\'.\n\n==subspecies==\n*\'\'acraea induna induna\'\' (malawi, zambia, zimbabwe: eastern highlands)\n*\'\'acraea induna salmontana\'\' <small>(henning & henning, 1996)</small> (only found in montane sourveld on the ridges of the soutpansberg in the limpopo province)\n\n==references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==external links==\n*[http://archive.org/stream/diegrossschmett13seit#page/n119/mode/2up \'\'die gross-schmetterlinge der erde\'\' 13: die afrikanischen tagfalter. plate xiii 55] \'\'a\'\'\n\n\n{{wikispecies}}\n{{commons}}\n\n[[category:acraea (genus)]]\n[[catego
